William Corder is hanged at Bury St Edmunds, England, for the murder of Maria Marten at the Red Barn a year earlier.

In South America, the Empire of Brazil and United Provinces of the Río de la Plata (modern-day Argentina) recognize the independence of Uruguay, causing the end of the Cisplatine War. Simón Bolívar declares himself dictator of Gran Colombia.
Russian forces succeed in the Battle of Akhaltsikhe against the Ottomans, capturing the fortress after an 8-day siege.
1828 Siebold typhoon: A typhoon kills approximately 10,000 people in Kyūshū, Japan.
Russo-Turkish War (1828–29): Varna is taken by the Russian army.

English naturalist and explorer William John Burchell collects the only known specimen of Parabouchetia brasiliensis, an exceptionally rare member of the nightshade family Solanaceae, in central Brazil.
The Office of the Institutions of Empress Maria is established in Russia to maintain the charitable institutions previously under the patronage of the late Empress.
Greek War of Independence: the London Protocol entails the creation of an autonomous Greek state under Ottoman suzerainty encompassing the Morea and the Cyclades.
Anouvong, ruler of the Kingdom of Vientiane, is deposed and the kingdom is annexed by Siam. During the war, the city of Vientiane is obliterated by Siamese forces.

Decembrist revolution (Argentina): Juan Lavalle, returning to Buenos Aires with troops that fought in the Cisplatine War, deposes the provincial governor Manuel Dorrego, reigniting the Argentine Civil Wars.
1828 United States presidential election: Andrew Jackson is elected President of the United States, defeating incumbent John Quincy Adams in a landslide.

An attempt to assassinate Gran Colombia's President Simon Bolívar fails while he is visiting Jamaica. Bolivar accepts a last-minute invitation to be elsewhere and his servant, hired by the Spanish royal government to kill Bolivar, kills Bolivar's paymaster by mistake.

The U.S. State of Georgia legislature charters the Medical Academy of Georgia, which becomes the Medical College of Georgia, and authorizes it to award a Bachelor of Medicine degree, making it the 13th oldest U.S. medical school and the sixth public medical school to be established.
The province of Echigo, Japan, is hit by a 6.8 magnitude earthquake, killing more than 1,500 people.
The Cornwall Bank, earliest constituent of ANZ bank in Australasia, is formed in Launceston, Van Diemens Land.
In November the 1828 New South Wales census was conducted.
32,000 Angolans are sold in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.
Ányos Jedlik creates the world's first electric motor.
Friedrich Wöhler synthesizes urea, possibly discrediting a cornerstone of vitalism.
Publication (begun on January 14) of Franz Schubert 's song cycle Winterreise is concluded posthumously.
August Klingemann 's adaptation of Johann Wolfgang von Goethe 's Faust premieres in Braunschweig.
Battle of Tarqui: Troops of Gran Colombia and Peru battle to a draw.

German composer Felix Mendelssohn conducts the first performance of Johann Sebastian Bach 's St Matthew Passion since the latter's death in 1750, in Berlin; the success of this performance sparks a revival of interest in Bach.
The bloodless Wellington–Winchilsea duel takes place at Battersea near London

Greece receives autonomy from the Ottoman Empire in the London Protocol, signed by Russia, France and Britain, effectively ending the Greek War of Independence. Greece continues to seek full independence through diplomatic negotiations with the three Great Powers.
Pope Pius VIII succeeds Pope Leo XII as the 253rd pope.
Vicente Guerrero becomes president of Mexico.
The Mexican city of Cuautla, Morelos, is founded.
The Catholic Relief Act is passed by the Parliament of the United Kingdom, granting a substantial measure of Catholic emancipation in Britain and Ireland.

Popular German conductor Felix Mendelssohn begins his first of 10 visits to Britain, touring the island until November 28. This includes the first London performance of his concert overture to A Midsummer Night's Dream, and his trip to Fingal's Cave.
The patent for an instrument called the accordion is applied for by Cyrill Demian (officially approved on May 23).
Joseph Smith claims to have received the Aaronic Priesthood from John the Baptist.
The Philadelphia Inquirer is founded in the U.S. as The Pennsylvania Inquirer.
The Swan River Colony (later to become the cities of Perth and Fremantle) is founded in Western Australia. This secures the western third of the Australian landmass for the British.
HMS Pickle captures the armed slave ship Voladora off the coast of Cuba.
The Oxford University Boat Club wins the first inter-university Boat Race, rowed at Henley-on-Thames.
Robert Peel establishes the Metropolitan Police Service in London, the first modern police force. The first officers, known by the nickname "bobbies", go on patrol on September 29.
Russo-Turkish War (1828–29): Russian Field-Marshal Hans Karl von Diebitsch launches the Trans-Balkan Offensive, which brings the Russian army within 68 kilometres (42 mi) of Istanbul.
George Shillibeer begins operating the first bus service in London.
In the United States, William Burt obtains the first patent for a form of typewriter, the typographer.
Gioacchino Rossini 's opera William Tell (Guillaume Tell) is first performed, in Paris.
The Prince de Polignac succeeds the Vicomte de Martignac as Prime Minister of France.
Finsteraarhorn, the highest summit of the Bernese Alps, is first ascended.
Mrs. Helen Dance, wife of the captain of the ship Sulphur, cuts down a tree to mark the founding day of the town of Perth, Western Australia.
King's College London is founded by Royal Charter, under the patronage of King George IV and the Prime Minister, The Duke of Wellington.
The Ottoman Empire signs the Treaty of Adrianople with Russia, ending the Russo-Turkish War.
African-American abolitionist David Walker publishes his Appeal to the Coloured Citizens of the World, in Boston, Massachusetts.
South African College is inaugurated in Cape Town.
Stephenson 's Rocket wins the Rainhill trials to determine the practicality of steam locomotives to operate the Liverpool and Manchester Railway in England.
The first modern hotel in the United States, Tremont House (Boston), opens.
Kaspar Hauser is found wounded.
The Chalmers University of Technology is founded in Gothenburg, Sweden.
Technical University of Denmark (DTU) opens.
The original Welland Canal opens for a trial run, with a ceremony at Port Dalhousie, Upper Canada.

In India, Lord William Bentinck, British Governor General of the Presidency of Fort William in Bengal, pushes through a regulation declaring that all who abet sati (suttee) (the self-immolation of a widow on her husband's funeral pyre) in parts of British India are guilty of culpable homicide. This follows long campaigning by Bengali reformer Ram Mohan Roy.
LaGrange College (later the University of North Alabama) begins operation, becoming the first publicly chartered college in Alabama.

Webster–Hayne debate: In the United States Congress, Robert Y. Hayne of South Carolina debates against Daniel Webster of Massachusetts about the question of states' rights vs. federal authority. The debate lasts until – January 27.
The London Protocol establishes the full independence and sovereignty of Greece from the Ottoman Empire, as the result of the Greek War of Independence.

A fire destroys the Argyll Rooms in London, where the Philharmonic Society of London presents concerts, but firefighters are able to prevent its further spread by use of their new equipment, steam-powered fire engines.

The Book of Mormon, subtitled "An Account Written by the Hand of Mormon, Upon Plates Taken from the Plates of Nephi", is first published, with E. B. Grandin printing the original edition in Palmyra, New York.
The Java War ends.

Joseph Smith and five others organize the Church of Christ (later renamed the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints), the first formally organized church of the Latter Day Saint movement, in northwestern New York.
Ecuador separates from Gran Colombia.
The Royal Swedish Yacht Club (KSSS) is founded.

The Indian Removal Act is signed into law by U.S. President Andrew Jackson, beginning the " Trail of Tears " with the forced relocation of more than 60,000 Indigenous Americans from the Cherokee, Muscogee (Creek), Seminole, Chickasaw, and Choctaw nations from the southeastern United States to what is now the U.S. state of Oklahoma. The relocation is accomplished by the end of 1838. In addition to the five tribes, thousands of Indian-owned black slaves are moved as well, and the move has the effect of beginning mass destruction of bison in North America.
7.5 magnitude earthquake kills more than 7,400 people in the Chinese province of Hebei.
William IV succeeds his brother George IV, as King of the United Kingdom.
French invasion of Algiers, leading to creation of French Algeria.

The General Assembly's Institution (later the Scottish Church College), one of the pioneering institutions that ushers in the Bengali Renaissance, is founded by Alexander Duff and Raja Ram Mohan Roy, in Calcutta, India.
Barthélemy Thimonnier is granted a French patent (#7454) for a sewing machine; it chains stitches at 200/minute.
Uruguay adopts its first constitution.
Greece grants citizenship to Romaniote Jews.
The July Revolution in France begins when people in Paris rebel against the July Ordinances, issued earlier in the day at Saint-Cloud by King Charles X of France.
"The Three Glorious Days" of the July Revolution in France begin. The Paris mob clashes with the National Guard: over the period 1,800 rioters and 300 soldiers will die.
"The Three Glorious Days" of the July Revolution in France end with establishment of a provisional government in Paris.
King Charles X of France flees to the Château de Rambouillet.
King Charles X abdicates the throne in favor of his grandson Henri, Count of Chambord, who never takes the throne.
Louis Philippe, the "Citizen King", becomes King of the French.
The Duc de Broglie is appointed Prime Minister of France by Louis Philippe.
The Belgian Revolution begins in Brussels with revolts against King William I of the Netherlands.
Edwin Beard Budding is granted an English patent for the invention of the lawn mower.
The opening of the Liverpool and Manchester Railway, the world's first intercity passenger railway operated solely by steam locomotives, takes place in England, UK.

Belgian Revolution: The army of the United Kingdom of the Netherlands fails to retake Brussels, a National Congress is summoned to draw up a Constitution and a Provisional Government of Belgium is established under Charles Latour Rogier.
Belgian Revolution: The Provisional Government in Brussels declares the creation of the independent state of Belgium.
Thomas Cochrane is granted a patent for the first airlock.
The Regeneration in Switzerland begins; more liberal constitutions are adopted in most cantons.
Jacques Laffitte succeeds the Duc de Broglie as Prime Minister of France.
Ferdinand II becomes King of the Two Sicilies.
The Whig Charles Grey, 2nd Earl Grey succeeds Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington, as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
On what is now called "the Ustertag ", men of the Canton of Zürich in Switzerland gather to demand a new constitution.
The Polish November Uprising begins in Warsaw against Russian rule.
Hector Berlioz 's most famous work, Symphonie fantastique, has its world premiere in Paris.
10,000 chests of opium are sold in China.
The independence of Belgium is recognized by the Great Powers.
Austins of Derry is established in Northern Ireland. Until closure in 2016, it is the world's oldest independent department store.
Sogo, a Japanese department store brand founded in Osaka, Japan, as predecessor part of Seven & I Retail Group.
In Munich, the museum Glyptothek opened.
The Entuzjastki society is founded in Poland.
William Lloyd Garrison begins publishing The Liberator, an anti- slavery newspaper, in Boston, Massachusetts.
Revolts in Modena, Parma and the Papal States are put down by Austrian troops.
Japanese department store, Takashimaya in Kyoto established.
Pope Gregory XVI succeeds Pope Pius VIII, as the 254th pope.
Dutch naval lieutenant Jan van Speyk blows up his own gunboat in Antwerp rather than strike his colours on the demand of supporters of the Belgian Revolution.
The Belgian Constitution of 1831 is approved by the National Congress.
French-born botanical explorer Aimé Bonpland leaves Paraguay for Argentina.
Battle of Debre Abbay: Ras Marye of Yejju marches into Tigray, and defeats and kills the warlord Sabagadis.
Battle of Olszynka Grochowska (Grochów): Polish rebel forces divide a Russian army.
The French Foreign Legion is founded.
Victor Hugo 's historical romantic Gothic novel Notre-Dame de Paris, known in English as The Hunchback of Notre-Dame, is published in Paris.
The Bosnian uprising (1831–32) against the Ottoman Empire begins.
Pedro I abdicates as Emperor of Brazil in favor of his 5-year-old son Pedro II, who will reign for almost 59 years.
The University of Alabama is founded.
The Sydney Morning Herald newspaper is first published, as the Sydney Herald.
Charles Albert becomes king of Sardinia after the death of King Charles Felix.
Ending of the First Anglo-Ashanti War (1823–1831).
Battle of Ostrołęka: The Poles fight another indecisive battle.
Merthyr Rising: Coal miners and others riot in Merthyr Tydfil, Wales, for improved working conditions.
Auxiliary paddle steamer Sophia Jane arrives at Sydney from London, becoming the first steamboat to operate in the coastal waters of New South Wales.
British Royal Navy officer James Clark Ross locates the position of the North Magnetic Pole, at this time on the Boothia Peninsula.
The North Carolina State House and Canova 's George Washington are destroyed by fire in Raleigh, North Carolina.
Russian imperial officials in Wallachia adopt Regulamentul Organic, introducing a period of unprecedented reforms that provide for Westernization of this region of Romania.
The volcanic Graham Island briefly emerges in the Mediterranean.
Leopold of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha is inaugurated as the first King of the Belgians, in Brussels.
The Dutch Ten Days' Campaign against Belgium is halted by a French army.
American Baptist minister William Miller preaches his first sermon on the Second Advent of Christ in Dresden, New York, launching the Advent Movement in the United States.
Nat Turner's slave rebellion in the United States breaks out in Southampton County, Virginia.
Michael Faraday demonstrates electromagnetic induction at the Royal Society of London. Joseph Henry recognises it at about the same time.
Coronation of King William IV of the United Kingdom (he will reign until 1837).
Battle of Warsaw: The Army of Russia takes the Polish capital after a two-day battle to crush the Polish uprising.
The House of Commons of the United Kingdom passes the Great Reform Bill to expand the franchise, but this is later defeated in the House of Lords.
The first national presidential nominating convention in the United States concludes after three days as the Anti-Masonic Party selects its nominee for President in Baltimore, Maryland.
Ioannis Kapodistrias, Greek head of state and founder of Greek independence, is assassinated in Nafplion.
The November Uprising ends in the defeat of Polish forces.
Michael Faraday constructs an early form of dynamo.

The 1831 Bristol riots ("Queen Square riots") in Bristol (England) begin, in connection with the Great Reform Bill controversy. Quelled by the authorities and the military on October 31, 100 city centre properties are destroyed, at least 120 are estimated to have been killed, 31 of the rioters will be sentenced to death and a colonel facing court-martial for failure to control the riot commits suicide.
In Southampton County, Virginia, escaped slave Nat Turner is captured and arrested for leading the bloodiest slave rebellion in United States history.
Slave trading is forbidden in Brazil.
The Kings School (Parramatta) was approved to be established.
Ecuador and Venezuela are separated from Gran Colombia.
First Canut Revolt: After a bloody battle with the military causing 600 deaths, rebellious silk workers seize Lyon, France.

Global financial services business Assicurazioni Generali is founded in Trieste (at this time in the Austrian Empire) as Imperial Regia Privilegiata Compagnia di Assicurazioni Generali Austro-Italiche.

The Baptist War (Christmas Rebellion) begins in Jamaica, with the setting afire of the Kensington House in St James Parish, inspiring thousands of black slaves to revolt against their British masters. At its peak, more than 20,000 people will be involved, and more than 500 killed.
Charles Darwin embarks from Plymouth on the second voyage of HMS Beagle which will be the foundation for his life of scientific study.
Gramercy Park is deeded to New York City.
Egyptian–Ottoman War (1831–1833): Muhammad Ali of Egypt 's French-trained forces occupy Ottoman Syria.
Scholar Rifa'a at-Tahtawi returns from study in Paris to Egypt, where he will participate in the Nahda.
Abolitionist William Lloyd Garrison founds the New-England Anti-Slavery Society.

The Christmas Rebellion of slaves is brought to an end in Jamaica, after the island's white planters organize militias and the British Army sends companies of the 84th regiment to enforce martial law. More than 300 of the slave rebels will be publicly hanged for their part in the destruction.
The Swan River Colony is renamed Western Australia.
The Florida Legislative Council grants a city charter for Jacksonville, Florida.
Ecuador annexes the Galápagos Islands.
A cholera epidemic in London claims at least 3,000 lives; the contagion spreads to France and North America later this year.
Charles Darwin and the crew of HMS Beagle arrive at South America for the first time.
In Hiram, Ohio, a group of men beat, tar and feather Mormon leader Joseph Smith.
The Black Hawk War begins in the United States.
The Treaty of London creates an independent Kingdom of Greece. Otto of Wittelsbach, Prince of Bavaria, is chosen King; thus begins the history of modern Greece.
The Egyptians, aided by Maronites, seize Acre from the Ottoman Empire after a 7-month siege.
Greece is recognized as a sovereign nation; the Treaty of Constantinople ends the Greek War of Independence in July.
Juan Godoy discovers the rich silver outcrops of Chañarcillo sparking the Chilean silver rush.
The Hambacher Fest, a demonstration for civil liberties and national unity in Germany, ends with no result.
The Rideau Canal in eastern Ontario (Canada) is opened.
6 – The June Rebellion in France, anti- monarchist riots led chiefly by students, breaks out in Paris.

The Reform Act receives royal assent after passage by the British Parliament, reforming the electoral system and setting uniform law for voting rights in England and Wales, though not in Scotland or Ireland.
The Strasburg Rail Road is incorporated by the Pennsylvania State Legislature, making it the oldest continuously operating railroad in the Western Hemisphere.
Global conglomerate Jardine Matheson is founded in Canton (modern day Guangzhou) in Qing dynasty China by Scottish merchants.
André-Michel Guerry presents his Essay on moral statistics of France to the French Academy of Sciences, a significant step in the founding of empirical social science.
Durham University is founded in the north of England by an act of Parliament given royal assent by King William IV.
The Commissioner of Indian Affairs post is created within the United States Department of War.
The United States Survey of the Coast is revived within the Department of the Treasury.
The Bad Axe Massacre ends the last major Native American rebellion east of the Mississippi in the United States.
William Howley, Archbishop of Canterbury, has his coach attacked by an angry mob on his first official visit to Canterbury because of his opposition to the Reform Act in the United Kingdom.
Leopold I of Belgium marries the daughter of the French king Louise of Orléans in a dynastic marriage at the Château de Compiègne
Black Hawk (Sauk leader) surrenders to the United States authorities, ending the Black Hawk War.
Qasim al-Ahmad is appointed as the new Ottoman Governor (mutasallim) of Jerusalem (Kudüs), after Sultan Mahmud II dismisses Muhammad Said Agha.

Prince Otto of Bavaria, the second oldest son of King Ludwig I, is selected by Europe's major powers to become Othon, the first King of Greece, after the Hellenic nation's reacquisition of independence.

Principal Chief Levi Colbert (Itawamba Mingo) and other leaders of the Chickasaw Nation of American Indians sign the Treaty of Pontotoc Creek with the United States, ceding their remaining 9,400 square miles of land to the U.S., in return for a promise that they will receive all proceeds of sales of the land by the federal government to private owners, along with expenses for relocation and food and supplies for one year. The area ceded includes the entire northern one-sixth of the state of Mississippi.
Wabash College, a small, private, liberal arts college for men, is founded.

Nullification Crisis: The U.S. state of South Carolina passes the Ordinance of Nullification, challenging the power of the U.S. federal government, by declaring that it will not enforce national tariffs signed into law in 1828 and 1832.
1832 United States presidential election: Andrew Jackson is re-elected president.
Siege of Antwerp: The last remaining Dutch stronghold, Antwerp Citadel, comes under French attack in the aftermath of the Belgian Revolution.
U.S. President Andrew Jackson responds to the Nullification Crisis by threatening to send the U.S. Army and Navy into South Carolina if it does not comply.
Battle of Konya: The Egyptians defeat the main Ottoman army in central Anatolia.
The Siege of Antwerp ends with the Dutch garrison losing the citadel.
The Cumberland and Oxford Canal connects the largest lakes of southern Maine with the seaport of Portland, Maine.
The first commutator DC electric motor, capable of turning machinery, is demonstrated by William Sturgeon in London.
Publication begins (posthumously) of Carl von Clausewitz 's Vom Kriege (" On War ").
Global watch brand Longines is founded in Switzerland.
The City of Buffalo in New York is incorporated.
George Catlin starts to live among the Sioux in the Dakota Territory.
John C. Calhoun becomes the first Vice President of the United States to resign.
The first Baedeker guidebook, Voyage du Rhin de Mayence à Cologne, is published in Koblenz.
The United Kingdom reasserts British sovereignty over the Falkland Islands in the South Atlantic Ocean.
Prince Otto Friedrich Ludwig of Bavaria arrives at the port of Nafplio to assume the title King Othon the First of Greece
The United States Supreme Court hands down its landmark decision of Barron v. Mayor and City Council of Baltimore.

General Antonio López de Santa Anna is elected President of Mexico by the legislatures of 16 of the 18 Mexican states. During his frequent absences from office to fight on the battlefield, Santa Anna turns the duties of government over to his vice president, Valentín Gómez Farías.
Over 300 delegates from England, Scotland, Wales and Ireland travel to the office of the Prime Minister, the Earl Grey, to call for the immediate abolition of slavery throughout the British Empire.
In Germany, Carl Friedrich Gauss and Wilhelm Weber obtain permission to build an electromagnetic telegraph in Göttingen.
In Alexandria, Virginia, an attack is made on U.S. President Andrew Jackson.
The Ottoman Empire promulgates a firman ratifying the Peace Agreement of Kütahya, bringing an end to the Egyptian-Ottoman War.
The Le Van Khoi revolt breaks out in southern Vietnam against Emperor Minh Mang, who has desecrated the deceased mandarin Le Van Duyet.
At least 170 people, and perhaps as many as 265, are killed when the British brig Lady of the Lake, sinks off Cape St. Francis at Newfoundland. Only 15 people survive.
The Chilean Constitution of 1833 is promulgated.
Ada Lovelace is introduced to Charles Babbage, a pioneer in developing a computer, by Mary Somerville.
Dubai gets independence from the United Kingdom and is founded as a city.
An earthquake at Fort Nisqually is experienced by William Fraser Tolmie; his journal entry records the first written eyewitness account of an earthquake in the Puget Sound region.
Liberal Wars: The forces of Queen Maria II of Portugal win the Battle of Cape St. Vincent, defeating the supporters of her uncle, King Miguel, who usurped the throne in 1828.
The Treaty of Hünkâr İskelesi creates an alliance between the Ottoman Empire and the Russian Empire.

At Oxford University, John Keble preaches a sermon against the Church Temporalities (Ireland) Act 1833. Keble's sermon, published afterwards published as National Apostasy, is traditionally considered as the beginning of the Oxford Movement of High Church Anglicans.
A mob in Jackson County, Missouri, destroys the printing office of the early Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints containing what becomes known as The Doctrine and Covenants.
King William's College opens on the Isle of Man.
The settlement of Chicago is established by 350 settlers at the estuary of the Chicago River in the U.S. state of Illinois.
The Canadian ship SS Royal William sets out from Pictou, Nova Scotia on a 25-day passage of the Atlantic Ocean, primarily under steam, to Gravesend in England.

Future United States President Benjamin Harrison is born in Ohio. From this date until the death of Former U.S. President James Madison on June 28 1836, a total of 18 Presidents of the United States (2 former, 1 current, and 15 future) are living; which is more than any other time period in U.S. history.
The Canton of Basel is partitioned by the Swiss Tagsatzung to create the two half-cantons of Basel-City and Basel-Country.

The British Slavery Abolition Act 1833, beginning the process of giving slaves in much of the British Empire their freedom, receives royal assent, with an effective date of August 1, 1834. A £20 million fund is established to compensate slaveowners.
The Parliament of the United Kingdom votes to pass the Factory Acts, limiting child labour.

The chartered ship Amphitrite sinks off Boulogne-sur-Mer while transporting 108 British female convicts and 12 children from Woolwich in England to New South Wales in what is now Australia. All of the passengers die, along with 13 of the 16 crew. The only survivors are three members of the crew.
Oberlin College is founded in the U.S. at Oberlin, Ohio.
At least 6,000 people are killed when an 8.0 magnitude earthquake shakes the Chinese province of Yunnan destroying buildings, homes and temples.

Three-year-old Isabella II becomes Queen of Spain, under the regency of her mother, Maria Christina of the Two Sicilies. Her uncle Don Carlos, Conde de Molina challenges her claim, beginning the First Carlist War.
Alfred, Lord Tennyson, writes his oft-quoted poem, Ulysses.
13 – A very spectacular occurrence of the Leonid meteor shower is observed all over North America, and is the inspiration for the song " Stars Fell on Alabama ".
An 8.7 magnitude earthquake strikes Sumatra in what is now Indonesia.
The American Anti-Slavery Society is founded.
Kaspar Hauser, the well known and mysterious German youth, is fatally stabbed. He dies three days later on December 17.
The dawn of biochemistry: The first enzyme, diastase, is discovered by Anselme Payen.
H.R.H. Prince Mongkut of Siam founds the Dhammayut Buddhist reform movement.
American healthcare brand McKesson Corporation established as a partnership.
The national anthem of the Russian Empire, God Save the Tsar!, is first performed.
Greece recaptures the Acropolis of Athens.
Zollverein (Germany): Customs charges are abolished at borders within its member states.
The government of Mexico imprisons Stephen F. Austin in Mexico City.
The Wilmington and Raleigh Railroad is chartered in Wilmington, North Carolina.
Wake Forest University is founded as the Wake Forest Manual Labor Institute in Wake Forest, North Carolina.
Freed American slaves from Maryland form a settlement in Cape Palmas, it is named the Republic of Maryland.
Robert Owen organizes the Grand National Consolidated Trades Union in the United Kingdom.
York, Upper Canada, is incorporated as Toronto.
The United States Survey of the Coast is transferred to the Department of the Navy.
John Herschel discovers the open cluster of stars now known as NGC 3603, observing from the Cape of Good Hope.
Andrew Jackson is censured by the United States Congress (expunged in 1837).
John Scott Russell 's Scottish Steam Carriage Company begins operating a regular passenger service in west central Scotland on the open road between Glasgow and Paisley, Renfrewshire.
The LaLaurie mansion in New Orleans burns, and Madame Marie Delphine LaLaurie flees to France.
The Whig Party is officially named by United States Senator Henry Clay.
Spain, France, Portugal and the United Kingdom sign the Quadruple Alliance.
The founder of the Second Saudi State, Imam Turki bin Abdullah Al Saud, is assassinated after the Friday prayers by Ibrahim Hamza, following the orders of his cousin Mishari.

The Syrian Peasant Revolt (1834–35) erupts in Egyptian-ruled Ottoman Syria, encompassing peasant uprisings in Palestine and Transjordan, at Galilee and Hauran and at the Syrian coast; the rebellions are suppressed with harsh military response leading to thousands of deaths and mostly subdued by August, though the Syrian coast uprising lasts until early 1835.
Greek independence: General Theodoros Kolokotronis is sentenced to death for treason, for resisting the rule of Otto of Greece (he is released the following year).
American inventor and businessman Cyrus McCormick is granted a patent for his mechanical reaper.
10 – Anti-abolitionist riots break out in New York City.

Imam Faisal bin Turki enters Riyadh and upon entering his father's palace, assassinates his father's murderer, Ibrahim Hamza, and his master; Mishari, and becomes the ruler and founder of the Second Saudi State.
The Spanish Inquisition, which began in the 15th century, is suppressed by royal decree.
William Lamb, 2nd Viscount Melbourne succeeds Earl Grey as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
The Liberal Wars end in Portugal.
The Office of Indian Affairs is organized in the United States.
Slavery is abolished in the British Empire, by the Slavery Abolition Act 1833.
Construction work begins on the Wilberforce Monument in Kingston Upon Hull.
12 – Ursuline Convent riots: A convent of Ursuline nuns is burned near Boston.

In the Empire of Brazil, the Additional Act provides for establishment of the Provincial Legislative Assembly, extinction of the State Council, replacement of the Regency Trina, and introduction of a direct and secret ballot.
The Poor Law Amendment Act in the United Kingdom states that no able-bodied British man can receive assistance, unless he enters a workhouse (a kind of poorhouse).
The South Australia Act allows for the creation of a colony there.
The emigrant ship Sybelle out of Cromarty (Scotland) is wrecked off St. Paul Island (Nova Scotia) with the loss of all 316 passengers and all but six of her crew.
The Gleaner newspaper is first published in Jamaica.
Athens becomes Greece's capital city.

The Palace of Westminster is destroyed by fire, along with both the House of Commons and the House of Lords (which are not in session) of the British Parliament. An investigation later traces the disaster to an order from the Exchequer to the Board of Works to destroy the tally sticks that had been stored as part of record keeping, the use of the furnaces beneath the House of Lords to carry out the task, and the failure of authorities to stop the work or to fight the fire after smoke had first been detected, the conclusion being that the fire was "wholly attributable to carelessness and negligence."

William Lamb, 2nd Viscount Melbourne becomes the last Prime Minister of the United Kingdom to be dismissed by the British monarch. King William IV temporarily appoints Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington, to form a caretaker government.
The Zollverein institutes the first regular census in Germany. The population is 23,478,120.
Sir Robert Peel succeeds The Duke of Wellington as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
The British East India Company monopoly on China trade ends. It appoints a Tea Committee to assess the potential of Assam tea.
Thomas Davenport, inventor of the first American DC electrical motor, installs his motor in a small model car, creating one of the first electric cars.
The Sixth Xhosa War is characterized by severe clashes between white settlers and Bantu peoples in Cape Colony; Dutch-speaking settlers colonize the area north of Orange River.
The Medical School of Louisiana (later Tulane University) is founded in New Orleans.
The Romanian language is banned in the schools and government facilities of the Russian Empire's Bessarabia Governorate.
Charles Babbage begins the conceptual design of the Analytical Engine, a mechanical forerunner of the modern computer. It will not be built in his lifetime.
Statue of Jean-Jacques Rousseau is erected in his birthplace of Geneva.
HMS Beagle anchors off the Chonos Archipelago on her second voyage, with Charles Darwin on board as naturalist.
The United States public debt contracts to zero, for the only time in history.
Malê Revolt: African slaves of Yoruba Muslim origin revolt against Brazilian owners at Salvador, Bahia.
Queen Maria II of Portugal marries Auguste de Beauharnais, 2nd Duke of Leuchtenberg, in Lisbon; he dies only two months later.
Saint Paul's in Macau is largely destroyed by fire after a typhoon hits.
The first assassination attempt against a President of the United States is carried out against U.S. President Andrew Jackson at the United States Capitol
Slavery is abolished in Mauritius.
1835 Concepción earthquake: Concepción, Chile, is destroyed by an earthquake. The resulting tsunami destroys the neighboring city of Talcahuano.
Ferdinand becomes Emperor of Austria.
The Academia Mexicana de la Lengua (Mexican Academy of Language) is established.
Lord Melbourne succeeds Sir Robert Peel as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
The first railway in continental Europe is opened between Brussels and Mechelen in Belgium.
Braulio Carrillo is sworn in as Head of State of Costa Rica.
Hans Christian Andersen 's Fairy Tales Told for Children. First Collection. is first published..
Matua, High Priest (taura tupua) of the Polynesian island of Mangareva, is baptized into the Roman Catholic Church.
At least 224 people, most of them female convicts being transported from Cork, Ireland, to Australia, are drowned when the British barque Neva is wrecked in the Bass Strait. Only 15 people survive.
The Mexican State of Aguascalientes is formed, by decree of President Antonio López de Santa Anna.
Kingston Penitentiary opens in Kingston, Ontario.
The universal Catholic Apostolic Church is organized, initially in the U.K.
James Bowman Lindsay demonstrates a constant electric light at a public meeting in Dundee, Scotland.
An assassination attempt against King Louis Philippe I of France is attempted by Giuseppe Marco Fieschi, who uses a home-made volley gun and kills 10 people. The King escapes with a minor wound.
The Bertelsmann company is founded by Carl Bertelsmann as a religious printer and publisher in Prussia.
In the U.S., The New York Sun prints the first of six installments of the Great Moon Hoax.
St. Vincent's Ecclesiastical Seminary, a predecessor of Castleknock College, is founded by the Vincentian community in Dublin, Ireland.
European settlers, landing on the north banks of the Yarra River in Victoria, Australia, found the settlement of Melbourne.
H. Fox Talbot exposes the world's first known photographic negatives, at Lacock Abbey in England.
Charles Darwin arrives at the Galápagos Islands, aboard HMS Beagle.
William Lloyd Garrison publishes Angelina Grimké 's anti-slavery letter in The Liberator.
The Ragamuffin War begins in Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil.
The Texas Revolution – Battle of Gonzales: Mexican soldiers attempt to disarm the people of Gonzales, Texas, but encounter stiff resistance from a hastily assembled militia.
The Staedtler Company (pencil manufacturers) is founded by J. S. Staedtler in Nuremberg, Germany.
Battle of Concepción: The Texian Army defeats the Mexicans.
The United Tribes of New Zealand is founded at Waitangi, with the Declaration of the Independence of New Zealand.
Construction is completed on the Wilberforce Monument in Kingston Upon Hull.
Halley's Comet reaches perihelion, its closest approach to the Sun.

Two London men, James Pratt and John Smith, are hanged in front of Newgate Prison in London, after a conviction of buggery. They are the last to suffer capital punishment for homosexual acts in England.
Start of Moriori genocide, the killing and enslavement of the indigenous people of the Chatham Islands by 500 Māori people from New Zealand.
The Bavarian Ludwig Railway opens between Nuremberg and Fürth, with a train hauled by the English-built Der Adler (" The Eagle "), the first railway in Germany.
Future U.S. President James K. Polk becomes Speaker of the United States House of Representatives.
The Army of the Republic of Texas captures San Antonio.
The Great Fire of New York begins and lasts until the next day, destroying 530 buildings, including the New York Stock Exchange.
The Texas Declaration of Independence is signed by American residents rebelling against Mexico at Goliad, Texas.
The Raleigh and Gaston Railroad is chartered in Raleigh, North Carolina.
— The Second Seminole War, led by Seminole Chief Osceola breaks out in the U.S. state of Florida.
Civil war erupts in Uruguay, between supporters of the Blanco and Colorado parties.
The Cachar Levy, forerunner of the Assam Rifles, is founded in India.
The Treaty of New Echota is signed between the United States Government and representatives of the Cherokee Nation.
Fort Cass is established, the military headquarters and site of the largest internment camps during the 1838 Trail of Tears.
The British Geological Survey is founded, as the world's first national geological survey.
Edward Strutt Abdy publishes his Journal of a Residence and Tour in the United States of North America: From April, 1833, to October 1834.
The first Bulgarian -language school opens in the Ottoman Empire.
English becomes the official language of India.
Charles-Louis Havas creates Havas, the first news agency in the world (which later spawns Agence France-Presse).
David Strauss begins publication of Das Leben Jessu, kritisch bearbeitet ("The life of Jesus, critically examined") in Tübingen.
The first Egyptian Museum in Cairo opened.
The French word for their language changes to français, from françois.
The British East India Company negotiates a lease of the Darjeeling area west of the Mahananda River, from the Kingdom of Sikkim.
Juan Manuel de Rosas becomes Caudillo of Argentina.
— Hill Street Academy is named Colombo Academy and acquired by the Government, establishing the first public school in Sri Lanka.
Queen Maria II of Portugal marries Prince Ferdinand Augustus Francis Anthony of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha.
Former U.S. Representative Davy Crockett of Tennessee arrives in Texas to join the Texan fight for independence from Mexico.
Will County, Illinois, is formed.
HMS Beagle, with Charles Darwin on board, reaches Sydney.
London and Greenwich Railway opens its first section, the first railway in London, England.
Texas Revolution: The Battle of the Alamo begins, with an American settler army surrounded by the Mexican Army, under Santa Anna.
Samuel Colt receives a United States patent for the Colt revolver, the first revolving barrel multishot firearm.
Texas Revolution – Convention of 1836: Delegates from many Texas communities gather in Washington-on-the-Brazos, Texas, to deliberate independence from Mexico.
Texas Revolution – Convention of 1836: The Texas Declaration of Independence is signed by 60 delegates, and the Republic of Texas is declared.
Texas Revolution: The Battle of the Alamo ends. At least 182 Texan settler soldiers die in a struggle against more than 2,000 Mexican soldiers.
Sultan Mahmud II abolishes the posts of Reis ül-Küttab and Kahya Bey, and establishes the Ottoman ministries of Foreign Affairs and of the Interior in their place.

Texas Revolution – Convention of 1836: Delegates adopt the Constitution of the Republic of Texas, modeled after the United States Constitution. It allows slavery, requires free blacks to petition Congress to live in the country, but prohibits import of slaves from anywhere but the United States.
Goliad massacre: 342 Texan prisoners are shot and killed, along with Texan General James Walker Fannin, by Mexican troops in Goliad, near the Presidio La Bahía.
The United States Survey of the Coast is returned to the U.S. Treasury Department, and renamed the U.S. Coast Survey.
Richard Wagner 's opera Das Liebesverbot is performed for the first time, in Magdeburg.
The first monthly part of Charles Dickens 's The Pickwick Papers (" The Posthumous Papers of the Pickwick Club..., edited by Boz") is published in London.
The Wisconsin Territory is created; the first capital is Belmont.
Texas Revolution – Battle of San Jacinto: Mexican forces under General Antonio López de Santa Anna are defeated at San Jacinto, Texas.
Texas Revolution: Forces under Texas General Sam Houston capture Mexican General Antonio López de Santa Anna.
The Ancient Order of Hibernians, an Irish Catholic fraternal organization, is founded in New York City.
The settlement of Mayagüez, Puerto Rico is elevated to the royal status of villa, by the government of Spain.

Texas Revolution: The Treaties of Velasco are signed, between Mexican General Antonio López de Santa Anna and the Republic of Texas. In exchange for his freedom and the guarantee of free passage back to Mexico, General Santa Anna gives his recognition to the independence of Texas. The Mexican government refuses to ratify the treaties.
During an eclipse of the Sun, English astronomer Francis Baily observes the phenomenon named after him as Baily's beads.
Fort Parker massacre: Among those captured by Native Americans is 9-year-old Cynthia Ann Parker. She later gives birth to a son named Quanah, who becomes the last chief of the Comanche.
Arkansas is admitted into as the 25th state of the United States of America.
The first numbered U.S. patent 1 (after filing 9,957 unnumbered patents) is granted to John Ruggles, for improvements to railroad steam locomotive tires.
The Champlain and St. Lawrence Railroad opens between St. John and La Prairie, Quebec, the first steam-worked passenger railroad in British North America.
The settlement of Adelaide, South Australia, is founded.
The first English-language newspaper is published in Hawaii.
The Marriage Act in the United Kingdom establishes civil marriage and registration systems that permit marriages in nonconformist chapels, and a Registrar General of Births, Marriages, and Deaths.
The settlement of Houston, Texas is founded.
Rebuilding begins at the Hurva Synagogue in Jerusalem.
Sam Houston is elected as the first president of the Republic of Texas.
The Riograndense Republic is proclaimed in South America.

Charles Darwin returns to England aboard HMS Beagle, with biological data he will later use to develop his theory of evolution, having left South America on August 17. October 2: Darwin returns aboard HMS Beagle.
Theodor Fliedner, a Lutheran minister, and Friederike, his wife, open the Deaconess Home and Hospital at Kaiserswerth, Germany, as an institute to train women in nursing.
Sam Houston is inaugurated as first elected President of the Republic of Texas.
The earliest United States patent for a phosphorus friction match is granted to Alonzo Dwight Phillips, of Springfield, Massachusetts.
Construction begins on the Wilmington and Raleigh Railroad in North Carolina. Due to a lack of support in Raleigh, the route is revised to run from Wilmington to the Petersburg Railroad in Weldon.
The University of London is established by Royal Charter, with University College London and King's College London named as the first affiliated colleges.
The Whig Party (United States) holds its first national convention, in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania.

1836 United States presidential election: Martin Van Buren defeats William Henry Harrison, and three other Whig candidates, marking the most recent time a Democrat is elected to succeed a two-term Democratic U.S. president.
The United States Patent Office burns in Washington, D.C.
The Crown colony of South Australia is officially proclaimed (subsequently celebrated in the state of South Australia as Proclamation Day).
Lewes avalanche: An avalanche at Lewes in Sussex, England, kills eight of fifteen people buried, when a row of cottages is engulfed in snow.
Spain recognizes the independence of Mexico.
The Colony of South Australia is founded by Captain John Hindmarsh.
Chatsworth Head is found near Tamassos, Cyprus.
In Munich, the art museum Alte Pinakothek opened.

John Murray III publishes A Hand-book for Travellers on the Continent; being a guide through Holland, Belgium, Prussia and northern Germany, and along the Rhine from Holland to Switzerland, the first of Murray's Handbooks for Travellers, in London.
In Saint Petersburg, the Lehman Theater catches fire, killing 800 people.
George Catlin ends his 6-year tour of 50 tribes in the Dakota Territory.
The New Board brokerage group is founded in New York City.
The first printed literature in Assyrian Neo-Aramaic is produced by Justin Perkins, an American Presbyterian missionary in Persia.

Eugène Schneider and his brother Adolphe Schneider purchase a bankrupt ironworks near the town of Le Creusot, in the Burgundy region of France, and found the steelworks and engineering company Schneider Frères & Cie.
The destructive Galilee earthquake causes thousands of deaths in Ottoman Syria.
Michigan becomes the 26th state admitted to the United States.
Seminoles attack Fort Foster in Florida.
In Philadelphia, the Institute for Colored Youth (ICY) is founded, as the first institution for the higher education of black people in the United States.
Charles Dickens 's Oliver Twist begins publication in serial form in London.

The Congregation of Holy Cross is formed in Le Mans, France, by the signing of the Fundamental Act of Union, which legally joins the Auxiliary Priests of Blessed Basil Moreau, CSC, and the Brothers of St. Joseph (founded by Jacques-François Dujarié) into one religious association.

The conglomerate of Procter & Gamble has its origins, when British-born businessmen William Procter and James Gamble begin selling their first manufactured goods (soap and candles) in Cincinnati, Ohio.
The great fire in Surat, a city of India, begins. Over a three-day period, the fire kills more than 500 people and destroys more than 9,000 houses.
The Panic of 1837 begins in New York City.
W. F. Cooke and Charles Wheatstone patent an electrical telegraph system.
The city of Houston is incorporated by the Republic of Texas.
The Broad Street Riot occurs in Boston, Massachusetts, fueled by ethnic tensions between the Irish and the Yankees.

Queen Victoria, 18, accedes to the throne of the United Kingdom, on the death of her uncle William IV without legitimate heirs (she will reign for more than 63 years). Under Salic law, the Kingdom of Hanover passes to William's brother, Ernest Augustus, Duke of Cumberland, ending the personal union of Britain and Hanover which has persisted since 1714.
Queen Victoria moves from Kensington Palace into Buckingham Palace, the first reigning British monarch to make this, rather than St James's Palace, as her London home.
Charles W. King sets sail on the American merchant ship Morrison. In the Morrison incident, he is turned away from Japanese ports with cannon fire.
The Dutch colonial forces sack the fortress of Bonjol, Indonesia, ending the Padri War.
First Carlist War: Battle of Aranzueque – The liberal forces loyal to Queen Isabel II of Spain are victorious, ending the Carlist campaign known as the Expedición Real.

The destructive " Racer's hurricane " sweeps across the Caribbean, northeastern Mexico, the Republic of Texas and the Gulf Coast of the United States and lasts until October 9, after killing at least 105 people.
Samuel Morse files a caveat for a patent for the telegraph.
The French army under Sylvain Charles Valée captures the city of Constantine in French Algeria after a siege of three days.
The Tsarskoye Selo Railway, the first in the Russian Empire, opens between Saint Petersburg Tsarskoselsky station and Zarskoje Selo (modern-day Pushkin), engineered by Franz Anton von Gerstner.
In what will become the world's leading consumer goods brand, Procter & Gamble is founded in Ohio in the United States.
Louis-Joseph Papineau begins the Lower Canada Rebellion in the Quebec city of Montreal.
American abolitionist and newspaper editor Elijah Lovejoy is killed by a pro- slavery mob, at his warehouse in Alton, Illinois.
Mount Holyoke Female Seminary, later Mount Holyoke College, is founded in South Hadley, Massachusetts.
An earthquake in Valdivia, south-central Chile, causes tsunamis that led to significant destruction along Japan's coast.
Samuel Lount begins the Upper Canada Rebellion by marching with rebel followers to Toronto, one month after a similar rebellion against British rule had begun in Lower Canada.
Fire breaks out in the Winter Palace, in Saint Petersburg, Russia killing 30 guards.

The Slave Compensation Act is signed into law by the government of the United Kingdom. This paid a substantial amount of money, constituting 40% of the Treasury ’s tax receipts at the time, to former enslavers but nothing to those formerly enslaved.
Atlanta is fixed as the terminal of the Western and Atlantic Railroad; it is originally named Marthasville.
The first electric locomotive built is a miniature battery locomotive constructed by chemist Robert Davidson of Aberdeen in Scotland, and powered by galvanic cells (batteries).
The Caroline Affair, on the Niagara River, becomes the basis for the Caroline test for anticipatory self-defence in international relations.
Louis Daguerre develops the daguerreotype.
The Olney Friends School is founded in the Appalachian Mountains of the United States.
The 5th century B.C. Berlin Foundry Cup is acquired for the Antikensammlung Berlin in Germany.
A fire destroys Lloyd's Coffee House and the Royal Exchange in London.
At Morristown, New Jersey, Samuel Morse, Alfred Vail and Leonard Gale give the first public demonstration of Morse's new invention, the telegraph.
The first known report about the lowest temperature on Earth is made, indicating −60 °C (−76 °F) in Yakutsk.
A 7.5 earthquake strikes the Romanian district of Vrancea causing damage in Moldavia and Wallachia, killing 73 people.

Boer explorer Piet Retief and 60 of his men are massacred by King Dingane kaSenzangakhona of the Zulu people, after Retief accepts an invitation to celebrate the signing of a treaty, and his men willingly disarm as a show of good faith.
Weenen massacre: Zulu impis massacre about 532 Voortrekkers, Khoikhoi and Basuto around the site of Weenen in South Africa.

U.S. Representatives William J. Graves of Kentucky and Jonathan Cilley of Maine face each other in a duel with rifles at 80 yards near Bladensburg, Maryland. On the third attempt, Congressman Cilley is fatally wounded and bleeds to death.

A combination of rain and melting snow causes the Danube River to overflow its banks, washing away villages in western Hungary and inundating the twin cities that become Budapest. More than 150 people are drowned and Europe's nations come to Hungary's aid to prevent the spread of famine and disease.
The first installment of Nicholas Nickleby, the new novel by Charles Dickens, is released as the opener of a 20-part serialization in London.
22 – The paddle steamer SS Sirius makes the transatlantic crossing to New York from Cork, Ireland in 18 days, though not using steam continuously.
23 – Isambard Kingdom Brunel 's paddle steamer SS Great Western (1838) makes the transatlantic crossing to New York from Avonmouth, England, in 15 days, inaugurating a regular steamship service.
Nicaragua declares independence from the Federal Republic of Central America.
Trail of Tears: The Cherokee Nation is forcibly relocated in the United States.
Braulio Carrillo is sworn in as Head of State of Costa Rica, thus beginning his second term in office.
Myall Creek massacre: 28 Indigenous Australians are killed.
The coronation of Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom takes place at Westminster Abbey in London.

In the United States, the Iowa Territory is formally established, following the signing of a bill by President Martin Van Buren on June 12. In addition to Iowa, which will become a state on December 28, 1846, the Territory also includes most of what will become the states of Minnesota, North Dakota and South Dakota. Robert Lucas, former Governor of Ohio, takes office as the first Territorial Governor.
Most former slaves in the British Empire are released from apprenticeships, giving them full emancipation under terms of the Slavery Abolition Act 1833.
The Polytechnic Institution, predecessor of the University of Westminster and Britain's first polytechnic, opens in Regent Street, London.
Grace Darling and her father rescue 13 survivors from the Forfarshire, off the Farne Islands.
The Anti-Corn Law League is established in Britain by Richard Cobden.
First Carlist War – Battle of Maella: Supporters of Infante Carlos, Count of Molina, are victorious.
Killough massacre, believed to be both the largest and last Native American attack on white settlers in East Texas. 18 casualties are either killed or carried away.

Lilburn Boggs, Governor of Missouri, by Missouri Executive Order 44, declares Mormons to be enemies of the state, and encourages the extermination or exile of the religious minority, forcing nearly 10,000 Mormons out of the state.
The Bombay Times and Journal of Commerce is founded (renamed The Times of India in 1861).
Dissolution of the Federal Republic of Central America: Honduras and Costa Rica follow the example of Nicaragua and secede from the federation.
Austria: Moravia opens the final section of Emperor Ferdinand Northern Railway (Rajhrad – Brno) for exhibition (preliminary) use.
Pastry War: Mexico is invaded by French forces.
Proteins are discovered by Gerardus Johannes Mulder. and named by Jöns Jacob Berzelius.
Friedrich Bessel makes the first accurate measurement of distance to a star.
The 5th century BC bronze Chatsworth Head is acquired by the 6th Duke of Devonshire at Smyrna, from H. P. Borrell.
The Pitcairn Islands become a Crown colony of the United Kingdom, and women there are the first in the world to be granted and maintain women's suffrage.
Duke University is established in North Carolina.
Biblical criticism: Christian Hermann Weisse proposes the two-source hypothesis.
Sylvain Charles Valée founds Skikda, Algeria.
Battle of Blood River: The Boers win a decisive victory over the Zulus.
First Anglo-Afghan War: British and Presidency armies set out from Punjab in support of Shah Shujah Durrani 's claim to the throne of Afghanistan.
The first photograph of the Moon is taken, by French photographer Louis Daguerre.
Night of the Big Wind: Ireland is struck by the most damaging cyclone in 300 years.
The French Academy of Sciences announces the daguerreotype photography process.
The British Aden Expedition captures Aden.
The first parallax measurement of the distance to Alpha Centauri is published by Thomas Henderson.
Battle of Yungay: Chile defeats the Peru–Bolivian Confederation, leading to the restoration of an independent Peru.
The University of Missouri is established, becoming the first public university west of the Mississippi River.
William Otis receives a U.S. patent for the steam shovel.
Longwood University is founded in Farmville, Virginia.
Baltimore City College, the third public high school in the United States, is established in Baltimore, Maryland.
The Pastry War between France and Mexico ends.
Prussia imposes the Child Labor Law of 1839, becoming the first nation in the world to place restrictions on child labor.
The Anti-Corn Law League is founded in Manchester, England.
An earthquake in the Kingdom of Burma kills more than 400 people and destroys three cities, as well as heavily damaging the capital at Ava.
The Boston Morning Post first records the use of "O.K." (oll korrect).
The first Henley Royal Regatta is held on the River Thames in England.
The world's first commercial electric telegraph line comes into operation, alongside the Great Western Railway line in England, from London Paddington station to West Drayton.

The Treaty of London establishes Belgium as a kingdom, with its independence and neutrality guaranteed by the great powers of Europe. Half of the Limburg province of Belgium is added to the Netherlands, giving rise to a Belgian Limburg and Dutch Limburg (the latter being joined (from September 5) to the German Confederation).
Boston University is established as the Newbury Biblical Institute in Vermont.

11 – The Bedchamber Crisis in the United Kingdom: Following the announcement by Prime Minister Lord Melbourne that he intends to resign, Robert Peel asks (for political reasons) that Queen Victoria dismiss some of her personal attendants, Ladies of the Bedchamber, as a condition for his forming a government. Victoria refuses to accept the condition and Melbourne is persuaded to stay on as Prime Minister.
First Rebecca Riots targeted against turnpikes in Wales, at Efailwen in Carmarthenshire.

Socialist activist Louis Auguste Blanqui and the Société des Saisons begin an uprising against the government of France. The insurrection is suppressed, but not before 50 people are killed and 190 wounded. Blanqui is imprisoned until 1848.

Former British statesman Lord Durham, as President of the New Zealand Company, formally asks the British government for permission to colonize New Zealand, and to establish a colonial government under the sovereignty of the United Kingdom.
Turkish troops cross the Euphrates River and invade Syria, but are defeated in battle in June.

Destruction of opium at Humen begins, casus belli for Britain to open the 3-year First Opium War against Qing dynasty China. A rapid rise in the sale of opium in China to over 40,000 chests (~56,000 kilograms (123,000 lb) per annum) has caused the Chinese government to dispatch scholar-official Lin Zexu to Guangzhou to deal with the growing problem of opium addiction.
Louis Daguerre receives a patent for his camera (commercially available by September at the price of 400 francs).
The emperor of the Sikh Empire, Maharaja Ranjit Singh, dies at 58.
Slaves aboard the Amistad rebel, and capture the ship.
Abdülmecid I (1839– 1861) succeeds Mahmud II (1808 –1839) as Ottoman Emperor.
First Anglo-Afghan War: Battle of Ghazni – British forces capture the fortress city of Ghazni in Afghanistan.
The Fraternity of Beta Theta Pi is founded by John Reily Knox at Miami University.
The French government gives the daguerreotype "for the whole world".

The First Carlist War (Spain) ends with the Convenio de Vergara, also known as the Abrazo de Vergara ("the embrace in Vergara"; Bergara in Basque), between liberal general Baldomero Espartero, Count of Luchana and Carlist General Rafael Maroto.
Battle of Kowloon: British vessels open fire on Chinese war junks enforcing a food sales embargo on the British community in China in the first armed conflict of the First Opium War.
A railway between Naples and Portici (7.4 km (4.6 mi)) in the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies is inaugurated by King Ferdinand II of Bourbon as the first line in the Italian Peninsula.
Emir Abdelkader declares a jihad against the French.

Newport Rising: Between 5,000 and 10,000 Chartist sympathisers march on Newport, Monmouthshire, to liberate Chartist prisoners; around 22 are killed when troops fire on the crowd. This is the last large-scale armed civil rebellion against authority in mainland Britain and sees the most deaths.
The Virginia Military Institute is founded in Lexington, Virginia.
Giuseppe Verdi 's first opera, Oberto, conte di San Bonifacio, opens in Milan.
A disastrous cyclone hits India with terrible winds and a giant 40-foot storm surge, wiping out the port city of Coringa; 300,000 people die.
The American Statistical Association is founded in Boston, Massachusetts.

The Whig Party (United States), at its first ever national convention, in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, nominates former U.S. Army General William Henry Harrison to be its candidate for President of the United States in the 1840 election. Although Senator Henry Clay of Kentucky has received 103 of the 128 necessary votes on the first ballot, he obtains only 90 on the final vote, while Harrison gets 148. Former U.S. Senator John Tyler is unanimously nominated for vice president.
Tanzimat starts in the Ottoman Empire.

Khalid bin Saud Al Suad usurps the throne from Faisal bin Turki bin Abdullah Al Saud, who assumed power of Nejd in 1834, and is sent to Cairo as prisoner. Omar bin Ofaysan, the Amir Faisal's governor in the Eastern Province seeks asylum in Bahrain, but Khalid the pretender demands his surrender and the surrender of the fort at Dammam; then under the control of the Al Khalifa of Bahrain.

A quarrel breaks out between the Chief of Abu Dhabi of the Beniyas tribe, Shaikh Khalifa bin Shakboot, and the fugitives who settled there after their departure from Bahrain, the Al Binali tribe. Under the command of their leader, Isa bin Tureef Al Binali, they relocate to Kenn Island where they exercise depredations over the Bahrain and other Gulf vessels. Their motive is to restore their belongings which they abandoned upon leaving Bahrain.
Khorshid Pasha vows to attack Bahrain to exert Egyptian rule over Bahrain, but his attack is prevented after Shaikh Abdulla bin Ahmed of Bahrain pays tribute.
Charles Goodyear vulcanizes rubber.
Heinola in the Grand Duchy of Finland is granted town rights by Czar Nicholas I.
In the United States, the first state law permitting women to own property is passed in Jackson, Mississippi.

The United Kingdom, backed by the Russian Empire and the Austrian Empire, compels July Monarchy France to abandon Muhammad Ali of Egypt, and forces him to return Syria and Arabia to the Ottoman Empire.
Chattanooga, Tennessee, is incorporated as a town.
Emperor Minh Mạng renames Việt Nam to Đại Nam.
Michael Faraday publishes Experimental Researches in Electricity, clarifying the true nature of electricity.
Valley Falls Company, a predecessor of Berkshire Hathaway, a conglomerate and holdings company in the United States, is founded in Rhode Island. [ citation needed ]
Galveston, Texas, is incorporated.
Episcopal High School (Alexandria, Virginia) is founded in Alexandria, Virginia, as the first high school in Virginia.
Archaeological excavation at the Mayan site of Copán begins. [ citation needed ]
One of the predecessor papers of the Herald Sun of Melbourne, Australia, The Port Phillip Herald, is founded.
Uniform Penny Post is introduced in the United Kingdom.
The steamship Lexington burns and sinks in icy waters, four miles off the coast of Long Island; 139 die, only four survive.

Captain Charles Wilkes ' United States Exploring Expedition sights what becomes known as Wilkes Land in the southeast quadrant of Antarctica, claiming it for the United States, and providing evidence that Antarctica is a complete continent.
Jules Dumont d'Urville discovers Adélie Land in Antarctica, claiming it for France.
The Rhodes blood libel is made against the Jews of Rhodes.
British colonists reach New Zealand, officially founding the settlement of Wellington.
Damascus Affair: The murder of a Capuchin friar and his Greek servant leads to a highly publicized case of blood libel, against the Jews of Damascus.
The Treaty of Waitangi, granting British sovereignty in New Zealand, is signed.
Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom marries her cousin Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha.
Gaetano Donizetti 's opera La fille du régiment premieres in Paris.
Adolphe Thiers becomes prime minister of France.
Alexander S. Wolcott and John Johnson open the world's first commercial photography portrait studio, their Daguerreian Parlor, on Broadway in Manhattan.
The Wilmington and Raleigh Railroad is completed, from Wilmington, North Carolina to Weldon, North Carolina. At 161.5 miles (259.9 km), it is the world's longest railroad.
The Raleigh and Gaston Railroad is completed from Raleigh to near Weldon, North Carolina.
Paweł Strzelecki reaches Australia 's highest summit, Mount Kosciuszko.
The Washingtonian movement for teetotalism is founded by a group of alcoholics in Baltimore, Maryland.
Johnny Appleseed meets Abraham Lincoln, and plants apple trees in New York City.
King's College Hospital opens in London.
Britain issues the Penny Black, the world's first postage stamp; it becomes valid for the pre-payment of postage from May 6.

Great Natchez Tornado: A massive tornado strikes Natchez, Mississippi during the early afternoon. Before it is over, 317 people are killed and 109 injured (the second deadliest tornado in U.S. history).
New Zealand is declared a British colony.
On the death of Frederick William III of Prussia, he is succeeded on the throne of the Kingdom of Prussia (which he has ruled for more than 40 years) by his eldest son Frederick William IV.

23 – The World Anti-Slavery Convention is organised by the British and Foreign Anti-Slavery Society, at Exeter Hall in London, England. Arguments over the exclusion of women from the convention have important ramifications for the movement for women's suffrage in the United States.

Maria massacre: British brigantine Maria is wrecked off South Australia. All 26 passengers and crew make it to the shore but none survive the trek to safety over the following two weeks, most being massacred by Aboriginal Australians.
The Cunard Line 's 700- ton wooden paddlewheel steamer RMS Britannia departs from Liverpool, bound for Halifax, Nova Scotia, on the first steam transatlantic passenger mail service.
The Austrian Empire, the United Kingdom, the Kingdom of Prussia and the Russian Empire sign the Convention of London with the Sublime Porte, ruler of the Ottoman Empire.
August Borsig 's steam locomotive, the first built in Germany, competes against a Stephenson -built locomotive on the Berlin–Jüterbog railroad; the Borsig locomotive wins by 10 minutes.
Pedro II is declared "of age" prematurely, and begins to reassert central control in Brazil.
The Province of Canada is created by the Act of Union, but not proclaimed until 10 February 1841.
Remaining former slaves in the British Empire are released from apprenticeships under terms of the Slavery Abolition Act 1833.
Fortsas hoax: A number of book collectors gather in Binche, Belgium, to attend a non-existent book auction of the late "Count of Fortsas".
The Battle of the Barrier.
Ottoman and British troops bombard Beirut, and land troops on the coast, to pressure Egyptian Muhammad Ali to retreat from the country.
Joseph Strutt hands over the deeds and papers concerning the Derby Arboretum, which is to become England's first public park.
The French frigate Belle-Poule arrives in Cherbourg, bringing back the remains of Napoleon from Saint Helena to France.
William II becomes King of the Netherlands.
A firman (imperial decree) of Sultan Abdulmejid I replaces Bashir Shihab II as Emir of Mount Lebanon with Prince Bashir Chehab III (Bashir Qasim al-Chehab).
Maronite leader Bashir Shihab II surrenders to the Ottomans, and on October 14 goes into exile, initially in Malta.
1840 United States presidential election: William Henry Harrison defeats Martin Van Buren in a landslide.
David Livingstone leaves Britain for Africa.
The body of Napoleon is laid to rest in Les Invalides in Paris.
Egyptian–Ottoman War (1839–41)
First Anglo-Afghan War (1839–1842)
First Opium War (1839–1842)
Volcanic eruption of Tinakula in the Solomon Islands causes the island to be depopulated.
Kajima, a construction company based in Japan, is founded in Edo (modern-day Tokyo).
The first English translation of Goethe's Theory of Colours by Charles Eastlake is published.
Stockport Viaduct is completed in North West England. It is one of the largest brick structures in Europe.
The first known photograph of Niagara Falls, a daguerreotype, is taken by English chemist Hugh Lee Pattinson.
Charles Elliot of the United Kingdom and Qishan of the Qing dynasty agree to the Convention of Chuenpi.
Britain occupies Hong Kong. Later in the year, the first census of the island records a population of about 7,500.
The active volcano Mount Erebus in Antarctica is discovered, and named by James Clark Ross.
Ross discovers the "Victoria Barrier", later known as the Ross Ice Shelf. On the same voyage, he discovers the Ross Sea, Victoria Land and Mount Terror.
El Salvador proclaims itself an independent republic, bringing an end to the Federal Republic of Central America.
A fire destroys two-thirds of the city of Mayagüez, Puerto Rico.
The first known reference is made to Groundhog Day, celebrated in North America, in the diary of a James Morris.
The Act of Union (British North America Act, 1840) is proclaimed in Canada.
Upper Canada and Lower Canada are merged to create the United Province of Canada.
The first ongoing filibuster in the United States Senate begins, and lasts until March 11.
United States v. The Amistad: The Supreme Court of the United States rules in the case, that the Africans who seized control of the ship had been taken into slavery illegally.
All 136 passengers and crew on steamship SS President, commanded by legendary captain Richard Roberts (known for saying "I'd go to sea in a bathtub"), are killed when the ship founders in rough seas.
The Sino-Sikh War begins.

President William Henry Harrison dies of pneumonia, aged 68, becoming the first president of the United States to die in office, and at one month, the American president with the shortest term served. He is succeeded by Vice President John Tyler.
New Zealand becomes a separate British colony, having previously been administered as part of the Colony of New South Wales.
The Georgian province of Guria revolts against the Russian Empire.
The United Kingdom Census is held, the first to record names and approximate ages of every household member, and to be administered nationally.
St. John's College, later Fordham University, is founded in The Bronx by Jesuits.

The ballet Giselle is first presented by the Ballet du Théâtre de l'Académie Royale de Musique, at the Salle Le Peletier in Paris, France, with music by Adolphe Adam and Italian ballerina Carlotta Grisi in the title role.
Thomas Cook arranges his first railway excursion in England.
The first edition of the humorous magazine Punch is published in London.
Emperor Pedro II of Brazil is crowned in Rio de Janeiro.
The sixth bishop of Calcutta, Daniel Wilson, and Dr. James Taylor, Civil Surgeon at Dhaka, establish the first modern educational institution on the Indian subcontinent, Dhaka College.
The Mercantile Agency (ancestor of Dun & Bradstreet) is founded in New York City by Lewis Tappan.
Scottish missionary David Livingstone arrives at Kuruman in the Northern Cape, his first posting in Africa.
Frederick Douglass speaks in front of the Anti-Slavery Convention in Nantucket, Massachusetts.

U.S. President John Tyler vetoes a bill which called for the re-establishment of the Second Bank of the United States. Enraged Whig Party members riot outside the White House, in the most violent demonstration on White House grounds in U.S. history.

October 16 – The Niger expedition of 1841 begins sailing up the Niger River by paddle steamers, under the auspices of the British Society for the Extinction of the Slave Trade and the Civilisation of Africa; it is largely abortive, due to the high incidence of disease among the crews.
Sarawak is broken away from Brunei, and James Brooke is appointed Rajah.
First Opium War: Battle of Chinhai – British capture a Chinese garrison.
First Opium War: British occupy Ningbo.
Queen's University is founded in Kingston, Ontario, by Rev. Thomas Liddell, who carries a Royal Charter from Queen Victoria, and becomes the school's first principal.
A fire at the Tower of London destroys its Grand Armoury and causes a quarter of a million pounds' worth of damage.
The settlement of Dallas, Texas, is founded by John Neely Bryan.
Scottish surgeon James Braid first sees a demonstration of animal magnetism by Charles Lafontaine in Manchester, which leads to his study of the phenomenon that he (Braid) eventually calls hypnotism.

The first multilateral treaty for the suppression of the African slave trade, the Treaty for the Suppression of the African Slave Trade, signed in London by the representatives of Austria, Britain, France, Prussia and Russia.
First Anglo-Afghan War: At a meeting with the Afghan general Akbar Khan, British diplomat Sir William Hay Macnaghten is shot dead at close quarters.

Franz Liszt gives a piano recital at the Sing-Akademie zu Berlin to an enthusiastic audience, retrospectively marked as the beginning of Lisztomania, which will accompany his tours across Europe during the decade.
John Augustus develops the concept of probation in Boston, Massachusetts.
First Opium War (1839–42)
First Anglo-Afghan War (1839–42)

13 – First Anglo-Afghan War – Massacre of Elphinstone's army (Battle of Gandamak): British East India Company troops are destroyed by Afghan forces on the road from Kabul to Jalalabad, Afghanistan, by Akbar Khan, son of Dost Mohammad Khan.
Delft University of Technology is established by William II of the Netherlands, as a 'Royal Academy for the education of civilian engineers'.
Antarctic explorer James Clark Ross, charting the eastern side of James Ross Island, reaches a Farthest South of 78°09'30"S.

The modern-day Willamette University, the oldest institution of higher learning in the western United States, is established in Salem, Oregon as "The Oregon Institute". The first students begin classes begin on August 13, 1844.
Commonwealth v. Hunt: The Massachusetts Supreme Court rules that labor strikes and the formation of labor unions are both legal in the United States.
Battle of Debre Tabor: Ras Ali Alula, Regent of the Emperor of Ethiopia, defeats warlord Wube Haile Maryam of Semien.
Gaylad, ridden by Tom Olliver, wins the Grand National at Aintree Racecourse in England.
Mexican troops led by Ráfael Vásquez invade Texas, briefly occupy San Antonio, and then head back to the Rio Grande. This is the first such invasion since the Texas Revolution.
Giuseppe Verdi 's third opera Nabucco premieres at La Scala in Milan; its success establishes Verdi as one of Italy's foremost operatic composers.
The Female Relief Society of Nauvoo, forerunner to the philanthropic and educational women's organization of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS Church) is formally organized.
The Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra, founded by Otto Nicolai, performs its first concert.
American physician and pharmacist Crawford Long administers an inhaled anesthetic (diethyl ether) to facilitate a surgical procedure, performing the removal of a neck tumor.
The Middleton Junction and Oldham Branch Railway line is opened up to Werneth in North West England.
1842 general strike spreads across England's industrial districts, driven by Chartism. Includes the Preston Strike and Pottery Riots. Protestors are killed by the military in several places.
First Anglo-Afghan War: Battle of Jellalabad – British troops are victorious.
8 – The Great fire of Hamburg in Germany destroys around one-third of the city centre and kills 51.
Versailles rail accident: A train traveling between Versailles and Paris, France derails, due to a broken locomotive axle, and catches fire, killing at least 55 passengers in the locked carriages.
The Income Tax Act establishes the first peacetime income tax in the United Kingdom; 7 pence in the pound, for incomes over 150 pounds.
Dorr Rebellion: Militiamen supporting Thomas Wilson Dorr attack the arsenal in Providence, Rhode Island, but are repulsed.

In South Africa, hunter Dick King rides into a British military base in Grahamstown, to warn that the Boers have besieged Durban (he had left 11 days earlier). The British army dispatches a relief force.
Queen Victoria becomes the first reigning British monarch to travel by train, on the Great Western Railway between Slough and London Paddington station.
Education in Sweden: A primary school system is established in Sweden.
James Nasmyth patents the steam hammer in the United Kingdom.
The total solar eclipse of July 8, 1842 is visible from Asia.
The Tri-Kap fraternity is founded at Dartmouth College (the oldest local fraternity in the United States).
The Armed Occupation Act is signed, providing for the armed occupation and settlement of the unsettled part of the Peninsula of East Florida.
The Webster–Ashburton Treaty is signed between the United States and United Kingdom, establishing the United States–Canada border east of the Rocky Mountains.
The Mines and Collieries Act 1842 in the United Kingdom makes it illegal for women and girls of any age, and boys under ten years, to work underground.
American Indian Wars: United States general William J. Worth declares the Second Seminole War to be over.

The Treaty of Nanking, an unequal treaty between the United Kingdom and Qing dynasty China, ends the First Opium War, and establishes Hong Kong as a British colony (later a British dependent territory until 1997).
Wesleyan University is established in Ohio.
17 – The Treaty of Chushul ends the Dogra–Tibetan war (Sino-Sikh War).
Josef Groll brews the first pilsner light lager beer in the city of Pilsen, Bohemia (the modern-day Czech Republic).
The Iberian Peninsula is struck by a category 2 hurricane.
London debtor's prisons the Fleet Prison and Marshalsea are closed and inmates transferred to Queen's Bench Prison. Pentonville Prison for criminals is completed in north London this year.
The University of Notre Dame in Notre Dame, Indiana (United States) is established by Father Edward Sorin, of the Roman Catholic Congregation of Holy Cross.
The New York Philharmonic, founded by Ureli Corelli Hill, performs its first concert.
The Citadel, The Military College of South Carolina, is established.
Pickelhaube helmet introduced in the Prussian Army.
Julius von Mayer proposes that work and heat are equivalent.
The New Zealand seat of government moves from Russell to Auckland.
English palaeontologist Richard Owen coins the name Dinosauria, hence the Anglicized dinosaur.
Dzogchen Monastery, in Sichuan, China, is almost completely destroyed by an earthquake.
The Polynesian islands of Tahiti and Tahuata are declared a protectorate of France.
The Sons of Temperance is founded in New York City.
Beecham's Pills (a laxative) is first marketed in Lancashire, England, by Thomas Beecham, forming the basis of the Beecham Group and GSK plc pharmaceutical companies.
The Illustrated Treatise on the Maritime Kingdoms (海國圖志, Hǎiguó Túzhì) compiled by Wei Yuan and others, the first significant Chinese work on the West, is published in China.
Antarctic explorer James Clark Ross discovers Snow Hill Island.
