General Joaquin Solares of Guatemala leads an invasion of neighboring Honduras, beginning a war that lasts until February 13, 1856.
Leo Tolstoy 's debut novel Childhood is published under the initials L. N., in this month's issue of the Saint Petersburg literary journal Sovremennik (and later in book form).
1852 United States presidential election: Democrat Franklin Pierce of New Hampshire defeats Whig Winfield Scott of Virginia.
Camillo Benso, Count of Cavour becomes the Piedmontese prime minister.
The new Palace of Westminster opens in London as the home of the Parliament of the United Kingdom.
22 – The New French Empire is confirmed by plebiscite: 7,824,000 for, 253,000 against.

The first roadside pillar boxes in the British Isles are brought into public use in Saint Helier, on Jersey in the Channel Islands, at the suggestion of English novelist Anthony Trollope, at this time an official of the British General Post Office.
A magnitude 7.5 to 8.8 earthquake strikes near the Banda Islands, Dutch East Indies, triggering a deadly tsunami.
The Western Railroad is chartered to build a railroad from Fayetteville, North Carolina, to the coal fields of Egypt, North Carolina.
Napoleon III becomes Emperor of the French.
The French capture Laghouat.
Taiping Rebellion: The Taiping army takes Hanyang and begins the siege of Wuchang.
Antioch College is founded in Yellow Springs, Ohio (its first president is Horace Mann).
The semaphore line in France is superseded by the telegraph.

Justin Perkins, an American Presbyterian missionary, produces the first translation of the Bible in Assyrian Neo-Aramaic, which is published with the parallel text of the Syriac Peshitta, by the American Bible Society.
The grooved rail is developed by Alphonse Loubat.
Taiping Rebellion: The Taiping army takes Hankou.
The Devil's Island penal colony opens in the colony of French Guiana.
Mills College is founded as the Young Ladies Seminary in Benicia, California.
Smith & Wesson is founded as a firearms manufacturer in the United States.
In Hawaii, sugar planters bring over the first Chinese laborers on 3- or 5-year contracts, giving them 3 dollars per month plus room and board for working a 12-hour day, 6 days a week.
Germans are encouraged to immigrate to Chile.
Loyola College is chartered in Baltimore, Maryland.

The French Catholic De La Salle Brothers arrive from Europe in Singapore, aboard La Julie, and sail up to Penang in the Straits Settlements, to found the first Lasallian educational institutions in Asia.
The British Inman Line is the first to offer United States-bound migrants steerage passage in a steamer, SS City of Glasgow.
Florida Governor Thomas Brown signs legislation that provides public support for the new East Florida Seminary, leading to the establishment of the University of Florida.
U.S. President-elect Franklin Pierce 's only living child, Benjamin "Benny" Pierce, is killed in a train accident.
Taiping Rebellion: Zeng Guofan is ordered to assist the governor of Hunan in organizing a militia force to search for local bandits.
Taiping Rebellion: The Taiping army occupies Wuchang.
Giuseppe Verdi 's opera Il Trovatore premieres in performance at Teatro Apollo in Rome.
Taiping Rebellion: Taiping forces assemble at Hanyang, Hankou, and Wuchang, for the march on Nanjing.
The city of Puerto Montt is founded in the Reloncaví Sound, Chile.
Washington University in St. Louis is founded as Eliot Seminary.
Saint Paul Fire and Marine, as predecessor of The Travelers Companies, a worldwide insurance service, founded in Minnesota, United States.
Taiping Rebellion: A rebel army of around 750,000 seizes Nanjing, killing 30,000 Imperial troops.
Manchester is granted city status in the United Kingdom.
The clothing company Levi Strauss & Co. is founded in the United States.
Prince Leopold, the youngest son and the eighth child of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert, is born.
Indian Railways: The first passenger railway in India opens from Bombay to Thana, Maharashtra, 22 miles (35 km).
Perpetual Maritime Truce comes into force between the United Kingdom and the rulers of the Sheikhdoms of the Lower Gulf, later known as the Trucial States.
October 31 – The Great Industrial Exhibition is held in Dublin, Ireland.
The first plat for Seattle, Washington, is laid out.
Guimarães is elevated to city status by Queen Maria II.
Taiping Rebellion: The Northern Expeditionary Force crosses the Yellow River.
Georges-Eugène Haussmann is selected as préfect of the Seine (department) to begin the re-planning of Paris.
The Swiss watch company Tissot is founded.
U.S. Commodore Matthew C. Perry arrives in Edo Bay, Japan, with a request for a trade treaty.
Japan allows U.S. Commodore Perry to come ashore and begin negotiations.
Outlaw and bandit Joaquin Murrieta is killed in California.
Iesada succeeds his father Ieyoshi as Japanese shōgun. The Late Tokugawa shogunate (the last part of the Edo period in Japan) begins.
New Zealand acquires self-government.
The first true International Meteorological Organization is established in Brussels, Belgium.
Potato chips are first prepared, by George Crum at Saratoga Springs, New York, according to popular accounts.
The Royal Norwegian Navy Museum is founded at Karljohansvern in Horten, perhaps the world's first naval museum.
Hudson Taylor first leaves for China.
Otis Elevator, as predecessor of Otis Worldwide, was founded in the United States.
C. Bechstein 's piano factory is founded, one of three established in a "golden year" in the history of the piano (Julius Blüthner and Steinway & Sons being the others).
On the east coast of the United States, Donald McKay launches the Great Republic, the world's biggest sailing ship, which at 4,500 tons is too large to be successful.
5 – Crimean War: The Ottoman Empire begins war with Russia.
In Munich, the art museum Neue Pinakothek opened.
Crimean War: The Ottoman army crosses the Danube into Vidin / Calafat, Wallachia.
Taiping Rebellion: The Taiping Northern Expeditionary Force comes within 3 miles (4.8 km) of Tianjin.
Troops of William Walker capture La Paz in Baja California Territory and declare the (short-lived) Republic of Sonora.
Crimean War: Battle of Oltenitza – Turkish forces defeat the Russians.
Maria II of Portugal is succeeded by her son Pedro V.
Crimean War: Battle of Sinop – The Russian fleet destroys the Turkish fleet.
Taiping Rebellion: French minister de Bourboulon arrives at the Heavenly Capital, aboard the Cassini.
Compagnie Générale des Eaux, predecessor of Vivendi and Veolia, a global media conglomerate, is founded in Paris, France.
The Independent Santa Cruz Maya of Eastern Yucatán is recognized as an independent nation by the British Empire.
The Chartered Bank of India, Australia and China is incorporated in London by Scotsman James Wilson, under a Royal Charter from Queen Victoria.
Wheaton Academy is founded in West Chicago, Illinois.
Gadsden Purchase: The United States buys approximately 77,000 square kilometres (30,000 sq mi) of land from Mexico to facilitate railroad building in the Southwest.
Charles Pravaz and Alexander Wood independently invent a practical hypodermic syringe.
More than 130,000 Chinese laborers come to Cuba.
Melbourne Cricket Ground, now the largest sports stadium in the Southern Hemisphere, officially opens.
Arthur de Gobineau begins publication of his An Essay on the Inequality of the Human Races (Essai sur l'inégalité des races humaines).
The McDonald Islands are discovered by Captain William McDonald aboard the Samarang.
The fictional detective Sherlock Holmes is perhaps born.
The Teutonia Männerchor in Pittsburgh is founded to promote German culture.

The North Carolina General Assembly in the United States charters the Atlantic and North Carolina Railroad, to run from Goldsboro through New Bern, to the newly created seaport of Morehead City, near Beaufort.
The iron clipper RMS Tayleur runs aground off the east coast of Ireland, on her maiden voyage out of Liverpool, bound for Australia, with the loss of at least 300 out of 650 on board.
Major streets are lit by coal gas for the first time by the San Francisco Gas Company; 86 such lamps are turned on this evening in San Francisco, California. [ where? ]
Mexican troops force William Walker and his troops to retreat to Sonora.
Texas is linked by telegraph with the rest of the United States, when a connection between New Orleans and Marshall, Texas is completed.
The British recognize the independence of the Orange Free State in Southern Africa; its official independence is declared six days later in the Orange River Convention.
Britain sends Russia an ultimatum to withdraw from two Romanian provinces it has conquered, Moldavia and Wallachia.
The Plan de Ayutla calls for liberal reforms and the ouster of President Antonio López de Santa Anna of Mexico.
German psychologist Friedrich Eduard Beneke disappears; 2 years later his remains are found in the canal near Charlottenburg.
The British Inman Line 's SS City of Glasgow sets out from Liverpool on passage to the United States with 480 on board; she is lost without a trace.
Australia's first telegraph line, linking Melbourne and Williamstown, Victoria, opens.
A Royal Navy fleet sails from Britain, under Vice Admiral Sir Charles Napier.
The Republican Party is formed by anti-slavery opponents of the Kansas–Nebraska Act in Ripon, Wisconsin.
The Boston Public Library opens to the public.
Slavery is abolished in Venezuela.
Crimean War: The United Kingdom declares war on Russia.
Crimean War: France declares war on Russia.
United States Navy Commodore Matthew C. Perry signs the Convention of Kanagawa with the Japanese government (the Tokugawa shogunate), opening the ports of Shimoda and Hakodate to American trade.
The British East India Company annexes Jhansi State in India under the doctrine of lapse.
Hard Times begins serialisation in Charles Dickens ' magazine, Household Words.
The United States packet ship Powhattan is wrecked off the New Jersey shore, with more than 200 victims.
15 – Hokkien–Teochew Riots in Singapore.
The Catholic University of Ireland (forerunner of University College Dublin) is founded.
Taiping Rebellion: United States diplomatic minister Robert McLane arrives at the Heavenly Capital aboard the USS Susquehanna.

The Kansas–Nebraska Act becomes law (replacing the Missouri Compromise of 1820), creating the Kansas Territory and the Nebraska Territory, west of the State of Missouri and the State of Iowa. The Kansas–Nebraska Act also establishes that these two new Territories will decide either to allow or disallow slavery, depending on balloting by their residents (these areas would have been strictly "free territory" under the Missouri Compromise, which allowed slavery in the State of Missouri but disallowed it in any other new state north of latitude 36° 30', which forms most of the southern boundary of Missouri. This prohibition of slavery extended all the way from the western boundary of Missouri to the Pacific Ocean).
The first class of the United States Naval Academy graduates at Annapolis, Maryland.

Battle of Bomarsund in Åland off the coast of Finland: British Royal Navy seaman's mate Charles Davis Lucas throws a live Russian artillery shell overboard by hand before it explodes, for which he is awarded the first Victoria Cross in 1857.
The Grand Excursion takes prominent Eastern United States inhabitants from Chicago to Rock Island, Illinois, by railroad, then up the Mississippi River to Saint Paul, Minnesota, by steamboat.
James Ambrose Cutting takes out the first of his three United States patents for improvements to the wet plate collodion process (Ambrotype photography).
In Jackson, Michigan, the first convention of the U.S. Republican Party is held.
The Bombay Spinning and Weaving Company is established as the first cotton mill in India by Cowasjee Nanabhoy Davar and associates.
Mohamed Sa'id Pasha succeeds his nephew Abbas as the Wāli of Egypt and Sudan, then a province of the Ottoman Empire.
The Bienio progresista revolutionary coup occurs in Spain.
Wood's despatch is sent by Charles Wood, 1st Viscount Halifax to Lord Dalhousie, Governor General of India, proposing radical improvements to the Indian educational system.
Johann succeeds to the throne of Saxony, on the death of his brother.
Battle of Bomarsund: Russian troops on the island of Bomarsund, in Åland, surrender to French–British troops.
John Lawrence Grattan leads 29 United States troops and a civilian interpreter in attack on Lakota village over dispute involving emigrant cow. Grattan's command was annihilated.
English lawyer Alfred Wills and party set out for the first ascent of the Wetterhorn in Switzerland, regarded as the start of the " golden age of alpinism ".

September 8 – An epidemic of cholera in London kills over 10,000. Dr John Snow traces the source of one outbreak (that killed 500) to a single water pump, validating his theory that cholera is water-borne, and forming the starting point for epidemiology. Original map by Dr John Snow showing the clusters of cholera cases in the London epidemic of 1854
British Inman Line 's SS City of Philadelphia (1854) is wrecked off Cape Race (Newfoundland) on her maiden voyage without loss of life.
Crimean War: Battle of Alma – The French–British alliance wins the first major land engagement of the war. Battle of Alma

SS Arctic disaster: The American paddle steamer SS Arctic sinks after a collision with the much smaller French ship SS Vesta, 50 miles (80 km) off the coast of Newfoundland, with approximately 320 deaths.

The watch company founded in 1850 in Roxbury, Massachusetts, by Aaron Lufkin Dennison, relocates to Waltham, to become the Waltham Watch Company, pioneer in the American system of watch manufacturing.
The great fire of Newcastle and Gateshead in England is ignited by a spectacular explosion.
11 – United States diplomats in Europe meet and draft the Ostend Manifesto, setting out a rationale for the U.S. to acquire Cuba from Spain.
The Age newspaper is founded in Melbourne, Australia.

Crimean War: Battle of Balaclava – The allies gain an overall victory, except for the disastrous cavalry Charge of the Light Brigade, from which only 200 of 700 men survive. October 25: Battle of Balaclava
Crimean War: Battle of Inkerman – The Russians are defeated.
Great Storm of 1854 in the Black Sea: 19 British transport and other ships (plus 2 French) supporting the Crimean War are wrecked with the loss of at least 287 men.
In Egypt, the Suez Canal Company is formed.
The Eureka Stockade Miners' Rebellion breaks out in Ballarat, Victoria (Australia).
Pope Pius IX in the apostolic constitution Ineffabilis Deus defines ex Cathedra the dogma of Immaculate Conception, which holds that the Blessed Virgin Mary was conceived without original sin.
The French fashion label Louis Vuitton is founded.
Bryant & Stratton College is founded as a business institute in the United States.
Sa'id Pasha officially abolishes slavery in Egypt.
Ignacy Łukasiewicz drills the world's first oil well in Poland, in Bóbrka near Krosno County.
Professor Benjamin Silliman of Yale University is the first person to fractionate petroleum into its individual components, by distillation.
A Russian fort is established at the modern-day site of Almaty.

The future Waterbury Clock Company (Incorporated on March 27, 1857) is founded as a department within the Benedict and Burnham Manufacturing Company in Waterbury, Connecticut, the predecessor of Timex Group USA in timepiece manufacturing.
The Icelandic trade is opened to merchants other than Danes.
Ottawa, Ontario, is incorporated as a city. '
Ramón Castilla begins his third term as President of Peru.
The first bridge over the Mississippi River opens in modern-day Minneapolis, a predecessor of the Father Louis Hennepin Bridge.
The 8.2–8.3 M w Wairarapa earthquake claims between five and nine lives near the Cook Strait area of New Zealand.
The Point No Point Treaty is signed in the Washington Territory.
The Panama Railway becomes the first railroad to connect the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.
Lord Aberdeen resigns as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, over the management of the Crimean War.
Lord Palmerston becomes Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
Kassa Hailu is crowned Tewodros II, Emperor of Ethiopia.
Michigan State University (the "pioneer" land-grant college) is established.
The North Carolina General Assembly incorporates the Western North Carolina Railroad, to build a rail line from Salisbury to the western part of the state.
Pennsylvania State University is founded, as the Farmers' High School of Pennsylvania.
Alexander II ascends the Russian throne, upon the death of his father Nicholas I.
The United States Congress appropriates $30,000 to create the U.S. Camel Corps.
Bates College is founded by abolitionists in Lewiston, Maine.
Taiping Rebellion: A Taiping army of 350,000 invades Anhui.
Elections are held for the first Kansas Territory legislature. Missourian ' Border Ruffians ' cross the border in large numbers to elect a pro- slavery body.
The Nepalese invasion of Tibet (west of China) to the north across the Himalaya Mountains (tallest and most rugged in the world) starts the Nepalese–Tibetan War (1855–1856).

Battle of Kaba: The Kingdom of Tonga in the islands of the southwest Pacific Ocean (Polynesia, Melanesia / Oceania), intervenes in the war between the self-proclaimed Tui Viti (King) of the island of Fiji, Cakobau, and his rivals the Confederation of Rewa. It results in Rewa's defeat and the tenuous unification of Fiji under Cakobau.
Emperor of the French Napoleon III, with Empress Eugénie, begins a 6-day state visit to Britain.
The Bordeaux Wine Official Classification of 1855, requested by Napoleon III for the Exposition Universelle (opening May 15), first appears.
Van Diemen's Land is separated administratively from the province New South Wales and granted self-government in the Australia continent.
American adventurer William Walker and a group of armed mercenaries (filibusters) sail from San Francisco in California south to Central America to attempt to conquer Nicaragua.
The Exposition Universelle (an early World's fair) officially opens in Paris (continues to November 15).
The Great Gold Robbery is made from a moving train between London Bridge and Folkestone in England, one of the first crimes of its kind.
Mount Sinai Hospital, New York, is dedicated (originally named as the Jews' Hospital) in New York City; it opens to patients on June 5.

In Australia, the province of Victoria (named for then reigning British monarch, Queen Victoria) to the southeast is separated administratively from the earlier larger province of New South Wales to the north.
Stamp duty revenue tax is removed from British newspapers, creating free mass media thereafter in the United Kingdom.
The Daily Telegraph newspaper begins publication in London.
Bank of Toronto incorporated in Canada (in 1955 it will merge with The Dominion Bank to become Toronto-Dominion Bank).
The Quinault Treaty, in which the Quinault and Quileute tribes cede their land to the United States, is signed.
The Kansas territorial legislature convenes in Pawnee, and begins passing proslavery laws.
Walt Whitman 's poetry collection Leaves of Grass is published in Brooklyn.
Thomas Cook escorts his first party of excursionists from England to tour the European continent, travelling via Belgium and enabling the tourists to visit the Paris Exposition.
The Australian Colonies are granted self-governing status by the United Kingdom.
Monte Rosa, the second-highest summit in the Alps, is first ascended.

Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom, with Prince Albert, begins a 10-day state visit to Paris, the first visit of a reigning British monarch to France since 1413. While there, she visits the Exposition Universelle.
The last Bartholomew Fair is held in London, England.
Crimean War: Siege of Sevastopol (1854–1855) – Sevastopol falls to French and British troops.
Alfred Tennyson reads from his new book Maud and other poems, at a social gathering in the home of Robert and Elizabeth Browning in London; Dante Gabriel Rossetti makes a sketch of him doing so.

The Port of Iloilo in the Philippines is opened to international trade, by Queen Isabel II of Spain. This year also the ports of Sual (modern-day Pangasinan) and Zamboanga City are opened to international trade.
Henry Bessemer files his patent in the United Kingdom for the Bessemer process of steelmaking.
Van Diemen's Land is officially renamed Tasmania.
Henry Wadsworth Longfellow 's fictional poem The Song of Hiawatha is published in Boston.

The Hejaz rebellion takes place in Hejaz against the Ottoman Empire, triggered by a firman of 1854 against the slave trade, which is condemned by the ulema of Mecca as influenced by Westerners and contrary to Islamic law.
Scottish missionary explorer David Livingstone becomes the first European to see Victoria Falls, in modern-day Zambia – Zimbabwe.
Large-scale Bleeding Kansas violence begins, with events leading to the ' Wakarusa War ' between antislavery and proslavery forces.
Ignacio Comonfort (1812–1863) becomes President of Mexico.
Palm oil sales from West Africa to the United Kingdom reach 40,000 tons.
Samuel Colt incorporates his business as the Colt's Patent Firearms Manufacturing Company and opens a new factory, the Colt Armory, in Hartford, Connecticut.
The Metropolitan Board of Works is established in London.
The cocaine alkaloid is first isolated by German chemist Friedrich Gaedcke.
Borax deposits are discovered in large quantities by John Veatch in California.
The American sidewheel steamer SS Pacific leaves Liverpool (England) for a transatlantic voyage on which she will be lost with all 186 on board.
U.S. President Franklin Pierce declares the new Free-State Topeka government in " Bleeding Kansas " to be in rebellion.
First Battle of Seattle: Marines from the USS Decatur suppress an indigenous uprising, in response to Governor Stevens' declaration of a "war of extermination" on Native communities.
Queen Victoria institutes the Victoria Cross as a British military decoration.
The 223-mile North Carolina Railroad is completed from Goldsboro through Raleigh and Salisbury to Charlotte.
Auburn University is first chartered, as the East Alabama Male College.
Dallas, Texas, is incorporated as a city.
The Nawab of Oudh, Wajid Ali Shah, is exiled to Metiabruz and the state is annexed by the British East India Company.
American clipper ships Driver and Ocean Queen leave Liverpool and London respectively; both will be lost without trace in the Atlantic, perhaps due to ice, killing 374 and 123 respectively.
The American Know Nothing Party convenes in Philadelphia to nominate their first Presidential candidate, former President Millard Fillmore.
Nepalese–Tibetan War: The signing of the Treaty of Thapathali concludes the war.
Fire destroys the Covent Garden Theatre in London.
Maryland Agricultural College (modern-day University of Maryland, College Park) is chartered.
Filibuster War: Battle of Santa Rosa: – Costa Rican troops rout Walker 's soldiers.

Taiping Rebellion: Suspecting treachery on the part of East King Yang Xiuqing, Shi Dakai garrisons Anhui and begins his march back to the Heavenly Capital, having defeated a strong Xiang Army detachment.
The Treaty of Paris is signed, ending the Crimean War.
The Xhosa cattle-killing movement and famine begins in Cape Colony.
Nelson College is founded in Nelson, New Zealand.
Theta Chi international college fraternity is founded at Norwich University in Vermont.
The Paris Declaration Respecting Maritime Law abolishes privateering, and regulates the relationship between neutral and belligerent and shipping on the high seas.
The Chicago Historical Society Museum is established at 1601 N. Clark Street, Chicago.
Building workers agitate for the eight-hour day in Melbourne, Australia.
The iron-hulled paddle steamer RMS Persia concludes a 9-day 16 hour westbound transatlantic crossing, at an average 13.11 knots (24.28 km/h), regaining the Blue Riband for the Cunard Line.
The province of Isabela is created in the Philippines, in honor of Queen Isabella II of Spain.

Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom gives Norfolk Island to the population of the colony at Pitcairn Island, most being descendants of the Mutiny on the Bounty. They first settle on Norfolk Island on June 8. Women's suffrage, as practiced on Pitcairn, is extended to Norfolk Island.
The San Francisco Committee of Vigilance is founded in the United States. It lynches two gangsters, arrests most Democratic Party officials, and disbands itself on August 18.
David Livingstone arrives at Quelimane on the Indian Ocean, having completed a 2-year transcontinental journey across Africa from Luanda.
Sacking of Lawrence: Lawrence, Kansas, is captured and burned by pro- slavery forces.

Caning of Charles Sumner: United States Congressman Preston Brooks of South Carolina beats Senator Charles Sumner with a cane in the hall of the United States Senate for a speech Sumner had made attacking pro- slavery Southerners, especially elderly South Carolina Senator Andrew Butler, a relative of Brooks. Sumner is unable to return to duty for three years while he recovers; Brooks becomes a hero across the South.
Pottawatomie massacre: A group of followers of radical abolitionist John Brown kill 5 homesteaders in Franklin County, Kansas.
Battle of Black Jack: Antislavery forces, led by John Brown, defeat proslavery forces in Bleeding Kansas.
500 Mormon handcart pioneers leave Iowa City and head west for Salt Lake City, Utah, carrying all their possessions in two-wheeled handcarts.
Taiping Rebellion: Shi Dakai arrives at Nanjing.
General Mills is founded in Minneapolis, Minnesota, United States, as the Minneapolis Milling Company.
Natal becomes a British Crown colony.
15 – In Spain, General Leopoldo O'Donnell takes control of the government, bringing an end to the bienio progresista.
The Great Train Wreck (the worst railroad calamity in the world to date) occurs near Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, United States.
Pre-human remains are found in the Neanderthal Valley in Prussia.
Christchurch, New Zealand, is chartered as a city.
The Last Island hurricane destroys Last Island, Louisiana, leaving 400 dead. The whole island is broken up into several smaller islands by the storm.
Battle of Osawatomie: Proslavery forces defeat antislavery forces in Bleeding Kansas.

Seton Hall University is founded in South Orange, New Jersey, by Roman Catholic Bishop of Newark James Roosevelt Bayley, a cousin of future U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt and nephew of Saint Elizabeth Ann Seton.
Taiping Rebellion: Wei Changhui and Qin Rigang assassinate Yang Xiuqing.
The Saimaa Canal was inaugurated.
The Second Opium War between several Western powers and China begins with the Arrow Incident on the Pearl River.
1856 Heraklion earthquake: A powerful earthquake rocks the Mediterranean, killing hundreds on the island of Crete and many more in the Middle East.
American mercenary William Walker effectively takes control of Nicaragua.
Anglo-Persian War: War is declared between Great Britain and Persia.

1856 United States presidential election: Democrat James Buchanan defeats former President Millard Fillmore, representing a coalition of Know Nothings and Whigs, and John C. Frémont of the fledgling Republican Party, to become the 15th President of the United States.
Taiping Rebellion: Shi Dakai arrives at the Heavenly Capital once more with 100,000 men, and demands that Wei Changhui and Qin Rigang be executed. Shi subsequently becomes head of the government.
American Old West: On the Sonoita River in modern-day southern Arizona, the United States Army establishes Fort Buchanan, in order to help control new land acquired in the Gadsden Purchase.
Niagara University is founded in Niagara Falls, New York.
The Coup of 1856 leads to Luxembourg 's unilateral adoption of a new, reactionary constitution, as King-Grand Duke William III signs the new constitution without the Chamber of Deputies ' consent.

Under the County and Borough Police Act, in any county or area of England and Wales where a police force has not already been established, the Justices of the Peace must from this date take steps to create one according to nationally defined standards.
The National Portrait Gallery, London, is established.
Bushehr surrenders to the British.
Charles III of Monaco grants a concession to Napoléon Langlois and Albert Aubert to establish a German-style casino at Monte Carlo.
Gregor Mendel starts his research on genetics.
Global financial services business Credit Suisse is founded as La Schweizerische Kreditanstalt.
Legal protection of widow remarriage is extended in India.
St. Paul's School, Belgaum, is founded by the Jesuits in Belgaum, India.
Kate Warne, the first female private detective, begins to work for the Pinkerton Detective Agency.
The British Guiana 1c magenta postage stamp is issued in British Guiana in limited numbers; the one surviving specimen will become regarded as the world's rarest stamp.
The biggest Estonian newspaper, Postimees, is established by Johann Voldemar Jannsen.
The partly French-owned London General Omnibus Company begins operating.
The 7.9 M w Fort Tejon earthquake shakes Central and Southern California, with a maximum Mercalli intensity of IX (Violent).

The University of Calcutta is established in Calcutta, as the first multidisciplinary modern university in South Asia. The University of Bombay is also established in Bombay, British India, this year.
The National Deaf Mute College (later renamed Gallaudet University) is established in Washington, D.C., becoming the first school for the advanced education of the deaf.
The Austrian garrison leaves Bucharest.
The Federal Constitution of the United Mexican States is promulgated.

The largest slave auction in U.S. history is held, dubbed The Weeping Time. Over a 2-day period (starting March 2), Pierce M. Butler sells 436 men, women, children, and infants, all of whom are kept in stalls meant for horses at a racetrack in Savannah, Georgia, for weeks beforehand.
France and the United Kingdom formally declare war on China, in the Second Anglo-Chinese War.

Dred Scott v. Sandford: The Supreme Court of the United States rules that blacks are not citizens and slaves can not sue for freedom, driving the U.S. further towards the American Civil War (the ruling is not overturned until the 14th Amendment is adopted in 1868).
12 – Spirit Lake Massacre, near Okoboji and Spirit lakes in the northwestern territory of Iowa near the Minnesota border.
Elizabeth Blackwell opens a hospital, the New York Infirmary for Indigent Women and Children.
Youssef Bey Karam is assigned, by the people of Ehden and Bsharri, to be the region's ruler.
Elisha Otis ' first elevator is installed (at 488 Broadway, New York City).
The phonautograph is patented by French typesetter Édouard-Léon Scott de Martinville. It is the earliest known device for recording sound.
The Anglo-Persian War ends.
Mangal Pandey is hanged for mutiny against the British East India Company army; the execution is a precursor event to the Indian Rebellion of 1857.
Princess Beatrice, the fifth daughter and the youngest child of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert, is born.
The Spirits' Book (Le Livre des Esprits), one of the Five Fundamental Works of Spiritism, is published by French educator Allan Kardec.
First horse race run at Longchamp Racecourse in Paris.
October 17 – The Art Treasures of Great Britain exhibition is held in Manchester, one of the largest such displays of all time.
Indian Rebellion of 1857: The 3rd Light Cavalry of the British East India Company 's army rebels against its British officers, thus beginning the rebellion.
Indian Rebellion of 1857: Indian combatants capture Delhi from the British East India Company.
Spanish financial group, Banco Santander founded in Cantabria, Spain.
Banco de Bilbao, as predecessor of BBVA is founded in Spain.
Second Anglo-Chinese War: Battle of Fatshan Creek – The British Royal Navy defeats the Cantonese fleet of Qing dynasty China.
Sophia of Nassau marries the future King Oscar II of Sweden–Norway.
U.S. mercenary William Walker is overthrown as ruler of Nicaragua by Honduran general Florencio Xatruch.
The Victoria and Albert Museum in London is officially opened by Queen Victoria.
At a ceremony in London, Queen Victoria awards the first 66 Victoria Crosses to British troops, for actions during the Crimean War.
November 19 – Indian Rebellion of 1857: Siege of Lucknow.
Indian Rebellion of 1857: The second massacre at Kanpur takes place.
The Utah Expedition leaves Fort Leavenworth, effectively beginning the Utah War.
Prison hulks are used for the last time in the United Kingdom.
The Dunbar wrecks near the entrance to Sydney Harbour, Australia, with the loss of 121 lives.

The Panic of 1857 begins: Speculation in U.S. railroad shares, and the collapse on August 24 of the New York City branch of the Ohio Life Insurance and Trust Company, following widespread embezzlement, trigger a financial crisis which will extend to Europe.
The Matrimonial Causes Act makes divorce without parliamentary approval legal in the United Kingdom.
The Mountain Meadows massacre occurs in Utah.
The SS Central America sinks off the coast of North Carolina with the loss of 425 lives.
Indian Rebellion of 1857: British forces recapture Delhi, compelling the surrender of Bahadur Shah II, the last Mughal emperor.
Russian ship of the line Lefort sinks in the Gulf of Finland during a sudden squall with the loss of 826 lives; 30 other ships are wrecked in the same storm.
Panic of 1857: New York banks close, and do not reopen until December 12.
Sheffield F.C., the world's first association football team, is founded in Sheffield, United Kingdom.
28 enslaved people escape their enslavers in Maryland.
The Indus Valley Region (i.e., Pakistan Region) is incorporated as part of British India, for the next 90 years until 1947.
Indian Rebellion of 1857: British troops win 24 Victoria Crosses in action this day.
President of Mexico Ignacio Comonfort is succeeded by Félix María Zuloaga.
The Reform War in Mexico begins.
U.S. Consul in Japan Townsend Harris meets the Shogun in Edo in a diplomatic reception, the first ever meeting between the Shogun and a foreign diplomat.
The 7.0 M w Basilicata earthquake shakes the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies (Southern Italy) with a maximum Mercalli intensity of XI (Extreme), killing about 10,000 people.
Emperor Franz Joseph I of Austria issues a decree, Es ist Mein Wille, which leads to the demolition of the city walls of Vienna, allowing the construction of the Ringstraße.
Second Anglo-Chinese War: 2nd Battle of Canton – British and French forces begin an assault on the Qing dynasty Chinese city of Canton (Guangzhou).
San Jose State, the first public U.S. university west of the Mississippi River, opens in San Francisco as Minn's Evening School.
Bucharest becomes the world's first city to have its streets illuminated by kerosene lamps.
Queen Victoria chooses Ottawa as the capital of Canada.
U.S. politician William Daniel proposes the Local Option for Prohibition.
Suzumoto Vaudeville Theater officially opens in Ueno region, Edo (modern-day Tokyo) in Japan.
U.S. composer James Lord Pierpont composes " Jingle Bells ", originally entitled "The One Horse Open Sleigh".
La Tène culture artifacts are discovered in Switzerland, by Hansli Kopp.
Illinois State University, the first public university in Illinois, is established in Normal, Illinois.
Kuala Lumpur, the future capital of Malaysia, is founded as a tin mining settlement.
The first commercial tea plantation in the British Raj is opened in the Mulnicherra Estate in Sylhet.
The Mormons abandon Las Vegas.
Liberia annexes the Republic of Maryland as native groups (notably Grebo people and Kru people) continually attack and kill settlers in Cape Palmas.
Anson Jones, the last president of the Republic of Texas, commits suicide.
Revolt of Rajab Ali: British forces finally defeat Rajab Ali Khan of Chittagong.

Orsini affair: Piedmontese revolutionary Felice Orsini and his accomplices fail to assassinate Napoleon III in Paris, but their bombs kill eight and wound 142 people. Because of the involvement of French émigrés living in Britain, there is a brief anti-British feeling in France, but the emperor refuses to support it.

The Wedding March by Felix Mendelssohn becomes a popular wedding recessional, after it is played on this day at the marriage of Queen Victoria 's daughter Victoria, Princess Royal, to Prince Friedrich of Prussia in St James's Palace, London.
February
Queen Victoria announces her choice of Ottawa as capital of the Province of Canada.

Lourdes apparitions: Pauper girl Bernadette Soubirous of Lourdes, fourteen, has a vision at the grotto of Massabielle, the first in a series of eighteen events which will come to be regarded as Marian apparitions.
Richard Francis Burton and John Hanning Speke become the first Europeans to discover Lake Tanganyika.
Felice Orsini is executed by guillotine for the attempted assassination of Napoleon III of France.
Indian Rebellion: British troops retake Lucknow.
Hymen Lipman patents a pencil with an attached eraser in the United States.
The Wernerian Natural History Society, a former Scottish learned society, is wound up.
The United States signs a treaty with the Yankton Sioux Tribe.
May 1 – Battle of Grahovac: The Ottomans are decisively defeated by Montenegrin forces.
Minnesota is admitted as the 32nd U.S. state.
John Ruskin begins a tour of Europe; he considers it a significant turning point in his life.
David Livingstone 's 6-year Second Zambesi expedition arrives at the African coast.
" Bleeding Kansas: The Marais des Cygnes massacre is perpetrated by pro-slavery forces in the U.S. state of Kansas.
Mahtra War: Peasants in the Governorate of Estonia, Russian Empire revolt against ongoing serfdom, which was officially abolished in 1816.
Japanese trading company, Itochu founded in Toyosato, Shiga Prefecture, Japan. [ page needed ]
Comet Donati, the first comet to be photographed, is discovered by Giovanni Battista Donati, and remains visible for several months afterwards.
17 – The Treaty of Tientsin is signed, ending the first part of the Second Opium War.
Abraham Lincoln accepts the Republican Party nomination for a seat in the United States Senate, delivering his House Divided speech in Springfield, Illinois.
The Atlantic and North Carolina Railroad opens, operating 95 miles from Goldsboro, North Carolina, to New Bern, North Carolina.
The Queen of Jhansi, Rani Lakshmibai, dies at 30 at Gwalior, having been mortally wounded in combat against the British.
A six-minute earthquake destroys much of Mexico City and devastates Texcoco.
Indian Rebellion of 1857: The last rebels surrender in Gwalior.
Police of the Papal States seize Jewish boy Edgardo Mortara, and take him away to be raised as a Catholic.
A joint presentation of papers by Darwin and Alfred Russel Wallace, announcing a theory of evolution by natural selection, are read at London's Linnean Society.
A peace treaty ends the Indian Rebellion.
The Advertiser, a daily newspaper still in circulation, begins publication in Adelaide, Australia.
The Lutine bell is salvaged, and subsequently hung in Lloyd's of London.
In Bengal, India, British officer William James Herschel uses the hand impression of Rajyadhar Konai, as a contract fingerprint signature.
The United States and Japan sign the Treaty of Amity and Commerce, negotiated by Townsend Harris.

The Government of India Act, passed by the Parliament of the United Kingdom, transfers the territories of the British East India Company and their administration to the direct rule of the British Crown, through a Secretary of State for India.
A bill is passed to create a modern sewage system in London as a result of the Great Stink, when the heat of the summer made the smell from sewage in the Thames unbearable.
Cyrus West Field and others complete the first transatlantic telegraph cable, after several unsuccessful attempts. The service ends on September 1, due to weak current.
A football match, played under an unknown set of rules, is held between Melbourne Grammar School and Scotch College.
The Eiger is first ascended.
U.S. President James Buchanan inaugurates the new trans-Atlantic telegraph cable, by exchanging greetings with Queen Victoria. However, a weak signal forces a shutdown of the service in a few weeks.
The first aerial photography is carried out by Nadar, from a moored balloon in France.
The first of the Lincoln–Douglas debates is held in Illinois.
Cochinchina Campaign: French warships, under Charles Rigault de Genouilly, attack and occupy Da Nang, Vietnam.
Dom, the third-highest summit in the Alps, is first ascended.
Jacques Offenbach 's operetta Orpheus in the Underworld, featuring music associated with the can-can, is first performed in Paris.
Macy's department store, founded by R. H. Macy, opens for business in New York City.

Johann II, Prince of Liechtenstein, succeeds to the throne aged 18; he will rule until his death in 1929, the second-longest in European royal history and the longest precisely documented tenure of any monarch without a regent since antiquity.
The 2,400,000th day of the Epoch of the Julian day is reached.
The city of Denver, Colorado, is founded.
Modified Julian Day zero starts on this date.
— Mexican Conservative interim president Félix María Zuloaga proclaims the Plan of Tacubaya to abolish the Reform Laws, setting off a three-year civil war (1857–1860).
— Manuel Robles Pezuela (1817–1862) becomes Conservative president of Mexico.
The Northern Railway Company is established in Madrid, Spain, with a purpose to construct the Northern Railway.
Paraguay expedition: Seventeen U.S. Navy warships, under the command of William Shubrick, depart from Uruguay on a mission to demand concessions from Paraguay, and to go to war if necessary.
Feudalism and serfdom in Bulgaria are abolished in the Ottoman Empire (practically in 1880).
The haute couture firm of Worth and Bobergh is established in Paris.
William M. Tweed begins his 13-year term as " Boss " of Tammany Hall.
The Miners Association is established in Cornwall, England, UK.
The Russian Empire changes its flag.
Squibb Pharmacy, as predecessor of Bristol-Myers Squibb, a worldwide pharmaceutical brand, is founded in New York, United States. [ page needed ]
José Mariano Salas (1797–1867) becomes Conservative interim President of Mexico.

Under the rule of Alexandru Ioan Cuza, the provinces of Wallachia and Moldavia are united under the jurisdiction of the Ottoman Empire. It would be a principal step in forming the modern state of Romania.
The city of Olympia is incorporated in the Washington Territory of the United States of America.
Miguel Miramón (1832–1867) becomes Conservative interim President of Mexico.

German scholar Constantin von Tischendorf rediscovers the Codex Sinaiticus, a 4th-century uncial manuscript of the Greek Bible, in Saint Catherine's Monastery on the foot of Mount Sinai, in the Khedivate of Egypt and arranges for its presentation to his patron, Tsar Alexander II of Russia at Saint Petersburg.
The Mekteb-i Mülkiye School is founded in the Ottoman Empire.
Oregon is admitted as the 33rd U.S. state.
French naval forces under Charles Rigault de Genouilly capture the city and Citadel of Saigon in Vietnam, beginning the Siege of Saigon.
United States Congressman Daniel Sickles shoots Philip Barton Key (U.S. District Attorney) for having an affair with his wife.
Construction begins on the first railway in northern India as tracks are laid between the modern-day locations of Allahabad and Kanpur.
The army of the Kingdom of Sardinia mobilizes against Austria, beginning the crisis which will lead to the Austro-Sardinian War.
Pennsylvania issues the charter establishing the Zoological Society of Philadelphia, the first organization of its kind in the United States, and founder of the nation's first zoo.
French amateur astronomer Edmond Modeste Lescarbault claims to have noticed a planet closer to the Sun than Mercury (later named Vulcan).
The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art is founded by Peter Cooper, a New York industrialist, inventor and philanthropist.
Indian Rebellion revolutionary, Tantia Tope is hanged for the 1857 Rebellion
Ground is broken for the Suez Canal, in Egypt.
American ship Pomona is wrecked off the Irish coast, with 424 dead.
Austrian troops begin to cross the Ticino River to Piedmont.
A Tale of Two Cities by Charles Dickens is published in England.
The Cornwall Railway opens across the Royal Albert Bridge, linking the counties of Devon and Cornwall in England.
Border Treaty between Brazil and Venezuela: The two countries agree their borders should be traced at the water divide, between the Amazon and the Orinoco basins.

- The 1859 United Kingdom general election concludes. It is the first election fought by the new Liberal Party, in which they win a 28 seat majority, with Liberal leader Viscount Palmerston becoming Prime Minister
Austro-Sardinian War: Battle of Montebello – The Austrian army led by Karl von Urban faces the French-Sardinian combined forces.
Ferdinand II of the Two Sicilies is succeeded by his 23-year-old son, Francis II of the Two Sicilies.

Geologist Joseph Prestwich and amateur archaeologist John Evans report (to the Royal Society and Society of Antiquaries of London, respectively) the results of their investigations of gravel-pits in the Somme valley and elsewhere, extending human history back to what will become known as the Paleolithic Era.
Austro-Sardinian War: Battle of Varese – Giuseppe Garibaldi 's Hunters of the Alps confront and defeat Austrian forces, led by Field Marshal-Lieutenant Karl von Urban.
Austro-Sardinian War: Battle of Palestro – The Sardinians defeat the Austrian army.
Big Ben, the Great Clock at the Palace of Westminster, London, is started.
Austro-Sardinian War: Battle of Magenta – The French and Sardinians defeat the Austrians.
The British Crown colony of Queensland in Australia is created, by devolving part of the territory of New South Wales (Queensland Day). Brisbane is declared the capital.
The discovery of the Comstock Lode in the western Utah Territory sets off the Rush to Washoe.
The Austrian Field Marshall Karl von Urban defeats Giuseppe Garibaldi.
The so-called Pig War border dispute between the Americans and the British, over the San Juan Islands, begins by the death of the namesake pig.
The only recorded simoom ever in North America hits Goleta and Santa Barbara, California.
Aletschhorn, the second summit of the Bernese Alps, is first ascended.

Austro-Sardinian War – Battle of Solferino: The Kingdom of Sardinia and the armies of Napoleon III of France defeat Franz Joseph I of Austria in northern Italy; the battle inspires Henri Dunant to found the Red Cross.
Charles Blondin crosses Niagara Falls on a tightrope for the first time.
The first intercollegiate baseball game is played, between Amherst and Williams Colleges.
Charles XV succeeds his father Oscar I of Sweden and Norway (as Charles IV).
The chimes of Big Ben ring for the first time in London.

By the preliminary treaty signed at Villafranca, Italy, Lombardy is ceded to the French (who immediately cede it to Sardinia), while the Austrians keep Venetia, and the French promise to restore the Central Italian rulers expelled in the course of the war. This brings the Austro-Sardinian War effectively to a close.
The Bishop Cotton school (Shimla) (BCS) was founded on July 28, 1859,
Grand Combin, one of the highest summits in the Alps, is first ascended.
The Tuscan National Assembly formally deposes the House of Habsburg-Lorraine, ending an ascendancy of 109 years.
Edwin Drake drills the first oil well in the United States, near Titusville, Pennsylvania, starting the Pennsylvania oil rush.

September 2 – The solar storm of 1859, the largest geomagnetic solar storm on record, causes the Northern lights to be visible as far south as Montería, Colombia and knocks out telegraph communication (this is also called the Carrington Event).
British merchant Thomas Blake Glover begins business in Nagasaki, Japan.
In San Francisco, Joshua Norton proclaims himself to be His Imperial Majesty Emperor Norton I, Emperor of the United States and Protector of Mexico.
John Brown raids the Harpers Ferry Armory in Harper's Ferry, Virginia, in an unsuccessful bid to spark a general slave rebellion.
Troops under Colonel Robert E. Lee overpower John Brown at the Federal arsenal.
The steamship Royal Charter is wrecked on the coast of Anglesey, Wales, with 454 dead.
The current Cape Lookout, North Carolina, lighthouse is lighted for the first time (its first-order Fresnel lens can be seen for 19 miles).
The Treaty of Zürich, reaffirming the terms of the Treaty of Villafranca, brings the Austro-Sardinian War to an official close.
The first Zappas Olympics open in Greece.

English naturalist Charles Darwin publishes On the Origin of Species, a book which argues for the gradual evolution of species through natural selection (it immediately sells out its initial print run).
The French Navy's La Gloire, the first ocean-going ironclad warship in history, is launched.

Bernhard Riemann publishes On the Number of Primes Less Than a Given Magnitude. In his paper there is an incidental comment that later becomes the Riemann Hypothesis, one of the most important unsolved problems in Mathematics.
Militant abolitionist leader John Brown is hanged for his October 16 raid on Harpers Ferry, West Virginia.
The island of Timor is divided between Portugal and the Netherlands.
District nursing begins in Liverpool, England, when philanthropist William Rathbone employs Mary Robinson to nurse the sick poor in their own homes.
The Ateneo de Manila University is founded, as the Escuela Municipal de Manila.
Nillmij, a predecessor of Aegon, Dutch-based worldwide insurance company, is founded in the Dutch East Indies (modern Indonesia). [ citation needed ]
Tidskrift för hemmet, the first women's magazine in the Nordic countries, begins publication in Sweden.
The Society for Promoting the Employment of Women is founded.
Alfred, Lord Tennyson publishes the first set of Idylls of the King.
The Mary Institute is founded in Missouri.
George Eliot publishes Adam Bede.
John Stuart Mill publishes On Liberty.
Karl Marx publishes A Contribution to the Critique of Political Economy.
The University of Michigan Law School is founded.
The Rancho Rincon de Los Esteros Land Grant is confirmed to Rafael Alvisa (part of modern-day Santa Clara County, California).
The astronomer Urbain Le Verrier announces the discovery of a hypothetical planet Vulcan at a meeting of the French Academy of Sciences in Paris, France.
The Pemberton Mill in Lawrence, Massachusetts collapses, killing at least 77 workers.
Battle of Tétouan, Morocco: Spanish troops under General Leopoldo O'Donnell, 1st Duke of Tetuan defeat the Moroccan Army.
Camillo Benso, Count of Cavour is recalled as Prime Minister of Piedmont-Sardinia.
Canadian Royal Mail steamer SS Hungarian (1859) is wrecked on Cape Sable Island, Nova Scotia, on passage from the British Isles to the United States with all 205 onboard lost.
The Wiyot Massacre takes place at Tuluwat Island, Humboldt Bay in northern California.
Abraham Lincoln makes his Cooper Union speech in New York that is largely responsible for his election to the presidency.
The First Taranaki War begins at Waitara, New Zealand, when Māori refuse to sell land to British settlers.
The Grand Duchy of Tuscany is annexed to the newly formed Kingdom of Italy.
The second rout of the Jiangnan Daying destroys the Qing dynasty 's army of 180,000.

Sakuradamon Incident: Rōnin samurai of the Mito Domain in Japan assassinate tairō (Chief Minister) Ii Naosuke outside the Sakurada Gate of Edo Castle, disaffected with his role in the opening of Japan to foreign powers.
The first Italian Parliament meets at Turin.
In the U.S., the Pony Express begins its first run from St. Joseph, Missouri, to Sacramento, California, with riders carrying a small Bible.
A new uprising erupts in Palermo.

French typesetter Édouard-Léon Scott de Martinville creates a recording of the French folk song Au clair de la lune with his phonautograph, producing the world's earliest known intelligible sound recording of the human voice (however, it was not rediscovered until 2008).
A Chondrite-type meteorite falls to earth in Muskingum County, Ohio, near the town of New Concord.
Expedition of the Thousand: Giuseppe Garibaldi and his troops depart from Quarto.

In New Granada (modern-day Colombia) the southern state of Cauca secedes from the central government, in protest at the suggestion of increase of presidential powers; Magdalena and Bolívar join it; civil war erupts.
Expedition of the Thousand – Battle of Calatafimi: Troops under Giuseppe Garibaldi defeat the army of Naples in Sicily.
The German association football club TSV 1860 München is founded.
Garibaldi's forces take Palermo, the capital of Sicily.
(May 31 O.S.) – The State Bank of the Russian Empire is established.
Vladivostok is founded in Russia.
Mutsuhito (the future Emperor Meiji) becomes Crown Prince of Japan.
Battle of Milazzo: The forces of Giuseppe Garibaldi defeat royal Neapolitan forces near Messina, bringing nearly all of Sicily under Garibaldi's control. Garibaldi.
José Ignacio Pavón (1791-1866) becomes unconstitutional interim President of Mexico, replacing Miguel Miramón. Two days later Miramón becomes president again.
Assisted by the British Navy, the troops of Giuseppe Garibaldi cross from Sicily to the Italian mainland.
5 – The First International Chemistry Congress is held in Karlsruhe, Baden.
The PS Lady Elgin is accidentally rammed and sunk in Lake Michigan, drowning at least 300 people.
Giuseppe Garibaldi 's forces capture Naples.
Piedmontese forces invade the Papal States, hoping to link up with Garibaldi in Naples.

Battle of Castelfidardo: The Piedmontese decisively defeat the Papal forces, allowing them to continue their march into Neapolitan territory, and effectively reducing the Papal States to the territory around Rome.
Battle of Guayaquil: Ecuadorian forces, led by Juan José Flores and Gabriel García Moreno, take the port of Guayaquil from Supreme Chief Guillermo Franco, who is backed by Peruvian forces.
John Hanning Speke and James Augustus Grant leave Zanzibar, to search for the source of the Nile River.
Battle of Volturnus: Garibaldi defeats the last organized army of the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies.
Austria, Britain, France, Prussia and the Ottoman Empire form a commission to investigate the causes of the massacres of Maronite Christians, committed by Druzes in Lebanon earlier in the year.
Section 377 of the British Indian penal code was enacted in British India.
The Open Championship, also known as the British Open, is played for the first time at Prestwick Golf Club in Ayrshire, Scotland. The event is won by Willie Park Sr
The first Convention of Peking formally ends the Second Opium War.
21 – Beijing's Old Summer Palace is burned to the ground by orders of British general Lord Elgin, in retaliation for mistreatment of several prisoners of war, during the Second Opium War.
A new Māori revolt begins in New Zealand.
Garibaldi again defeats the Neapolitan forces, advancing on Gaeta, the last remaining Neapolitan strong-point.
Meeting at Teano: Giuseppe Garibaldi gives Naples to King Victor Emmanuel II, recognizing him as King of Italy.
The combined forces of Giuseppe Garibaldi and King Victor Emmanuel II besiege King Francis II of the Two Sicilies in Gaeta, his last remaining stronghold.

1860 United States presidential election: Abraham Lincoln elected as the 16th President of the United States, the first Republican to hold that office, defeating John C. Breckinridge, Stephen A. Douglas, and John Bell.
Charles Dickens publishes the first installment of Great Expectations in his magazine All the Year Round.
After a fiercely contested campaign, Monier Monier-Williams is elected as the new Boden Professor of Sanskrit, at Oxford University.
American Civil War: South Carolina, led by Governor Francis Pickens, becomes the first state to secede from the United States.
Mexico's interim president Miguel Miramón flees the country after being defeated in battle.
Christians and Druzes clash in Damascus, Syria.
The Russian Empire has c. 1,250 miles (2,010 km) of railroads.
Discovery of the chemical elements: Robert Bunsen discovers caesium and rubidium.
China agrees, in an unequal treaty (the Convention of Peking) imposed on it, to allow missionaries to proselytize throughout the country.
The world's first ocean-going (all) iron-hulled and armoured battleship, the (British) HMS Warrior, is launched.
German chemist Albert Niemann makes a detailed analysis of the coca leaf, isolating and purifying the alkaloid, which he calls cocaine.
Napoleon III, Emperor of the French, and Empress Eugénie visit Algiers and stay at the Casbah of Algiers.
In Buenos Aires, leader Bartolomé Mitre subverts the Argentine Confederation and begins to establish a new centralist government, with the help of Uruguayan Colorado party leader Venancio Flores.
TAG Heuer watchmaker founded in Bern Canton, Switzerland.
The first steam-powered carousel is recorded, in Bolton, England.
Benito Juárez captures Mexico City.
Friedrich Wilhelm IV of Prussia dies, and is succeeded by Wilhelm I.
Delaware votes not to secede from the Union.
Mississippi becomes the second state to secede from the Union.
Florida secedes from the Union.
Alabama secedes from the Union.
Major Robert Anderson sends dispatches to Washington.
Georgia secedes from the Union.
Jefferson Davis resigns from the United States Senate.
Louisiana secedes from the Union.
Kansas is admitted as the 34th U.S. state, being admitted as a free state.
Kukis raid the Chhagalnaiya plains in eastern Bengal, murdering and kidnapping hundreds of people, particularly women.
Texas secedes from the Union.
In Montgomery, Alabama, the Provisional Confederate States Congress is formed by representatives from the first seven break-away states.
The Confederate States of America are formed, comprising the first seven break-away States.
Jefferson Davis is elected Provisional President of the Confederate States of America, by the Weed Convention at Montgomery, Alabama.
American Civil War: The U.S. House unanimously passes a resolution, guaranteeing non-interference with slavery in any state.
About 850 convicts at Chatham Dockyard in England take over their prison in a riot.
Unification of Italy: The Siege of Gaeta, stronghold of the Neapolitan King Francis II, is ended by Piedmontese forces. Francis goes into exile.
American Civil War: In Montgomery, Alabama, Jefferson Davis is inaugurated as the provisional president of the Confederate States of America.
In Britain, storms damage the Crystal Palace and cause the collapse of the steeple of Chichester Cathedral.
Mariehamn, the capital of Åland, is founded.
President-elect Abraham Lincoln arrives secretly in Washington, D.C. after in light of suspicions of a conspiracy in Baltimore to kill him.
Battle of Ky Hoa: the French and the Spanish defeat the Vietnamese.
Russian troops fire upon a crowd in Warsaw protesting Russian rule over Poland, killing 5 protesters.
Colorado is organized as a United States territory.
Nevada is organized as a United States territory.
American Civil War: Texas is admitted to the Confederate States of America.
Emancipation reform of 1861: Alexander II abolishes serfdom in the Russian Empire.
American Civil War: The " Stars and Bars " is adopted as the flag of the Confederate States of America.
El Hadj Umar Tall seizes the city of Ségou, destroying the Bamana Empire of Mali.
American Civil War: The Constitution of the Confederate States of America is adopted.
Tsushima incident: The Russian corvette Posadnik arrives at Tsushima Island in the Korea Strait, Japan, provoking a reaction from the Japanese Shogunate.
Unification of Italy: The Kingdom of Italy is proclaimed by the new Parliament, with Victor Emmanuel II of Piedmont-Sardinia becoming its king.
The First Taranaki War ends in New Zealand.
An earthquake completely destroys Mendoza, Argentina.
Unification of Italy: The surrender of Civitella del Tronto ends the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies.

Alexander Stephens, Vice President of the Confederacy, gives the infamous Cornerstone Speech in Savannah, Georgia, in which he declares that slavery is the natural condition of blacks, and the foundation of the Confederacy.
Confederate Arizona: A convention in modern-day Tucson ratifies the ordinance of secession of the southern part of New Mexico Territory.
Discovery of the chemical elements: British chemist William Crookes announces his discovery of thallium.
A population census is taken in the United Kingdom. The population is more than double that of 1801 and those living in urban areas are in a majority.
The American Civil War begins with the bombardment of Fort Sumter, South Carolina.
Fort Sumter surrenders to Southern forces. April 12 – 13: Fort Sumter
President Abraham Lincoln issues a Proclamation calling for 75,000 men to confront in the South, "combinations too powerful to be suppressed in the ordinary way".
The state of Virginia secedes from the Union.
Robert E. Lee resigns his commission in the United States Army, in order to command the forces of the state of Virginia.
Bezdna unrest: Bezdna in Russia is the scene of a peasant uprising; the military open fire and about 90 are killed.
American Civil War: The Union Army arrives in Washington, D.C.
Giovanni Schiaparelli discovers the asteroid 69 Hesperia.
American Civil War: President Abraham Lincoln suspends the writ of habeas corpus in the United States.
Arkansas secedes from the Union.
Tennessee secedes from the Union.
Richmond, Virginia, is named the capital of the Confederate States of America.
Comet C/1861 J1 (the "Great Comet of 1861") is discovered from Australia. May 13: Great Comet
North Star affair: The British merchant ship North Star leaves Hong Kong for Nagasaki, Japan. Chinese pirates board the vessel, kill an officer, and escape with a large quantity of gold.
American Civil War: Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom issues a "proclamation of neutrality ", which recognizes the breakaway states as having belligerent rights.
The Canellas meteorite, an 859 gram chondrite type meteorite, strikes Earth near Barcelona, Spain.
A 7-day working men's package holiday to Paris, organised by Thomas Cook, sets out from London Bridge station.
Kentucky proclaims its neutrality, which lasts until September 3, when Confederate forces enter the state.
North Carolina secedes from the Union.
Russian sailors clash with a group of Japanese samurai and farmers at Tsushima Island.
American Civil War: The state of Virginia's ordinance of secession from the United States is ratified in a referendum.
The Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce is established.

Règlement Organique: With the approval of European powers, the Mount Lebanon Mutasarrifate is established as a semi-autonomous sub-division separate from the Sidon Eyalet. An Ottoman Armenian, Davud Pasha, is appointed Mutasarrıf by the Ottoman Sultan.
Benito Juárez is formally elected President of Mexico; he temporarily stops the payments of foreign debt.
Tooley Street fire breaks out and takes the life of James Braidwood, first superintendent of the London Fire Brigade.
Abdülmecid I, Sultan of the Ottoman Empire (1839 –1861) dies and is succeeded by Abdülaziz (1861– 1876). June 25: Abdülaziz
Lambing Flat riots: White miners attack Chinese in the Australian goldfields.
In Cologne, the Wallraf–Richartz Museum of art opens.
French and Imperial Chinese troops defeat Taiping forces.
The first issue of the Vatican 's newspaper L'Osservatore Romano is published.
Ivan Kasatkin lands on Hakodate, and introduces the Eastern Orthodox Church into Japan.
The Confederate States sign a Treaty with Choctaws and Chickasaws in Indian Territory.
The Battle of Corrick's Ford takes place in western Virginia.
First Battle of Bull Run – At Manassas Junction, Virginia, the first major battle of the war ends in a Confederate victory.
The Crittenden–Johnson Resolution is passed by the U.S. Congress, stating that the war is being fought to preserve the Union, and not to end slavery.
George B. McClellan assumes command of the Army of the Potomac, following the disastrous Union defeat at the First Battle of Bull Run.
The first public weather forecast: measured and predicted correctly by Admiral Robert FitzRoy in Britain.
The first major battle west of the Mississippi River, the Battle of Wilson's Creek, is fought, with a Confederate victory.
First description of Archaeopteryx, based on a feather found in Bavaria; in September the first complete identified skeleton is found near Langenaltheim in Germany.
Weisshorn, the fifth highest summit in the Alps, is first ascended.
22 – The first modern Welsh National Eisteddfod takes place in Aberdare.
Martin Doyle 's is the last execution in Britain for attempted murder.
Confederate General Leonidas Polk invades neutral Kentucky, prompting the state legislature to ask for Union assistance.
Forces under Union General Ulysses S. Grant bloodlessly capture Paducah, Kentucky, which gives the Union control of the mouth of the Tennessee River.
Argentine Civil War: Battle of Pavón: Victory of Buenos Aires over the Argentine Confederation, and the re-unification of Argentina.
American Civil War: Battle of Santa Rosa Island – Confederate forces are defeated in their effort to take the island.
Australian frontier wars: Cullin-la-ringo massacre – 19 white settlers are murdered by indigenous Australians, following which more than 300 of the latter are killed in retaliation.

American Civil War: Battle of Ball's Bluff – Union forces under Colonel Edward Baker are defeated by Confederate troops, in the second major battle of the war. Baker, a close friend of Abraham Lincoln, is also killed in the fighting.
Western Union completes the first transcontinental telegraph line across the United States.
HMS Warrior, the world's first ocean-going (all) iron-hulled armored battleship, is completed and commissioned into the British Royal Navy.
The Toronto Stock Exchange is established in Canada.
The Pony Express American transcontinental mail service announces its closure.
The Missouri legislature takes up a bill for Missouri's secession from the Union.
The bill for Missouri's secession from the Union is passed.
The Spanish, French and British governments sign a tripartite agreement to intervene in Mexico, in the hope of recovering unpaid debts.
The Missouri secession bill is signed by Governor Jackson.
American Civil War: Citing failing health, 75-year-old Union General Winfield Scott resigns as Commander of the United States Army.
U.S. President Abraham Lincoln appoints George B. McClellan as commander of the Union Army, replacing Winfield Scott.
American Civil War: Western Department Union General John C. Frémont is relieved of command and replaced by David Hunter.
The University of Washington is founded in Seattle.
The first Melbourne Cup horse race is held in Melbourne, Australia.
Jefferson Davis is elected president of the Confederate States of America.

Battle of Belmont – In Belmont, Missouri, Union forces led by General Ulysses S. Grant (in his first combat leadership role) overrun a Confederate camp, but are forced to retreat when Confederate reinforcements arrive.
Trent Affair – The USS San Jacinto stops the United Kingdom mail ship Trent, and arrests two Confederate envoys, James Mason and John Slidell, sparking a diplomatic crisis between the U.K. and U.S.
Death of French explorer Henri Mouhot, following which his servant Phrai begins shipping his diaries and specimens back to the west; they include accounts of Mouhot's discovery of Angkor Wat.
Battle of Round Mountain in Indian Territory (modern-day Oklahoma).
Confederate President Jefferson Davis appoints Judah P. Benjamin Secretary of War.
A tenement collapses in the Old Town, Edinburgh (Scotland), killing 35 people, while 15 others survive.
At a battle in the Sundarbans of Bengal, the house of Rahimullah of Baraikhali is attacked and he and 33 others are killed.
Acting on the ordinance passed by the Jackson government, the Confederate Congress admits Missouri as the 12th Confederate state.
American Civil War: Trent Affair – The British government dispatches its response, partly drafted by Albert, Prince Consort (a fortnight before his death).
American Civil War: A rebel government representing Kentucky is accepted into the Confederate States of America, although Kentucky officially remains part of the United States.
In southern French Indochina, resistance forces led by Nguyễn Trung Trực ambush, board and sink the French lorcha (boat) L'Esperance on the Nhat Tao canal.
Medal of Honor: Public Resolution 82, containing a provision for a Navy Medal of Valor, is signed into law by U.S. President Abraham Lincoln.
The Perpetual Truce of Peace and Friendship is signed between Bahrain and the United Kingdom.
The first industrial meat packing plant in Uruguay is established, at Fray Bentos.
The British Empire establishes bases in Lagos to stop the slave trade.
The first permanent color photograph is captured by Thomas Sutton using the three-color method proposed by James Clerk Maxwell.
The Royal Seminary becomes the first public institution of higher academic learning open to women in Sweden.
Statistically, this year is considered the end of the whale oil industry and (in replacement) the beginning of the petroleum oil industry.
The United Kingdom annexes Lagos Island, in modern-day Nigeria.
French intervention in Mexico: French, Spanish and British forces arrive in Veracruz, Mexico.
Hartley Colliery disaster in north-east England: 204 men are trapped and die underground when the only shaft becomes blocked.
American Civil War: The first U.S. ironclad warship, USS Monitor, is launched in Brooklyn.
Alvan Graham Clark makes the first observation of Sirius B, a white dwarf star, through an eighteen-inch telescope at Northwestern University in Illinois.
American Civil War: Julia Ward Howe 's " Battle Hymn of the Republic " is published for the first time in the Atlantic Monthly.
The first railway is opened in New Zealand, by the Dun Mountain Copper Mining Company.
General Ulysses S. Grant gives the Union Army its first victory of the war, by capturing Fort Henry, Tennessee.
16 – Battle of Fort Donelson – General Ulysses S. Grant attacks Fort Donelson, Tennessee, capturing it on the last day.
Battle of Valverde – Confederate forces defeat Union troops near Fort Craig in New Mexico Territory:
Jefferson Davis is officially inaugurated in Richmond, Virginia, to a six-year term as president of the Confederate States.
An ammunition warehouse explosion in San Andres Chalchicomula, Mexico, kills between 1,400 and 2,280 during the Second French intervention in Mexico.
Battle of Pea Ridge – The Confederates are shut out of Missouri.
Ironclad CSS Virginia (formerly USS Merrimack) is launched at Hampton Roads, Virginia; the Battle of Hampton Roads starts the same day.

American Civil War: The U.S. federal government forbids all Union army officers from returning fugitive slaves, thus effectively annulling the Fugitive Slave Act of 1850 and setting the stage for the Emancipation Proclamation.
A smallpox epidemic in San Francisco spreads to British Columbia.
The first railway line in Finland, between the cities of Helsinki and Hämeenlinna, is officially opened.
28 – American Civil War: Battle of Glorieta Pass – In New Mexico, Union forces succeed in stopping the Confederate invasion of New Mexico Territory.
Victor Hugo 's epic French historical novel Les Misérables begins publication in Brussels.
Second French intervention in Mexico: The Spanish and the British ended their alliance with France.
Battle of Yorktown – The battle begins when Union Army forces under General George B. McClellan close in on the Confederate capital of Richmond, Virginia.
7 – Battle of Shiloh – The Union Army, under General Ulysses S. Grant, defeats the Confederates near Shiloh, Tennessee.

Great Locomotive Chase (Andrews' Raid) – Union volunteers steal Confederate steam railroad locomotive The General (which will still exist in the 21st century) in an attempt to sabotage the rail network.* April 13 – The government of Vietnam is forced to cede the territories of Biên Hòa, Gia Định and Định Tường to France.
Global financial group UBS is founded in Switzerland as the Bank in Winterthur.
Capture of New Orleans – Forces under Union Admiral David Farragut occupy the Confederate city of New Orleans, securing access to the Mississippi River.
Siege of Fort Macon – The besieged Confederate garrison at Fort Macon, North Carolina surrenders.
November 1 – The 1862 International Exhibition is held at South Kensington in London; it is particularly noteworthy for an exhibit from Japan, influential in the development of Anglo-Japanese style.
The California State Normal School (later San Jose State University) is created by an Act of the California legislature.
Second French intervention in Mexico: Battle of Puebla – Mexican General Ignacio Zaragoza defeats the French Army; commemorated each year as Cinco de Mayo (Spanish for Fifth of May).
American Civil War: Ironclad CSS Virginia is scuttled in the James River northwest of Norfolk, Virginia.
U.S. President Abraham Lincoln signs a bill into law creating the U.S. Bureau of Agriculture (later renamed U.S. Department of Agriculture).
U.S. President Abraham Lincoln signs the Homestead Act into law.
Westminster Bridge is opened across the Thames in London. This new iron bridge, designed by Thomas Page, replaces the previous stone one.
Battle of Fair Oaks – Both sides claim victory.
Confederate troops evacuate Fort Pillow on the Mississippi River, leaving the way clear for Union Army troops to capture Memphis, Tennessee.

Treaty of Saigon: Emperor Tự Đức of the Nguyễn dynasty in Vietnam cedes Saigon, Côn Sơn Island and three southern provinces of what is to become known as Cochinchina (Biên Hòa, Gia Định and Định Tường) to become part of the French colonial empire. Guerilla leader Trương Định refuses to recognize the treaty.
First Battle of Memphis – Union Army troops capture Memphis, Tennessee, from the Confederate States.

Battle of Cross Keys – Confederate troops under General Stonewall Jackson save the Army of Northern Virginia from a Union Army attack on the James Peninsula that is led by General George B. McClellan.

John Winter Robinson, the Secretary of State of Kansas, is convicted and removed from office as the result of a bond scandal, becoming the first state executive official to be impeached and removed from office in American history.
American Civil War: Battle of Mechanicsville – Confederate General Robert E. Lee defeats the troops of General George B. McClellan in the first of the Seven Days Battles.
The Russian State Library is founded, as The Library of the Moscow Public Museum.
The Bureau of Internal Revenue, the forerunner of the Internal Revenue Service, is established in the United States.
Princess Alice, the second daughter of Queen Victoria, marries Prince Ludwig of Hesse and by Rhine.
U.S. President Abraham Lincoln signs into law the Pacific Railroad Acts, authorizing construction of the First Transcontinental Railroad.
U.S. President Abraham Lincoln signs the Morrill Land-Grant Act into law, creating a system of land-grant colleges, to teach agricultural and mechanical sciences across the United States.

Charles Dodgson (better known as Lewis Carroll) extemporises the story that becomes Alice's Adventures in Wonderland, for ten-year-old Alice Liddell and her sisters, on a rowboat trip on The Isis from Oxford to Godstow.
American Civil War:
American Civil War: David Farragut becomes the first rear admiral in the U.S. Navy.
Dent Blanche, one of the highest summits in the Alps, is first ascended.
American Civil War: Henry Halleck takes command of the Union Army.
Battle of Baton Rouge – Along the Mississippi River near Baton Rouge, Louisiana, Confederate troops drive Union forces back into the city.
Confederate ironclad CSS Arkansas is scuttled on the Mississippi River after suffering damage in a battle with USS Essex, near Baton Rouge, Louisiana.
Battle of Cedar Mountain – Confederate General Stonewall Jackson narrowly defeats Union forces under General John Pope at Cedar Mountain, Virginia.

U.S. President Abraham Lincoln meets with a group of prominent African-Americans, the first time an American President has done so. He suggests that Black people should migrate to Africa or to Central America, but this advice is rejected.
The Dakota War of 1862 begins in Minnesota, as Dakota Sioux attack white settlements along the Minnesota River. They are overwhelmed by the U.S. Army six weeks later.

Dakota War of 1862: During an uprising in Minnesota, Dakota warriors decide not to attack heavily defended Fort Ridgely and instead turn to the settlement of New Ulm, killing white settlers along the way.

Horace Greeley publishes an editorial, "The Prayer of Twenty Millions", in the New York Tribune, in which he urges U.S. President Abraham Lincoln to make abolition of slavery an official aim of the Union war effort.
The Vienna Stadtpark opens its gates.
30 – Second Battle of Bull Run – Confederate forces inflict a crushing defeat on Union General John Pope.
30 – Battle of Richmond, Kentucky – Confederate forces, led by General Edmund Kirby Smith, inflict a crushing defeat on Union General William "Bull" Nelson.
Battle of Chantilly – Confederate General Robert E. Lee leads his forces in an attack on retreating Union troops in Chantilly, Virginia, driving them away.
U.S. President Abraham Lincoln restores Union General George B. McClellan to full command, after General John Pope's disastrous defeat at the Second Battle of Bull Run.

In the Confederacy's first invasion of the North, General Robert E. Lee leads 55,000 men of the Army of Northern Virginia across the Potomac River at White's Ford near Leesburg, Virginia, into Maryland.
Francisco Solano López is appointed second President of Paraguay.
American Civil War:
Battle of Antietam: Union forces strategically defeat Confederate troops at Sharpsburg, Maryland, in the bloodiest day in U.S. history, with over 22,000 casualties.
mostly young women – being killed.
Battle of Iuka – Union troops under Major General William Rosecrans defeat a Confederate force commanded by Major General Sterling Price at Iuka, Mississippi.

American Civil War: The preliminary announcement of the Emancipation Proclamation is made by U.S. President Abraham Lincoln: From January 1, 1863, slaves in the Confederate States will be considered free.
Otto von Bismarck becomes Minister President of Prussia, following refusal by the country's Landtag to accept the military budget.
Johann II, Prince of Liechtenstein signs into law the 1862 Constitution of Liechtenstein.
New Prussian prime minister Otto von Bismarck delivers his Blood and Iron (Blut und Eisen) speech to the Prussian Landtag.

American Civil War: Battle of Perryville – Union Army forces under General Don Carlos Buell halt the Confederate invasion of Kentucky by defeating troops led by General Braxton Bragg at Perryville, Kentucky.
The Transvaal Civil War breaks out, following Stephanus Schoeman 's unconstitutional ousting of the acting President of the Executive Council of the South African Republic.
