Stella Maris Church, Sliema on Malta becomes a parish, seceding from the Parish of St. Helen's in Birkirkara.
The Specie Resumption Act takes effect. The United States Note is valued the same as gold, for the first time since the American Civil War.
Brahms ' Violin Concerto is premiered in Leipzig with Joseph Joachim as soloist and the composer conducting.
The Anglo-Zulu War begins.
Anglo-Zulu War – Battle of Isandlwana: A force of 1,200 British soldiers is wiped out by over 20,000 Zulu warriors. January 22: Battle of Isandlwana
Anglo-Zulu War – Battle of Rorke's Drift: Following the previous day's defeat, a smaller British force of 140 successfully repels an attack by 4,000 Zulus. January 22–23: Battle of Rorke's Drift
Mosley Street in Newcastle upon Tyne (England) becomes the world's first public highway to be lit by the electric incandescent light bulb invented by Joseph Swan.
At a meeting of the Royal Canadian Institute, engineer and inventor Sandford Fleming first proposes the global adoption of standard time.
United States Geological Survey is founded.
The Ryukyu Domain is incorporated into the Okinawa Prefecture of Japan and the last ruler, Shō Tai, exiled to Tokyo.
Dvořák 's Symphony No. 5 in F major, Op. 76, B. 54, is premiered (four years after being written) in Prague with Adolf Čech conducting.
Anglo-Zulu War – Battle of Hlobane: British forces suffer a defeat.
Anglo-Zulu War – Battle of Kambula: British forces defeat 20,000 Zulus.
Postman Ferdinand Cheval begins to build his Palais Idéal at Hauterives in France.
War of the Pacific: Chile formally declares war on Bolivia and Peru.
Mary Baker Eddy founds the Church of Christ, Scientist in Boston, Massachusetts.
The National Park, later renamed the Royal National Park, is declared in New South Wales, Australia, the world's second-oldest purposed national park.
The Spanish Socialist Workers' Party (Partido Socialista Obrero Español) is founded clandestinely at the Casa Labra tavern in Madrid, by printer Pablo Iglesias.
The current constitution of the State of California in the United States is ratified.
The Archaeological Institute of America (AIA) is formed.
English Catholic convert John Henry Newman is elevated to Cardinal.
The first group of 463 Indian indentured labourers arrive in Fiji, aboard the Leonidas.
Russia and the United Kingdom sign the Treaty of Gandamak, establishing an Afghan state.
New York City's Gilmore's Garden is renamed Madison Square Garden by William Henry Vanderbilt and is opened to the public at 26th Street and Madison Avenue.
Anglo-Zulu War: Louis-Napoléon, Prince Imperial of France, son of Napoléon III, is killed in Africa while attached to the British Army.
Yasukuni Shrine is officially renamed from Tokyo Shokonsha Shrine in Japan.

William Denny and Brothers launch the world's first ocean-going steamer to be built of mild steel, the SS Rotomahana, on the River Clyde in Scotland. On October 2 they launch the first transatlantic steamer of the same material, the SS Buenos Ayrean; on December 1 she makes her maiden voyage out of Glasgow, bound for South America.
Sidney Faithorn Green, a priest in the Church of England, is tried and convicted for using Ritualist practices.
German chemical company Linde is founded by Carl von Linde.
The 1879 Surigao earthquake measuring M w 7.4 causes major damage in the northern tip of Mindanao Island.

American Christian Restorationist Charles Taze Russell publishes the first issue of the monthly Zion's Watch Tower and Herald of Christ's Presence which, as The Watchtower, will become the most widely circulated magazine in the world.
An 8.0 earthquake shakes southern Gansu, killing 22,000 people.
Anglo-Zulu War – Battle of Ulundi: A British victory effectively ends the war.
Led by George W. De Long, the ill-fated United States Jeannette Expedition departs San Francisco, in an attempt to reach the North Pole, by pioneering a route through the Bering Strait.
The city of Kotka is founded in Kymenlaakso, Finland, by separating its two islands from the old Kymi parish.
Tokio Marine (insurer) is founded in Japan, as Tokio Marine Holdings.
Fulham F.C. is founded in London as a church soccer team.
Claimed apparition to local people at Knock, County Mayo, Ireland, of the Blessed Virgin Mary, Saint Joseph, Saint John the Evangelist and Jesus Christ (as the Lamb of God).
Henry George self-publishes his major work Progress and Poverty.
A fire in The Octagon, Dunedin (New Zealand), claims 12 victims.
The Blackpool Illuminations in England are switched on for the first time.
The Macedo-Romanian Cultural Society is founded.
A fire in Deadwood, South Dakota, leaves 2,000 people homeless and 300 buildings destroyed; total loss of property is estimated at $3 million.
Wilhelm Marr founds the Antisemitenliga (League of Antisemites), the first German organization committed specifically to combating the alleged threat to German culture posed by Jews.
Meeker Massacre: Nathan Meeker and others are killed in an uprising at the White River Ute Indian reservation in Colorado.

University of Nebraska Cornhusker Marching Band is founded in Lincoln, Nebraska. The group will go on to perform the first football halftime show in 1892 and, under Director Donald A. Lentz, invent Band Day.
Qing dynasty China signs the Treaty of Livadia with the Russian Empire.
The Dual Alliance is formed by Germany and Austria-Hungary.
War of the Pacific: Battle of Angamos – The Chilean Navy defeats Peruvian naval forces.
The first female students are admitted to study for degrees of the University of Oxford in England, at the new Lady Margaret Hall and Somerville Hall, and with the Society of Oxford Home-Students.
Sunderland Association Football Club is formed by a group of schoolteachers in northeast England.
Using a filament of carbonized thread, Thomas Edison tests his first practical electric light bulb (it lasts 13 + 1 ⁄ 2 hours before burning out).
Land is acquired for Simmons College of Kentucky, a historically black school, established as a Baptist institution.
The Hall effect is discovered by Edwin Hall at Johns Hopkins University in the United States.
Thomas Edison applies for a patent for his invention of the incandescent light bulb (U.S. Patent 223,898 will be granted on January 27, 1880).
The Bell Telephone Company and Western Union reach an agreement in the United States, in which the former agrees to stay out of telegraphy and the latter to keep out of the telephone business.
Tay Bridge disaster: The central part of the Tay Rail Bridge at Dundee, Scotland, collapses in a storm as a train passes over it, killing 75.
Wilhelm Wundt establishes the first psychological research laboratory, at the University of Leipzig.
The Stefan–Boltzmann law is discovered by Jozef Stefan.
Colonel Ahmed ‘Urabi forms the Egyptian Nationalist Party.
Gottlob Frege publishes Begriffsschrift, eine der arithmetischen nachgebildete Formelsprache des reinen Denkens in Halle, a significant text in the development of mathematical logic.
Thomas Edison demonstrates incandescent lighting to the public for the first time, in Menlo Park, New Jersey.
Tetteh Quarshie first brings cocoa beans to Ghana from Equatorial Guinea.

Gilbert and Sullivan 's comic opera The Pirates of Penzance opens at the Fifth Avenue Theatre in New York City (following a token performance the day before for U.K. copyright reasons in Paignton, Devon).

Thomas Edison is granted a patent for the incandescent light bulb. Edison filed for a US patent for an electric lamp using "a carbon filament or strip coiled and connected... to platina contact wires." Although the patent described several ways of creating the carbon filament,including using "cotton and linen thread, wood splints, papers coiled in various ways," Edison and his team later discovered that a carbonized bamboo filament could last more than 1200 hours.
The international White slave trade affair scandal in Brussels is exposed and attracts international infamy.
The first successful shipment of frozen mutton from Australia arrives in London, aboard the SS Strathleven.
The first electric streetlight is installed in Wabash, Indiana.
The Black Donnelly Massacre takes the lives of five members of one family in Biddulph Township, Middlesex County, Ontario, Canada.

The SS Columbia, which will be the first outside usage of Thomas Edison 's incandescent light bulb, is launched at the Delaware River Iron Ship Building and Engine Works of John Roach & Sons in Chester, Pennsylvania.
The government of Cape Colony sets a deadline for the Basuto people to surrender their weapons; non-compliance leads to the Basuto Gun War.
1880 United Kingdom general election: William Ewart Gladstone defeats Benjamin Disraeli, to become Prime Minister for the second time.
The Prime Minister of Sweden, Louis De Geer, resigns over the defeat of a defense reform bill in the country's Riksdag; he is succeeded by Count Arvid Posse (1880–1883).
The Royal University of Ireland is founded by charter, allowing the Catholic University of Ireland to re-form as University College Dublin.
After having her lights installed by Edison's personnel, the SS Columbia is lit up for the first time at the foot of Wall Street, in New York City.
The SS Columbia sets off on her maiden voyage around Cape Horn to Portland, Oregon, carrying 13 locomotives and 200 railcars.
In Menlo Park, New Jersey, Thomas Edison performs the first test of his electric railway.
Tinius Olsen is awarded a United States Patent, for the Little Giant Testing Machine.
Australian police capture bank robber Ned Kelly, after a gun battle at Glenrowan, Victoria.
France annexes Tahiti.
John Venn popularises Venn diagrams.
Dorchester Penitentiary opens in Canada.
Abdur Rahman Khan becomes Emir of Afghanistan.
Second Anglo-Afghan War – Battle of Maiwand: Afghan troops under Ayub Khan defeat British and Indian forces, under Brigadier General George Burrows.
Cologne Cathedral is completed, after construction began in 1248, 632 years earlier.
The SS Columbia completes her maiden voyage, arriving without incident in Portland, Oregon, after a stopover in San Francisco.

Competing circus owners P. T. Barnum and James A. Bailey sign a contract in Bridgeport, Connecticut, to create the Barnum & Bailey Circus. In 1907, the circus will merge forces with another competitor, the Ringling Brothers Circus.
Second Anglo-Afghan War – Battle of Kandahar: General Frederick Roberts, commanding British forces, defeats the Afghan troops of Mohammad Ayub Khan, bringing an end to the war.
German company Munich Re is founded in Munich.
The University of Southern California opens its doors to 53 students and 10 faculty.
Mexican soldiers kill Victorio, one of the greatest Apache military strategists.
A blizzard marks the start of the Hard Winter in North America.
The first stone is laid for the Clarkson Memorial in Wisbech, England.
1880 United States presidential election: James Garfield defeats Winfield S. Hancock.
The first cash register is patented by James and John Ritty of Dayton, Ohio.
A major earthquake strikes Zagreb and destroys many buildings, including Zagreb Cathedral.
Australian bushranger and bank robber Ned Kelly is hanged in Melbourne.
Vaudeville actress Lillian Russell makes her debut at Tony Pastor 's Theatre, in New York City.
Manuel González Flores becomes the 31st President of Mexico.
First Boer War: The Battle of Bronkhorstspruit results in a Boer victory over the British.
The Department of Scientific Temperance Instruction, of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union, is established in the United States.
The Transvaal becomes a republic, and Paul Kruger becomes its first president.
Pierre Savorgnan de Brazza signs a treaty of protection with the chief of the large Teke tribe, and begins to establish a French protectorate on the north bank of the Congo River.
Piezoelectricity is discovered by Pierre Curie and Jacques Curie.
The Capuchin catacombs of Palermo are officially closed (there will be some burials afterwards).
24 – Siege of Geok Tepe: Russian troops under General Mikhail Skobelev defeat the Turkomans.
War of the Pacific – Battle of San Juan and Chorrillos: The Chilean army defeats Peruvian forces.
War of the Pacific – Battle of Miraflores: The Chileans take Lima, capital of Peru, after defeating its second line of defense in Miraflores.

William Edward Forster, chief secretary for Ireland, introduces his Coercion Bill, which temporarily suspends habeas corpus so that those people suspected of committing an offence can be detained without trial; it goes through a long debate before it is accepted February 2. Note that Coercion bills had been passed almost annually in the 19th century, with a total of 105 such bills passed from 1801 to 1921.
Thomas Edison and Alexander Graham Bell form the Oriental Telephone Company.
The first issue of the feminist newspaper La Citoyenne is published by Hubertine Auclert in Paris.
The Canadian Pacific Railway is incorporated.
Carlos Finlay introduces his discovery of the transmission of Yellow Fever by mosquitoes Aedes aegypti, in the Fifth International Sanitary Conference held in Washington, D.C.
Kansas becomes the first U.S. state to prohibit all alcoholic beverages.
Qing dynasty China signs the Treaty of Saint Petersburg with the Russian Empire providing for the return to China of the eastern part of the Ili Basin. [ dubious – discuss ]
Phoenix, Arizona, is incorporated.
The Cunard Line 's SS Servia, the first large steel transatlantic liner, is launched at Clydebank in Scotland.

Assassination of Alexander II of Russia: Emperor Alexander II of Russia ("the Liberator") is killed near his palace in Saint Petersburg when bombs are thrown at him, an act committed by the revolutionary socialist group Narodnaya Volya coordinated by Sophia Perovskaya but falsely blamed upon Russian Jews. He is succeeded by his son, Alexander III. The assassin Ignacy Hryniewiecki is also killed by his own bomb.
The First Boer War comes to an end.
A fire caused by a gas explosion destroys the Opéra de Nice in the south of France with fatalities.
The Principality of Romania is proclaimed the Kingdom of Romania.
Edward Rudolf founds the ' Church of England Central Society for Providing Homes for Waifs and Strays' (later The Children's Society).
Spelman College is established in Atlanta, Georgia.
The Four Dead in Five Seconds Gunfight erupts in El Paso, Texas.
Anti-Semitic pogroms in Southern Russia begin.
Temuco, Chile, is founded.
The University of Connecticut is founded as the Storrs Agricultural School.
Caulfield Grammar School is founded in Melbourne, Australia.
Billy the Kid escapes from his 2 jailers at the Lincoln County Jail in Mesilla, New Mexico, killing James Bell and Robert Ollinger, before stealing a horse and riding out of town.
30 – SS Tararua hits a reef and sinks off the coast of New Zealand 's South Island with only 20 survivors of the 151 onboard.
In North Africa, Tunisia becomes a French protectorate by the Treaty of Bardo.
The Pacific island of Rotuma cedes to Great Britain, becoming a dependency of the Colony of Fiji.
The world's first regular electric tram service is started in Berlin, by Siemens & Halske.
The American Red Cross is established by Clara Barton.
The United States Tennis Association is established by a small group of tennis club members; the first U.S. Tennis Championships are played this year.
Prince Karl of Hohenzollern-Sigmaringen is crowned King of Romania.
The USS Jeannette is crushed in an Arctic Ocean ice pack.
The League of the Three Emperors is resurrected.
The current Cincinnati Reds baseball team plays its first game.
War of the Pacific – Battle of Sangrar: Peruvian and Chilean forces battle to a draw.
General Order 70, the culmination of the Cardwell–Childers reforms of the British Army 's organization, comes into effect.
Assassination of James A. Garfield: United States President James A. Garfield is shot by lawyer Charles J. Guiteau in Washington, D.C. The wound becomes infected, killing Garfield on September 19.
Tuskegee Institute opens in Alabama.
The first episode of Carlo Collodi 's The Adventures of Pinocchio is published in Italy.
20 – The London Social Revolutionary Congress is held; delegates include Marie Le Compte, Peter Kropotkin, Errico Malatesta, Saverio Merlino, Louise Michel, Nikolai Tchaikovsky and Émile Gautier.
Billy the Kid is shot and killed by Pat Garrett, outside Fort Sumner, New Mexico.
American Indian Wars: Sioux chief Sitting Bull leads the last of his people in surrender to United States troops at Fort Buford in Montana.
The Boundary Treaty of 1881 between Chile and Argentina is signed in Buenos Aires.
The Pretoria Convention peace treaty is signed, officially ending the war between the Boers and Britain.
The fifth hurricane of the Atlantic season hits Florida and the Carolinas, killing about 700.
The Thumb Fire in the U.S. state of Michigan destroys over a million acres (4,000 km 2) and kills 282 people.

Francis Howell High School (Howell Institute) in St. Charles, Missouri, and Stephen F. Austin High School in Austin, Texas, open on the same day, putting them in a tie for the title of the oldest public high school west of the Mississippi River.
President James A. Garfield dies eleven weeks after being shot. Vice President Chester A. Arthur becomes the 21st president of the United States.
Godalming becomes the first town in England to have its streets illuminated by electric light (hydroelectrically generated).
December 31 – The International Cotton Exposition is held in Atlanta, Georgia, USA.
Richard D'Oyly Carte 's Savoy Theatre opens in London, the world's first public building to be fully lit by electricity, using Joseph Swan 's incandescent light bulbs.

Determined to bring about the revival of the Hebrew language as a way of unifying Jews, Eliezer Ben-Yehuda has what is believed to be the first conversation in Modern Hebrew, with friends living in Paris.
The Gunfight at the O.K. Corral occurs in Tombstone, Cochise County, Arizona, USA.
Newcastle United F.C. is founded in the northeast of England as Stanley F.C., with a further name change to Newcastle East End F.C. the following year.
The satirical magazine Judge is first published in the United States.
The Mapuche uprising of 1881 begins with an attack on Quillem, Chile.
Brahms' Piano Concerto No. 2 premieres in Budapest with the composer as soloist.
The Clarkson Memorial to an anti-slavery campaigner in Wisbech (England) is completed and unveiled to the public.
A meteorite strikes the Earth near the village of Großliebenthal, a few kilometers southwest of Odesa, Ukraine.
At least 380 die in a fire at the Vienna Ringtheater.
27 – The Warsaw pogrom is carried out in Vistula Land, Russian Empire.
Catholic religious congregation Mothers of the Forsaken and Saint Joseph of the Mountain is founded by Blessed Petra of Saint Joseph.
Meiji Law School, predecessor of Meiji University, is founded in Yurakucho, Tokyo, Japan.
Virgil Earp is ambushed in Tombstone, Arizona, and loses the use of his left arm.
Abilene, Texas, is founded.
Some Vatican archives are opened to scholars for the first time.
The Vocational and Technical College of Tokyo, later Tokyo Institute of Technology, is founded in Japan.
Culford School, a public school in Suffolk, England, is founded as the East Anglian School for Boys.
Rafaela, Argentina, is formed.
Leyton Orient F.C. is founded in London.
Kinshasa (the capital of the modern-day Democratic Republic of the Congo) is founded by Henry Morton Stanley as a trading outpost called Léopoldville.
New York City's oldest independent school for girls, the Convent of the Sacred Heart New York (91st Street), is founded.
Hattori Watch Shop (服部時計店) is founded by Kanetarō Hattori in Ginza, Tokyo, Japan, predecessor of watch brand Seiko.
The Pali Text Society is founded by British scholar Thomas William Rhys Davids, for the study of Pali (Ceylonese) texts.
Tokyo Law College, predecessor of Hosei University, is founded in Japan. [ citation needed ]

On the Isle of Man (an internally self-governing dependent territory of the United Kingdom), the House of Keys Election Act extends the franchise for the national legislature to spinsters and widows owning real estate of a certain value.
Irish-born author Oscar Wilde arrives in New York at the beginning of a lecture tour of the United States and Canada.
The Standard Oil Trust is secretly created in the United States to control multiple corporations set up by John D. Rockefeller and his associates.
Charles J. Guiteau is found guilty of the assassination of James A. Garfield (President of the United States) and sentenced to death, despite an insanity defense raised by his lawyer.
Holborn Viaduct power station in the City of London, the world's first coal-fired public electricity generating station, begins operation.
American showman P. T. Barnum acquires the elephant Jumbo from the London Zoo.
Roderick Maclean fails in an attempt to assassinate Queen Victoria, at Windsor.
The Principality of Serbia becomes the Kingdom of Serbia following a proclamation.
British gunboats enter Monrovia, with Arthur Havelock demanding that Liberia cede disputed territory to the British colony of Sierra Leone, of which he is Governor.
Polygamy is made a felony by the Edmunds Act, passed by the United States Congress.
Robert Koch announces the discovery of the bacterium responsible for tuberculosis (Mycobacterium tuberculosis).
Republican Jules Ferry makes primary education in France free, non-clerical (laique) and obligatory.
German medical products company Beiersdorf is founded.
The Knights of Columbus, a Catholic fraternal service organization, is founded in New Haven, Connecticut.
Old West outlaw Jesse James is shot in the back of the head and killed by Robert Ford in St. Joseph, Missouri.
The Elektromote, the world's first trolleybus, begins operation in Berlin.
The Berlin Philharmonic orchestra is founded in Germany, as Frühere Bilsesche Kapelle.
Édouard Manet exhibits his painting A Bar at the Folies-Bergère at the Paris Salon.

The Kilmainham Treaty, an agreement between the British government and Irish nationalist leader Charles Stewart Parnell to abate tenant rent arrears, is announced; Parnell is released from Kilmainham Gaol in Dublin.

Phoenix Park Murders in Ireland: Lord Frederick Cavendish, the newly appointed Chief Secretary for Ireland, and Thomas Henry Burke, his Permanent Undersecretary, are fatally stabbed in Phoenix Park, Dublin, by members of the Irish National Invincibles (militant Irish republicans).
The Chinese Exclusion Act is the first law which restricts immigration into the United States.
Burnley F.C. in Northern England changes codes, from rugby football to association football.
The Triple Alliance is formed between Germany, Austria-Hungary and Italy.
Battle of Embabo: The Shewan forces of Menelik II defeat the Gojjame army.
Supposedly, the Bombay Cyclone of 1882 in the Arabian Sea causes flooding in Bombay harbor, leaving about 100,000 dead; this alleged event has, however, been proved a hoax.
The 'Urabi revolt breaks out in Egypt against Khedive Tewfik Pasha and European influence in that country.
The Anglo-French Convention of 1882 is signed, marking territorial boundaries between Guinea and Sierra Leone.
U.S. presidential assassin Charles J. Guiteau is hanged in Washington, D.C.
13 – Anglo-Egyptian War: The British Mediterranean Fleet carries out the Bombardment of Alexandria, its forces capturing the city of Alexandria, Egypt, and securing the Suez Canal.
The Imo Incident occurs in Seoul, Korea, as a result of bad rations and late payment for soldiers of the Joseon Army.
Boers establish the republic of Stellaland in southern Africa.
Richard Wagner 's opera Parsifal debuts, at the Bayreuth Festspielhaus in Bavaria.
The Hebrew Moshava of Rishon LeZion in Palestine is founded.
The U.S. Congress passes the 1882 Immigration Act.
Standard Oil of New Jersey, the company later known as ExxonMobil, is established.
The Married Women's Property Act 1882 receives royal assent in Britain; it enables women to buy, own and sell property, and to keep their own earnings.
Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky 's 1812 Overture debuts in Moscow.
The Australian cricket team historically defeats England at The Oval for the first time on English soil, a humiliation for the English and the origin for the Ashes test series.

Thomas Edison flips the switch to the first commercial electrical power plant in the United States, lighting one square mile of lower Manhattan. This is considered by many as the day that begins the electrical age.
The first United States Labor Day parade is held in New York City.
Tottenham Hotspur F.C. is founded (as Hotspur F.C.) in London.
Anglo-Egyptian War: British troops occupy Cairo, and Egypt becomes a British protectorate.
Selwyn College, Cambridge, is founded after Queen Victoria grants a Charter of Incorporation.

Great Comet of 1882: Her Majesty's Astronomer at the Cape, David Gill, reports watching the comet rise a few minutes before the Sun, describing it as "The nucleus was then undoubtedly single, and certainly rather under than over 4″ in diameter; in fact, as I have described it, it resembled very much a star of the 1st magnitude seen by daylight."
The Society for Ethical Culture of Chicago (the modern-day Ethical Humanist Society of Chicago) is founded by Felix Adler.
The Bank of Japan opens in Tokyo City.
The University of the Punjab at Lahore (Undivided India), is founded in modern-day Pakistan.

The New York, Chicago and St. Louis Railroad ("Nickel Plate Road") runs its first trains over the entire system between Buffalo, New York, and Chicago. Nine days later the Seney Syndicate sells the road to William Henry Vanderbilt, for US$7.2 million.
Waseda University is founded by Shigenobu Ōkuma in Japan as Tokyo Specializing School.
The Great Fire of Oulu destroys 27 buildings in the downtown of Oulu, Finland.
Franklyn Leslie shoots Billy Claiborne dead in the streets of Tombstone, Arizona.
The British Royal Navy 's HMS Flirt destroys Abari village in Niger.
Zikhron Ya'akov is founded in northern Israel.
Nikola Tesla claims this is when he conceives the rotating magnetic field principle, which he later uses to invent his induction motor.
Carolyn Merrick is elected president of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union in the United States.
The Personal Liberty League is established to oppose the temperance movement in the United States.
Redruth Mining School opens in Cornwall.
The British Chartered Institute of Patent Agents (the modern-day Chartered Institute of Patent Attorneys) is founded.
Zulu king Cetshwayo kaMpande returns to South Africa from England.
The first International Polar Year, an international scientific program, begins.
A transit of Venus, the last until 2004, occurs.
Pogroms in Southern Russia end.
A peace treaty is signed between Paraguay and Uruguay.
Life magazine is founded in Los Angeles, California, United States.
A fire at the Newhall Hotel in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, United States, kills 73 people.
The Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act, establishing the United States civil service, is passed.
The first electric lighting system employing overhead wires begins service in Roselle, New Jersey, United States, installed by Thomas Edison.
The Adventures of Pinocchio by Carlo Collodi is first published complete in book form, in Italy.
Tokyo Electrical Lightning Grid, predecessor of Tokyo Electrical Power (TEPCO), one of the largest electrical grids in Asia and the world, is founded in Japan.
The Ladies' Home Journal is published for the first time, in the United States.
Alabama becomes the first U.S. state to enact an antitrust law.
The first vaudeville theater is opened, in Boston, Massachusetts.
The Hong Kong Observatory is established.
The Paris Convention for the Protection of Industrial Property is held.
Battle of Gia Cuc: A French force defeats the Vietnamese in northern Vietnam in the run-up to the Sino-French War.
Oxygen is liquefied for the first time.
The first rugby sevens tournament is played at Melrose RFC in Scotland.
1883 eruption of Krakatoa, Indonesia
Robert Louis Stevenson 's children's pirate adventure novel Treasure Island is first published in book format, in London.
Brooklyn Bridge is opened to traffic in New York City, after 13 years of construction.
A rumor that the Brooklyn Bridge is going to collapse causes a stampede, which crushes 12 people.

Count Arvid Posse leaves office as Prime Minister of Sweden. He is succeeded by Carl Johan Thyselius, the first non-aristocrat (Swedish; " ofrälse ") to serve as Swedish head of government, and Prime Minister.
Otto von Bismarck pushes the first social security law through the Reichstag. It establishes a system of Publicly funded health care, one of the first worldwide.
Victoria Hall disaster: A rush for treats results in 183 children being asphyxiated in a concert hall in Sunderland, England.
In Milan, Italy, the first central European electricity power station is inaugurated.

Robert Louis Stevenson 's novel The Black Arrow first appears as a serial in the British magazine Young Folks; A Boys' and Girls' Paper of Instructive and Entertaining Literature as by 'Captain George North'. Stevenson completes writing it at the end of the summer in France.
The SS Daphne sinks on launch in Glasgow, Scotland, leaving 124 dead.
The world's first rodeo is held in Pecos, Texas.
Zulu King Cetshwayo barely escapes a rebel attack with his life.
King William's College is opened on the Isle of Man.
The last quagga dies at the Artis Magistra zoo in Amsterdam.
1883 Rochester tornado: An F5 tornado strikes Rochester, Minnesota, leading to the creation of the Mayo Clinic.
27 – 1883 eruption of Krakatoa: The volcanic island of Krakatoa erupts at 10:02 am (local time); 163 villages are destroyed, 36,417 killed by tsunami.
Dunfermline Carnegie Library, the first Carnegie library, is opened in Andrew Carnegie 's hometown, Dunfermline, Scotland.
Pope Leo XIII publishes the encyclical Supremi apostolatus officio ("On Devotion of the Rosary").
Major Evelyn Baring becomes Consul-General of Egypt under British rule.
The Bombay Natural History Society is founded in India.
The University of Texas at Austin opens to students.

A consortium of flour mill operators in Minneapolis forms the Minneapolis, Sault Ste. Marie and Atlantic Railway, as a means to get their product to the Great Lakes ports, avoiding the high tariffs of Chicago.
In Amsterdam, the first International Colonial and Export Exhibition closes, having had over 1 million visitors.
Sydney Boys High School is founded in Sydney, Australia, the country's first state high school.
The Boys' Brigade (the first uniformed youth organization in existence) is founded in Glasgow, Scotland.

The Orient Express train begins to run through from Paris Gare de l'Est to Giurgiu in Romania, with onward ferry and train connections to Istanbul (the train has been running since June 5 as far as Vienna).

In five Civil Rights Cases the Supreme Court of the United States declares part of the Civil Rights Act of 1875 to be unconstitutional, allowing individuals and corporations to discriminate based on race.
Peru and Chile sign the Treaty of Ancón, by which the Tarapacá province is ceded to Chile, ending Peru's involvement in the War of the Pacific.
The Mödling and Hinterbrühl Tram in Vienna (Austria) is the first electric tram powered by overhead wire.
Cardiff University, Wales, opens (under the name of University College of South Wales and Monmouthshire).

Two Clan na Gael dynamite bombs explode in the London Underground, injuring several people. The next day, British Home Secretary Vernon Harcourt drafts 300 policemen to guard the underground, and introduces the Explosives Bill.
American Old West: Self-described Black Bart the Po-8 makes his last stagecoach robbery, but leaves a handkerchief with a laundry mark that eventually leads to his capture.
The 14th Century AH begins in the Islamic calendar on the 1st of Muharram, 1301 AH.
Chile's National Library of Congress is founded.
U.S. and Canadian railroads institute 5 standard continental time zones, ending the confusion of thousands of local times.
Whitman College is chartered as a 4-year college in Walla Walla, Washington.
Battleford Industrial School, the first government-operated Indian residential school opens in Canada.
Bisbee Massacre: Five people are killed in the robbery of a general store by bandits in Bisbee, Arizona.
Tonkin Campaign: French forces capture the Sơn Tây citadel.
The Royal Canadian Dragoons and The Royal Canadian Regiment, the first Permanent Force cavalry and infantry regiments of the Canadian Army, are formed.
The Harbour Grace Affray takes place in Harbour Grace, Colony of Newfoundland.
Antoni Gaudí begins to work on the Sagrada Família Cathedral in Barcelona (it will be consecrated in 2010).
Construction of Speicherstadt as a free zone in the Port of Hamburg begins.
copper ore at Murray Mine, on the edge of the Sudbury Basin, located near Sudbury, Ontario, Canada.
The British Parliament considers a major bill to allow Indian judges to try Europeans in India. The British community rises in protest, and defeats the measure.

The Mexican government passes a law allowing real estate companies (controlled by General Porfirio Díaz 's political associates) to survey public and "vacant" lands, and to retain one third of the land they survey.
Bernard Kroger establishes the first Kroger grocery store, in Cincinnati, Ohio.
The first purebred Percheron (horse) stud book is created in France.
ASEA is founded by Ludvig Fredholm in Sweden, predecessor of the global electronic equipment and engineering business ABB.
The Fabian Society is founded in London to promote gradualist social progress.
Gilbert and Sullivan 's comic opera Princess Ida, a satire on feminism, premières at the Savoy Theatre, London.
German microbiologist Robert Koch isolates Vibrio cholerae, the cholera bacillus, working in India.

William Price attempts to cremate his dead baby son, Iesu Grist, in Wales. Later tried and acquitted on the grounds that cremation is not contrary to English law, he is thus able to carry out the ceremony (the first in the United Kingdom in modern times) on March 14, setting a legal precedent.
A New English Dictionary on historical principles, part 1 (edited by James A. H. Murray), the first fascicle of what will become The Oxford English Dictionary, is published in England.
Derby County Football Club is founded in England.

The Siege of Khartoum begins in the Sudan as part of the Mahdist War: an Egyptian garrison led by British General Charles Gordon and Sudanese civilians are besieged by Mahdist forces; the city falls on January 26, 1885.

Prince Leopold, the youngest son and eighth child of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert, dies, aged 30 in Cannes (France) following a fall complicated by his haemophilia. His son, Charles Edward, Duke of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha, is born nearly 4 months later.
John Joseph Montgomery conducts the first manned glider flights in the United States near Otay, California.
The Treaty of Valparaiso, an armistice between Chile and Bolivia, ends the War of the Pacific; Bolivia is obliged to cede Antofagasta to Chile, leaving Bolivia as a landlocked country.
Pope Leo XIII publishes the encyclical Humanum genus, denouncing Freemasonry and certain liberal beliefs which he considers to be associated with it.
The Colchester earthquake ("the Great English earthquake") measuring EMS-98 VIII (Heavily damaging) is the UK's most destructive, although no direct fatalities can be confirmed.
A German protectorate is established over South-West Africa.

The eight-hour workday is first proclaimed by the Federation of Organized Trades and Labor Unions in the United States. This date, called May Day or Labour Day, becomes a holiday recognized in almost every industrialized country.
The Panic of 1884 creates a credit shortage that accelerates the current United States economic recession into the Depression of 1882–1885.
Sweden 's Finance Minister Robert Themptander becomes his country's Prime Minister (1884–88).
Angelo Moriondo of Turin is granted a patent for an espresso machine.
The future flag of Estonia is consecrated as the flag of the Estonian Students' Society.
LaMarcus Adna Thompson opens the "Gravity Pleasure Switchback Railway " at Coney Island, New York City.

The Norwegian Association for Women's Rights (Norsk Kvinnesaksforening) is founded. Also this year, the Fredrika Bremer Association (Fredrika Bremer Förbundet) is founded in Sweden for the same purpose.
The first ascent is made of Castle Mountain in the Canadian Rockies, by geologist Arthur Philemon Coleman.
First International Forestry Exhibition opens in Edinburgh, Scotland.

The Dow Jones Transportation Average, consisting of eleven transportation-related companies (nine railroads and two non-rail companies, Western Union and Pacific Mail), is created in the United States. The index is the oldest stock index to remain in use.
Germany takes possession of Togoland.
Nagasaki Shipyard, predecessor of the Japanese aircraft and shipbuilding business Mitsubishi, is founded on the island of Kyushu.
German administration is established in Cameroon.
The first tennis tournaments, held in the grounds of Shrubland Hall, Leamington Spa, England, are recorded in today's Courier.
The cornerstone for the Statue of Liberty is laid on Bedloe's Island in New York Harbor.

An earthquake measuring 5.5 M fa affects a very large portion of the eastern United States. The shock has a maximum Mercalli intensity of VII (Very strong). Chimneys are toppled in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania. Property damage is severe in Jamaica, Queens and Amityville, New York.
The Sino-French War (for control of Tonkin) breaks out (continues to April 1885).
Sino-French War: Battle of Fuzhou – French Admiral Amédée Courbet 's Far East Squadron virtually destroys China's Fujian Fleet.
Staten Island Academy is founded.
The invention of local anesthesia by ophthalmologist Karl Koller is made public at a medical congress in Heidelberg, Germany.
24 (night) – Steamship Arctique runs aground near Cape Virgenes, leading to the discovery of nearby placer gold and beginning the Tierra del Fuego gold rush.
The United States Naval War College is established in Newport, Rhode Island.
The University College of North Wales, Bangor, is founded in the UK.
The International Meridian Conference meeting in Washington, D.C., fixes the Greenwich meridian as the world's prime meridian (voted on October 13).

The " Nine Graces ", nine women who are the first to be awarded degrees from the Royal University of Ireland, become the first women in the United Kingdom to be awarded degrees. They include Alice Oldham, Isabella Mulvany and Charlotte M. Taylor.
Hosay massacre in Trinidad: British colonial authorities fire on Indian indentured labourers marking a religious festival, killing at least 9.
The Irish Gaelic Athletic Association is founded in Thurles, Ireland.
Leicester City F.C. play their first match, as Leicester Fosse Football Club, in England.
Timișoara, Romania, is the first town in Europe with streets illuminated by electric light.
1884 United States presidential election: Democratic governor of New York Grover Cleveland defeats Republican James G. Blaine in a very close contest, to win the first of his non-consecutive terms.
The Berlin Conference, which regulates European colonisation and trade in Africa, begins (ends February 26, 1885).

American Old West: Near Frisco, New Mexico, deputy sheriff Elfego Baca holds off a gang of 80 Texan cowboys, who want to kill him for arresting cowboy Charles McCarthy (the cowboys have been terrorizing the area's Hispanos, and Baca is working against them).
Porfirio Díaz returns as President of Mexico, an office he will hold until 1911.
Tom Dudley and Edwin Stephens are convicted of murder in the survival cannibalism case of R v. Dudley and Stephens in the English courts.
Reformers in Korea who admire the Meiji Restoration in Japan stage the Gapsin Coup, with Japan's help. China intervenes to rescue the king and help suppress the rebels.
The Third Reform Act widens the adult male electorate in the United Kingdom to around 60%.
The Washington Monument is completed in Washington, D.C., becoming the tallest structure in the world at this date.
Mark Twain 's Adventures of Huckleberry Finn is first published, in London.
The World Cotton Centennial world's fair opens in New Orleans.
The first Christian missionary arrives in Korea.
Anton Bruckner 's Symphony No. 7 is premiered in Leipzig, bringing the composer his first great success.
Scottish Plymouth Brethren missionary Frederick Stanley Arnot identifies the source of the Zambezi River, near Kalene Hill.
The Yellow Crane Tower last burns in Wuhan.
Police training schools are established in every prefecture in Japan.
The water hyacinth is introduced in the United States, and quickly becomes an invasive species.
The Stefan–Boltzmann law is reformulated by Ludwig Boltzmann.
Mexican General Manuel Mondragón designs an early form of the Mondragón rifle, the world's first automatic rifle.
Thomas Parker builds a practical production electric car in Wolverhampton (England) using his own specially designed high-capacity rechargeable batteries.
4 – Sino-French War – Battle of Núi Bop: French troops under General Oscar de Négrier defeat a numerically superior Qing Chinese force, in northern Vietnam.
Mahdist War in Sudan – Battle of Abu Klea: British troops defeat Mahdist forces.
American inventor LaMarcus Adna Thompson patents a roller coaster.
Irish rebels damage Westminster Hall and the Tower of London with dynamite.
Mahdist War in Sudan: Troops loyal to Mahdi Muhammad Ahmad conquer Khartoum; British commander Charles George Gordon is killed.
King Leopold II of Belgium establishes the Congo Free State, as a personal possession.
The first Japanese arrive in Hawaii.

Charles Dow publishes the first edition of the Dow Jones Industrial Average. The index stands at a level of 62.76, and represents the dollar average of 14 stocks: 12 railroads and two leading American industries.
The Richmond Football Club is officially formed at the Royal Hotel in the Melbourne suburb of Richmond, Victoria.
United States President Chester A. Arthur dedicates the Washington Monument.
Battle of Đồng Đăng: France gains an important victory over China, in the Tonkin region of modern-day Vietnam.
An English executioner fails after several attempts to hang John Babbacombe Lee, sentenced for the murder of his employer Emma Keyse; Lee's sentence is commuted to life imprisonment.
The final act of the Berlin Conference regulates European colonization and trade, in the scramble for Africa.
February concludes without having a full moon.
A subsidiary of the American Bell Telephone Company, American Telephone and Telegraph (AT&T), is incorporated in New York.
The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Madrid is founded.
Gilbert and Sullivan 's comic opera The Mikado opens, at the Savoy Theatre in London.
First legal cremation in England: widowed painter Jeanette Pickersgill of London, "well known in literary and scientific circles", is cremated by the Cremation Society at Woking, Surrey.
The North-West Rebellion in Canada by the Métis people, led by Louis Riel, begins with the Battle of Duck Lake.
Prussian deportations: The Prussian government, motivated by Otto von Bismarck, expels all ethnic Poles and Jews without German citizenship from Prussia.
The Battle for Kushka triggers the Panjdeh Incident, which nearly gives rise to war between the British Empire and Russian Empire.
The United Kingdom establishes the Bechuanaland Protectorate.
Frog Lake Massacre: Cree warriors led by Wandering Spirit kill 9 settlers at Frog Lake in the Northwest Territories.
Gottlieb Daimler is granted a German patent, for his single-cylinder, water-cooled engine design.
Luton Town Football Club is created by the merger of (Luton) Wanderers F.C. and Luton Excelsior F.C. in England.
Sino-French War: A French victory at Kép causes China to withdraw its forces from Tonkin, in the final engagement of the conflict.
Symphony No. 7 (Dvořák) was premiered at St James's Hall in London.
A bill is signed in the New York State legislature, forming the Niagara Falls State Park.
Good Housekeeping magazine goes on sale for the first time in the United States.
Battle of Cut Knife: Cree and Assiniboine warriors win their largest victory over Canadian forces.
12 – North-West Rebellion – Battle of Batoche: Canadian government forces inflict a decisive defeat on Métis rebels, bringing an end to their part in the rebellion.
After a three-month legislative battle in the Illinois General Assembly, John A. Logan is re-elected to the United States Senate.
The first public train departs Swanage railway station, on the newly built Swanage Railway in England.

Battle of Loon Lake: The Canadian North-West Mounted Police and allies force a party of Plains Cree warriors to surrender in the last skirmish of the North-West Rebellion, and the last battle fought on Canadian soil.
The Statue of Liberty arrives in New York Harbor.
Robert Gascoyne-Cecil, 3rd Marquess of Salisbury, becomes Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
Japan Brewery, predecessor of Kirin Holdings is founded in Yokohama, Japan. [ citation needed ]
Louis Pasteur and Émile Roux successfully test their rabies vaccine. The patient is Joseph Meister, a boy who was bitten by a rabid dog.
Sarah E. Goode is the first African-American woman to apply for and receive a patent, for the invention of the hideaway bed.
The Reservation at Niagara Falls opens, enabling access to all for free. Thomas V. Welch is the first Superintendent of the Park.
BHP (Broken Hill Proprietary), a worldwide mining and natural gas producer is founded in New South Wales, Australia.
The Football Association recognises professional players in England.
Louis Riel 's trial for treason begins in Regina.
S Andromedae, the only supernova seen in the Andromeda Galaxy so far by astronomers, and the first ever noted outside the Milky Way, is discovered.
Gottlieb Daimler is granted a German patent for the Daimler Reitwagen, regarded as the first motorcycle, which he has produced with Wilhelm Maybach.
The Rock Springs massacre occurs in Rock Springs, Wyoming; 150 white miners attack their Chinese coworkers, killing 28, wounding 15, and forcing several hundred more out of town.
Eastern Rumelia declares its union with Bulgaria, completing the unification of Bulgaria.
Saint Thomas Academy is founded in Minnesota.
Arbroath FC defeats Bon Accord FC, 36-0, in the highest score ever in professional football.
A train wreck of the P. T. Barnum Circus kills giant elephant Jumbo, at St. Thomas, Ontario.
The union of Eastern Rumelia with Bulgaria is proclaimed at Plovdiv.
A British force abolishes the Boer republic of Stellaland, and adds it to British Bechuanaland.
Millwall F.C. is founded by workers on the Isle of Dogs in London, as Millwall Rovers.
The city of Fresno, California, is incorporated.
The Georgia Institute of Technology is established in Atlanta as the Georgia School of Technology.
The Third Anglo-Burmese War begins.
Symphony No. 4 (Brahms) is premiered in Meiningen, Germany, with Johannes Brahms himself conducting it.

Canadian Pacific Railway: In Craigellachie, British Columbia, construction ends on a railway extending across Canada. Prime Minister John A. Macdonald considers the project to be vital to Canada, due to the exponentially greater potential for military mobility.
28 – Serbo-Bulgarian War: Serbia declares war against Bulgaria, but is defeated in the Battle of Slivnitsa on November 17 – 19.
Louis Riel, Canadian rebel leader of the Métis, is executed for high treason.
The U.S. Patent Office acknowledges this date as the day Dr Pepper is served for the first time; the exact date of Dr. Pepper's invention is unknown.
John Kemp Starley demonstrates the Rover safety bicycle, regarded as the first practical modern bicycle.
Karl Benz produces the Benz Patent-Motorwagen, regarded as the first automobile (patented and publicly launched the following year).
Camp Dudley, the oldest continually running boys' camp in the United States, is founded.
The Home Insurance Building in Chicago, designed by William Le Baron Jenney, is completed. With ten floors and a fireproof weight-bearing metal frame, it is regarded as the first skyscraper.
Bicycle Playing Cards are first produced.
Chuo Law College, as predecessor of Chuo University, founded in Kanda, Tokyo, Japan. [ page needed ]
The Soldiers' and Sailors' Families Association is established in the United Kingdom, to provide charitable assistance.
Michigan Technological University (originally Michigan Mining School) opens its doors for the first time, in the future Houghton County Fire Hall.
72 Indian lawyers, academics and journalists gather in Bombay to form the Congress Party.
John Ormsby publishes his new English translation of Don Quixote, acclaimed as the most scholarly made up to that time. It will remain in print through the 20th century.
More than 24,000 Christians killed, 225 churches burnt, seventeen orphanages and ten convents destroyed in Cochinchina, now known as Vietnam.
Upper Burma is formally annexed to British Burma, following its conquest in the Third Anglo-Burmese War of November 1885.
9 – Robert Louis Stevenson 's novella Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde is published in New York and London.
A resolution is passed in the German Parliament to condemn the Prussian deportations, the politically motivated mass expulsion of ethnic Poles and Jews from Prussia, initiated by Otto von Bismarck.
Modern field hockey is born with the formation of The Hockey Association in England.
Karl Benz patents the first successful gasoline -driven automobile, the Benz Patent-Motorwagen (built in 1885).
9 – Seattle riot of 1886: Anti-Chinese sentiments result in riots in Seattle, Washington.
The West End Riots following a popular meeting in Trafalgar Square, London.
The first trainload of oranges leaves Los Angeles via the United States transcontinental railroad.
The Anglo-Chinese School is founded by Bishop William Fitzjames Oldham at 70 Amoy Street, Singapore.
The Treaty of Bucharest ends the Serbo-Bulgarian War in the Balkans.
A law establishing the Kiel Canal is adopted in the German Empire.
Carrollton Massacre: 20 African Americans are killed in Mississippi.
Wilhelm Steinitz becomes the first recognized World Chess Champion.
Gottlieb Daimler assembles his first automobile, in Germany.
William Ewart Gladstone introduces the First Irish Home Rule Bill in the Parliament of the United Kingdom; it is defeated on June 8.
The settlement of Vancouver, British Columbia, is incorporated.
The Swedish Dress Reform Society is established.
Father Augustine Tolton, the first Roman Catholic priest from the United States to identify himself publicly as African American, is ordained in Rome.
A general strike begins in the United States, which escalates on May 4 into the Haymarket affair in Chicago, and eventually wins the eight-hour day for workers.
Emile Berliner starts work that leads to the invention of the gramophone.
American pharmacist Dr. John Pemberton invents a carbonated beverage that will be named ' Coca-Cola '.
Portugal and France agree to regulate the borders of their colonies in Guinea.
Santa Clara County v. Southern Pacific Railroad: The U.S. Supreme Court rules that corporations have the same rights as living persons.
Motherwell Football Club is founded in Scotland.
John Pemberton begins to advertise Coca-Cola (in The Atlanta Journal).

U.S. President Grover Cleveland marries Frances Folsom in the White House (Washington, D.C.), becoming the only President of the United States to wed in the executive mansion. She is 27 years his junior.
Uganda Martyrs: Charles Lwanga, 12 other Catholic boys and men, and 9 Anglicans, are burned (and another Catholic speared) to death, at the orders of Kabaka Mwanga II of Buganda in Namugongo.
The Mount Tarawera volcano erupts in New Zealand, resulting in the deaths of over 150 people and the destruction of the famous Pink and White Terraces.
King Ludwig II of Bavaria is detained as part of a deposition, drowning the following day under mysterious circumstances. Six weeks later his unfinished Neuschwanstein Castle is opened to the public.
The Great Vancouver Fire devastates much of Vancouver, British Columbia.
A large log jam forms on the St. Croix River near Taylors Falls, Minnesota
Arturo Toscanini makes his conducting debut, with an Italian opera company visiting Rio de Janeiro.
The Royal Holloway College for women is opened by Queen Victoria, near London, England.
Karl Benz officially unveils the Benz Patent Motorwagen.

American inventor Charles Martin Hall files a patent for his inexpensive method of refining aluminium (discovered on February 23); independently and near-simultaneously discovered in France by Paul Héroult it becomes known as the Hall–Héroult process.
Steve Brodie is reported to have made a jump from the Brooklyn Bridge, a claim subsequently disputed.
Robert Cecil, 3rd Marquess of Salisbury becomes Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
Nagasaki Incident: Chinese troops riot during shore leave in Nagasaki, Japan.
The Christian Union (Church of God) is established in Monroe County, Tennessee
A massive hurricane demolishes the town of Indianola, Texas.
The 7.0 M w Charleston earthquake affects southeastern South Carolina, with a maximum Mercalli intensity of X (Extreme); 60 people are killed, and damage is estimated at $ 5–6 million.
Grasshopper Club Zürich is founded as the first football club in the Swiss city of Zürich by English students.
American Indian Wars: After almost 30 years of fighting, Apache leader Geronimo surrenders, with his last band of warriors, to General Nelson Miles, at Skeleton Canyon in Arizona.
The Berne Convention for the Protection of Literary and Artistic Works is signed.
American physicist William Stanley Jr. patents the first practical alternating current transformer device, the induction coil.
Spain abolishes slavery in Cuba.
The British merchant vessel Normanton sinks off the coast of Japan, triggering the Normanton incident.
U.S. President Grover Cleveland dedicates the Statue of Liberty, a gift from France, in New York Harbor. The ensuing spontaneous celebration in New York City leads to the first ticker tape parade.
The extremely harsh winter of 1886–87 in the United States begins, killing tens of thousands of cattle on the Great Plains of North America.
The biggest Buddhist boys' school in Sri Lanka, Ananda College, is founded in Colombo.
In the British Raj, what will become one of the biggest boys' schools in Pakistan, Aitchison College, Lahore, is founded under the auspices of Sir Charles Umpherston Aitchison.
Heinrich Hertz verifies the existence of electromagnetic waves, at the University of Karlsruhe.
German inventor Friedrich Soennecken first develops the hole puncher, a type of office tool capable of punching small holes in paper.

The Werkstätte für Feinmechanik und Elektrotechnik (Workshop for Fine Mechanics and Electronics) is founded in Baden-Württemberg, Germany by Robert Bosch. The company will later become the home appliance and power tool brand, Robert Bosch GmbH.
The Folies Bergère stages its first revue in Paris.

London Association football club Arsenal, founded as Dial Square by workers at the Royal Arsenal in Woolwich, play their first match (on the Isle of Dogs). The club is renamed Royal Arsenal soon afterwards, supposedly on December 25.
Avon Products, a worldwide cosmetics and household brand is founded in New York City, United States. [ page needed ]
Food product and processing brand Del Monte Foods is founded in California, United States.
Emily Ruete publishes her landmark memoir, Memoirs of an Arabian Princess: An Autobiography.
English adventurer Thomas Stevens concludes the first circumnavigation by bicycle in Yokohama, having set out on his penny-farthing from San Francisco in 1884.
Bedford Rugby Club is formed in England.
The village of Skorenovac is founded in Serbia, mostly by Székely Hungarians.
Yorkshire Tea is established in Harrogate, England.
Scotch whisky distiller William Grant & Sons is founded.
Addis Ababa is founded in the Ethiopian Empire.
Johnson & Johnson, which becomes a multinational brand, begins manufacturing healthcare products in New Jersey, United States.
Louis Pasteur 's anti- rabies treatment is defended in the Académie Nationale de Médecine, by Dr. Joseph Grancher.
The United States Senate allows the United States Navy to lease Pearl Harbor as a naval base.
British emigrant ship Kapunda sinks after a collision off the coast of Brazil, killing 303 with only 16 survivors.
Brisbane receives a one-day rainfall of 465 millimetres (18.3 in) (a record for any Australian capital city).
The Amateur Athletic Union (AAU) is formed in the United States.
Battle of Dogali: Abyssinian troops defeat the Italians.
Construction work begins on the foundations of the Eiffel Tower in Paris, France.
In a snowstorm at Fort Keogh, Montana, the largest snowflakes on record are reported. They are 15 inches (38 cm) wide and 8 inches (20 cm) thick.
The first Groundhog Day is observed in Punxsutawney, Pennsylvania.
The Interstate Commerce Act of 1887, passed by the 49th United States Congress, is signed into law by President Grover Cleveland.
The Giuseppe Verdi opera Otello premieres at La Scala, Milan.
The Dawes Act, or the General Allotment Act, is enacted in the United States.
The French Riviera is hit by a large earthquake, killing around 2,000 along the coast of the Mediterranean.
At the Sydney Cricket Ground, George Lohmann becomes the first bowler to take eight wickets, in a Test innings.
Anne Sullivan begins teaching Helen Keller. March 3: Helen Keller and Sullivan.
North Carolina State University is established, as North Carolina College of Agriculture and Mechanic Arts.
Chester Greenwood patents earmuffs in the United States.
The final of the first All-Ireland Hurling Championship is held.
Argonia, Kansas, elects Susanna M. Salter as the first female mayor in the United States.
The Catholic University of America is founded in Washington, D.C.
Occidental College is founded in Los Angeles, California.
Schnaebele incident: A French/German border incident nearly leads to war between the two countries.
An earthquake hits Sonora, Mexico.
Ricardo Palma founds the Peruvian Academy of Language.
The cornerstone of the new Stanford University, in northern California, is laid (the college opens in 1891).
The Hells Canyon massacre begins: 34 Chinese gold miners are ambushed and murdered in Hells Canyon, Oregon, United States.
Herman Hollerith receives a U.S. patent for his punched card calculator.
The Reinsurance Treaty is closed between Germany and Russia.
Zululand becomes a British colony.
The British Empire celebrates Queen Victoria 's Golden Jubilee, marking the 50th year of her reign.
The Rocky Mountains Park Act becomes law in Canada, creating that nation's first national park, Banff National Park.
Minot, North Dakota, is incorporated as a city.
The United Retail Federation is established in Brisbane, Australia.
James Blyth operates the first working wind turbine at Marykirk, Scotland.
Construction of the iron structure of the Eiffel Tower starts in Paris, France.

King Kalākaua of Hawai'i is forced by anti-monarchists to sign the ' Bayonet Constitution ', stripping the Hawaiian monarchy of much of its authority, as well as disenfranchising most native Hawaiians, all Asians and the poor.
Odense Boldklub, the Danish football team, is founded as the Odense Cricket Club.
Dorr Eugene Felt receives the first U.S. patent for his comptometer.
- 10 Italian workers killed and 6 injured by a train in New Jersey
L. L. Zamenhof publishes " Unua Libro " (Dr. Esperanto's International Language), the first description of Esperanto, the constructed international auxiliary language.
Blackpool F.C. is created in England, U.K.
The earliest constituent of the U.S. National Institutes of Health is established at the Marine Hospital, Staten Island, as the Laboratory of Hygiene.

Hibernian F.C. of Scotland defeats Preston North End F.C. of England to win the 'Championship of the World', after the two teams win the Association football Cup competitions in their respective countries.
The Theatre Royal, Exeter, England, burns down, killing 186 people.
The 1887 Yellow River flood begins in China, killing 900,000 to 2,000,000 people.
The British Empire takes over Balochistan.
Florida A&M University opens in Tallahassee, Florida.
Yamaha Corporation, the global musical instrument and audiovisual brand, is founded as Yamaha Organ Manufacturing in Hamamatsu, Japan.
The Coimbra Academic Association, the students' union of the University of Coimbra in Portugal, is founded.

The Association football club Celtic F.C. is formed in Glasgow, Scotland, by Irish Marist Brother Walfrid, to help alleviate poverty in the city's East End by raising money for his charity, the 'Poor Children's Dinner Table'.
Emile Berliner is granted a U.S. patent for the Berliner Gramophone.
Louis Lingg, sentenced to be hanged for his alleged role in the Haymarket affair (a bombing in Chicago on May 4, 1886), kills himself by dynamite.
August Spies, Albert Parsons, Adolph Fischer and George Engel are hanged for inciting riot and murder in the Haymarket affair.
Bloody Sunday: Police in London clash with radical and Irish nationalist protesters.
Örgryte IS, the Swedish football team is founded by Wilhelm Friberg.
The International Bureau of Intellectual Property is established.
Franz König publishes "Über freie Körper in den Gelenken" in the medical journal Deutsche Zeitschrift für Chirurgie, describing (and naming) the disease Osteochondritis dissecans for the first time.
The first battery rail car is used on the Royal Bavarian State Railways.
Heyl & Patterson Inc., a pioneer in coal unloading equipment, is founded by Edmund W. Heyl and William J. Patterson in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.
American financial services company A. G. Edwards is founded by General Albert Gallatin Edwards in St. Louis, Missouri.
Global construction and real estate development company Skanska is founded in Malmö, Sweden.
Tokyo Fire Insurance, predecessor of Sompo Japan Nipponkoa Insurance, is founded.
Nagase Shoten (長瀬商店), predecessor of Japanese cosmetics and toiletry brand Kao Corporation, is founded in Nihonbashi, Tokyo, Japan. [ citation needed ]
The Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn is founded.
Publication begins of Futabatei Shimei 's The Drifting Cloud (Ukigumo), the first modern novel in Japan.
Publication in Barcelona of Enrique Gaspar 's El anacronópete, the first work of fiction to feature a time machine.
The first English-language edition of Friedrich Engels ' 1844 study of The Condition of the Working Class in England, translated by Florence Kelley, is published in New York City.
Teachers College, later part of Columbia University, is founded.
Taiwan becomes a Chinese province

Heinrich Hertz discovers the photoelectric effect on the production and reception of electromagnetic (EM) waves (radio); this is an important step towards the understanding of the quantum nature of light.
Glenfiddich single malt Scotch whisky is first produced.
Laos and Cambodia are added to French Indochina.
The great telescope (with an objective lens of 91 cm (36 in) diameter) at Lick Observatory in California is first used.
The Schoolhouse Blizzard hits Dakota Territory, the states of Montana, Minnesota, Nebraska, Kansas, and Texas, leaving 235 dead, many of them children on their way home from school.
The National Geographic Society is founded in Washington, D.C.
The Battle of the Grapevine Creek, the last major conflict of the Hatfield-McCoy Feud.
The Amateur Athletic Union is founded by William Buckingham Curtis in the United States.
The Lawn Tennis Association is founded in England.
In West Orange, New Jersey, Thomas Edison meets with Eadweard Muybridge, who proposes a scheme for sound film.
The Agriculture College of Utah (later Utah State University) is founded in Logan, Utah.
Wilhelm I dies, Frederick III becomes German Emperor and King of Prussia.
The Great Blizzard of 1888 begins along the eastern seaboard of the United States, shutting down commerce and killing more than 400.
The summit of Ritter Island collapsed resulting in a tsunami and the deaths of an estimated 500 to 3,500 people.
De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd. is founded in Kimberley.
The Sikkim Expedition, a British military expedition to expel the Tibetans from northern Sikkim, begins.
The foundation stone for a new National Library of Greece is laid in Athens.
The first Romani language operetta premieres in Moscow, Russia.
A meeting called by William McGregor, to discuss establishment of The Football League, is held in London.

Opening of an international Congress for Women's Rights organized by Susan B. Anthony in Washington, D.C., leading to formation of the International Council of Women, a key event in the international women's movement.

London prostitute Emma Elizabeth Smith is brutally attacked by two or three men, dying of her injuries the following day, first of the Whitechapel murders, but probably not a victim of Jack the Ripper.
The Brighton Beach Hotel in Coney Island (New York) is moved 520 ft (160 m), using six steam locomotives, by civil engineer B. C. Miller, to save it from ocean storms.
The first New Year's Day is observed, of the solar calendar adopted by Siamese King Chulalongkorn, with the 106th anniversary of Bangkok 's founding in 1782 as its epoch (reference date).
The Concertgebouw orchestra in Amsterdam is inaugurated.
Kahisakan (可否茶館), the first coffee shop in Japan, opens in Tokyo
The German Empire annexes the island of Nauru.
Westminster School is founded in Simsbury, Connecticut.
The Texas State Capitol building, completed at a cost of $3 million, opens to the public in Austin.
Fort Belknap Indian Reservation is established by the United States Congress.
The International Exhibition of Science, Art and Industry in Kelvingrove Park, Glasgow opens (continues to November).
Nippon Oil Corporation, predecessor of Eneos, a petroleum and gas energy brand in Japan, is founded in Niigata Prefecture.
The North Borneo Chartered Company 's territories (including Sabah) become the British protectorate of North Borneo.
In Brazil, the Lei Áurea abolishes the last remnants of slavery.
The comic novel The Diary of a Nobody by brothers George and Weedon Grossmith begins serialization in Punch (London).
In Glasgow (Scotland), Celtic F.C. plays its first official match, winning 5–2 against Rangers F.C.
Hong Kong's Peak Tram begins operation.
Edward King (bishop of Lincoln) in England is called to account for using ritualistic practices in Anglican worship.
The Kingdom of Sedang is formed, in modern-day Vietnam.
American writer Ernest Thayer 's baseball poem " Casey at the Bat " is first published (under the pen name "Phin") as the last of his humorous contributions to The San Francisco Examiner.
The White Rajahs territories become the British protectorate of Sarawak.
Wilhelm II becomes German Emperor and King of Prussia; 1888 is the Year of the Three Emperors.
In Chicago, the Republican Convention opens at the Auditorium Building. Benjamin Harrison and Levi P. Morton win the nominations for President and Vice President of the United States, respectively.
Handel's Israel in Egypt is recorded onto wax cylinder at The Crystal Palace in London, the earliest known recording of classical music.
The Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom opens its laboratory, on Plymouth Hoe.

27 – London matchgirls strike of 1888: About 200 workers, mainly teenaged girls, strike following the dismissal of three colleagues from the Bryant and May match factory, precipitated by an article on their working conditions published on June 23 by campaigning journalist Annie Besant, and the workers unionise on July 27.
Over 200 miners were killed at a diamond mine in Kimberley, South Africa.
According to Japanese government official confirmed report, A large scale eruption and ash smoke hit around Mount Bandai area, Fukushima Prefecture, Japan, more than 477 people were killed.

Frank Edward McGurrin, a court stenographer from Salt Lake City, Utah, purportedly the only person using touch typing at this time, wins a decisive victory over Louis Traub in a typing contest held in Cincinnati, Ohio. This date can be called the birthday of the touch typing method that is widely used in modern times.
Carl Benz is issued with the world's first driving licence by the Grand Duchy of Baden.

Bertha Benz arrives in Pforzheim having driven 40 miles (64 km) from Mannheim in a car manufactured by her husband Carl Benz, thus completing the first "long-distance" drive in the history of the automobile.
Whitechapel murders: The body of London prostitute Martha Tabram is found, a possible victim of Jack the Ripper.

The Oaths Act permits the oath of allegiance taken to the Sovereign by Members of Parliament (MPs) to be affirmed, rather than sworn to God, thus confirming the ability of atheists to sit in the House of Commons of the United Kingdom.
A fire destroys the Main Building, the heart of Wells College in Aurora, New York, causing a loss of $130,000.
Dr Friedrich Hermann Wölfert ’s motorised airship successfully completes the world’s first engine-driven flight, from Cannstatt to Kornwestheim in Germany.

The Local Government Act, effective from 1889, establishes county councils and county borough councils in England and Wales, redraws some county boundaries, and gives women the vote in local elections. It also declares that "bicycles, tricycles, velocipedes, and other similar machines" be carriages within the meaning of the Highway Acts (which remains the case), and requires that they give audible warning when overtaking "any cart or carriage, or any horse, mule, or other beast of burden, or any foot passenger", a rule abolished in 1930.
A mutiny at Dufile, Equatoria, results in the imprisonment of the Emin Pasha.
Earliest evidence of a death and injury by a meteorite in Sulaymaniyah, Iraq.
–The first trams in Tallinn (Reval), horsecars, begin operation.
Whitechapel murders: The mutilated body of London prostitute Mary Ann Nichols is found; she is considered the first victim of Jack the Ripper.
In the United States, George Eastman registers the trademark Kodak, and receives a patent for his camera, which uses roll film.
Mohandas Gandhi embarks on the S.S. Clyde from Bombay for London.

Charles Turner becomes the first bowler in cricket to take 250 wickets in an English season – a feat since accomplished only by Tom Richardson (twice), J. T. Hearne, Wilfred Rhodes (twice) and Tich Freeman (six times).
Whitechapel murders: The mutilated body of London prostitute Annie Chapman is found (considered to be the second victim of Jack the Ripper).
The Great Herding (Spanish: El Gran Arreo) begins with thousands of sheep being herded from the Argentine outpost of Fortín Conesa to Santa Cruz near the Strait of Magellan.
In England, the first six Football League matches are played.
In a letter accepting renomination as President of the United States, Grover Cleveland declares the Chinese "impossible of assimilation with our people and dangerous to our peace and welfare".
Las Cruces College (later New Mexico State University) is founded in Las Cruces, New Mexico.
Whitechapel murders: The ' Dear Boss letter ' signed " Jack the Ripper ", the first time the name is used, is received by London's Central News Agency.
Stanley Park is officially opened by Vancouver (B.C.) mayor David Oppenheimer.

Whitechapel murders: The bodies of London prostitutes Elizabeth Stride and Catherine Eddowes, the latter mutilated, are found. They are generally considered Jack the Ripper 's third and fourth victims, respectively.
Sofia University officially opens, becoming the first university in liberated Bulgaria.
The Whitehall Mystery: Dismembered remains of a woman's body are discovered at three central London locations, one being the construction site of the police headquarters at New Scotland Yard.
The Washington Monument officially opens to the general public in Washington, D.C. October 9: Washington Monument opens.

Battle of Guté Dili: Seeking to extend Mahdist control over what is now southwestern Ethiopia, governor Khalil al-Khuzani is routed by an alliance of Shewan forces, under Ras Gobana Dacche and Moroda Bekere, ruler of Leqa Naqamte. Only a handful, including Khalil, barely manage to flee the battlefield.

Louis Le Prince films the first motion picture: Roundhay Garden Scene in Roundhay, Leeds, West Yorkshire, England, two seconds and 18 frames in length (followed by his movie Leeds Bridge and Accordion Player).
St Cuthbert's Society at the University of Durham in England is founded, after a general meeting chaired by the Reverend Hastings Rashdall.

The Rudd Concession, a written concession for exclusive mining rights in Matabeleland, Mashonaland and adjoining territories, is granted by King Lobengula of Matabeleland to Charles Rudd, James Rochfort Maguire and Francis Thompson, who are acting on behalf of South African-based politician and businessman Cecil Rhodes, providing a basis for white settlement of Rhodesia.

1888 United States presidential election: Democratic Party incumbent Grover Cleveland wins the popular vote, but loses the Electoral College vote to Republican challenger Benjamin Harrison, therefore losing the election.
Joseph Assheton Fincher files a patent in the United Kingdom for the parlour game which he calls " Tiddledy-Winks ".

Whitechapel murders: The mutilated body of London prostitute Mary Jane Kelly is found. She is considered to be the fifth, and last, of Jack the Ripper 's victims. A number of similar murders in England follow, but the police attribute them to copy-cat killers.
First signs of famine in Ethiopia, caused by drought combined with early spread of the 1890s African rinderpest epizootic.
The first Saint Verhaegen takes place in Brussels.
International sorority Delta Delta Delta is founded at Boston University in the United States.
The celebration of Thanksgiving (United States) and the first day of Hanukkah coincide.
John Boyd Dunlop patents the pneumatic bicycle tyre in the United Kingdom.
The Lyric Theatre, London opens.
Richard Wetherill and his brother-in-law, Charlie Mason, discover the Indian ruins of Mesa Verde in southwestern Colorado.

During a bout of mental illness (and having quarreled with his friend Paul Gauguin), Dutch painter Vincent van Gogh infamously cuts off the lower part of his own left ear, taking it to a brothel, and is removed to the local hospital in Arles.
Katz's Delicatessen is founded in the Lower East Side of Manhattan.
Letitia Alice Walkington became the first woman in the United Kingdom to receive a degree of Bachelor of Laws, from the Royal University of Ireland at Queen's College, Belfast.
The Baldwin School is founded in Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania, as "Miss [Florence] Baldwin's School for Girls, Preparatory for Bryn Mawr College ".
The Finnish epic Kalevala is published for the first time in the English language, by American linguist John Martin Crawford.
First British rugby union tour of Australia and New Zealand.
The Camborne School of Mines is founded in Cornwall, England.
The dolphin Pelorus Jack is first sighted in Cook Strait, New Zealand.
In Poland, Schiffers & Co. is founded in Warsaw.
In Germany, 1888 is known as the Year of the Three Emperors.
John Robert Gregg first publishes Gregg shorthand in the United States.
The total solar eclipse of January 1, 1889 is seen over parts of California and Nevada.
Paiute spiritual leader Wovoka experiences a vision, leading to the start of the Ghost Dance movement in the Dakotas.

An Act to Regulate Appointments in the Marine Hospital Service of the United States is signed by President Grover Cleveland. It establishes a Commissioned Corps of officers, as a predecessor to the modern-day U.S. Public Health Service Commissioned Corps.
Preston North End F.C. is declared the winner of the inaugural Football League in England.
Herman Hollerith receives a patent for his electric tabulating machine in the United States.
The Coca-Cola Company is originally incorporated as the Pemberton Medicine Company in Atlanta, Georgia.
Columbia Phonograph is formed in Washington, D.C.
Rudolf, Crown Prince of Austria and his mistress Baroness Mary Vetsera commit a double suicide (or a murder-suicide) in the Mayerling hunting lodge.
The Meiji Constitution of Japan is adopted; the 1st Diet of Japan convenes in 1890.
The first issue of La Solidaridad is published in Spain.
President Grover Cleveland signs a bill admitting North Dakota, South Dakota, Montana and Washington as U.S. states.

Battle of Metemma: Yohannes IV, Emperor of Ethiopia, is killed; Sudanese forces, who have been almost defeated, rally and destroy the Ethiopian army. Yohannes is probably the world's last ruler ever to die in battle; on March 25 Menelik II proclaims himself as his successor.
The North Carolina Legislature issues a charter for the creation of Elon College.
Samoan crisis: German and American warships keep each other at bay in a standoff in Apia Harbor, ending when a cyclone blows in and sinks them all.
English Association football team Sheffield United F.C. is formed at the Adelphi Hotel, Sheffield.
Claiming to be the Promised Messiah and Mahdi, Mirza Ghulam Ahmad founds the Ahmadiyya Muslim community in Punjab Province (British India).

The Eiffel Tower is inaugurated in Paris (opens May 6). At 300 m (980 ft), its height exceeds the previous tallest structure in the world by 130 m (430 ft). Contemporary critics regard it as aesthetically displeasing.
Following a failed attempt at a coup, French defense minister Georges Boulanger is forced to flee the country.
The Hammarby Roddförening (later Hammarby IF) sports club is founded in Sweden.
Birth of Adolf Hitler in Austria-Hungary.
1889–1890 pandemic of influenza first reported in the city of Bukhara in the Central Asian part of the Russian Empire.
At high noon in Oklahoma Territory, thousands rush to claim land in the Land Rush of 1889. Within hours the cities of Oklahoma City and Guthrie are formed, with populations of at least 10,000.
Menelik II, Emperor of Ethiopia, signs a treaty of amity with Italy, giving Italy control over what will become Eritrea.
The Exposition Universelle opens in Paris, with the Eiffel Tower as its entrance arch. The Galerie des machines, at 111 m (364 ft), spans the longest interior space in the world at this time.
Wham Paymaster robbery: An attack upon a U.S. Army paymaster and escort in the Arizona Territory results in the theft of over $28,000, and the award of two Medals of Honor.
Rubber tire company Michelin is registered by Édouard and André Michelin in Clermont-Ferrand, France.
Johnstown Flood: The South Fork Dam collapses in western Pennsylvania, killing more than 2,200 people in and around Johnstown, Pennsylvania.
The Naval Defence Act dictates that the fleet strength of the British Royal Navy must be equal to that of at least any two other countries.
Vincent van Gogh paints The Starry Night at Saint-Rémy-de-Provence.
The first long distance electric power transmission line in the United States is completed, running 14 miles (23 km) between a generator at Willamette Falls and downtown Portland, Oregon.
The Great Seattle Fire ravages through the downtown area without any fatalities.
