The Armagh rail disaster near Armagh in Ireland kills 80 people.
A Neapolitan baker named Raffaele Esposito invents the Pizza Margherita, named after the queen consort of Italy Margherita of Savoy. This is the forerunner of the modern pizza.
Bangui is founded in the French Congo.
The annular solar eclipse of June 28, 1889 is visible in Atlantic Ocean, Africa and Indian Ocean, and is the 47th solar eclipse of Solar Saros 125.
30 – First Inter-Parliamentary Conference held.
The first issue of The Wall Street Journal is published in New York City.

The last official bare-knuckle boxing title fight is held (under London Prize Ring Rules): Heavyweight Champion John L. Sullivan, the Boston Strong Boy, defeats Jake Kilrain in a world championship bout, lasting 75 rounds, in Mississippi.
International Workers Congresses of Paris open, and establish the Second International.
The Emperor of Brazil, Pedro II, survives an assassination attempt in Rio de Janeiro.
Louise, Princess Royal of the United Kingdom, marries Alexander Duff, 1st Duke of Fife.
Mahdist War: Battle of Toski – Egyptian and British troops are victorious.
The Great Fire of Spokane, Washington destroys some 32 blocks of the city, prompting a mass rebuilding project.
The Savoy Hotel in London opens.

At the Vienna Hofburg, the grand opening ceremony is held for the Imperial Natural History Museum (German: K.k. Naturhistorisches Hofmuseum), begun in 1871; from August 13 to the end of December, the museum counts 175,000 visitors.

September 15 – London Dock Strike: Dockers strike for a minimum wage of sixpence an hour (The dockers' tanner), which they eventually receive (a landmark in the development of New Unionism in Britain).

The Prevention of Cruelty to, and Protection of, Children Act, commonly known as the Children's Charter, is passed in the United Kingdom; for the first time it imposes criminal penalties to deter child abuse.
The Royal Mail Mount Pleasant Sorting Office officially opens in London.
The Jewish settlement of Moisés Ville is founded in Argentina.
Albert Honoré Charles Grimaldi becomes Albert I, Prince of Monaco.
Civil War veteran Charles Jefferson Wright founds New York Military Academy, with 75 students on 30 acres (120,000 m 2) of land in Cornwall, New York.
The Nintendo Koppai (Later Nintendo Company, Limited) is founded in Japan by Fusajiro Yamauchi, to produce and market Hanafuda playing cards.
In Washington, D.C., the first International Conference of American States begins.
Mount Kilimanjaro 's summit is first reached, by German geologist Hans Meyer with Austrian mountaineer Ludwig Purtscheller.
The Moulin Rouge cabaret opens in Paris.
Gustaf Åkerhielm, previously Swedish Foreign Minister, replaces Gillis Bildt as Prime Minister of Sweden.

Helmuth von Moltke the Elder is recorded by Adelbert Theodor Wangemann, a German associate of Thomas Edison, on wax cylinders via phonograph. The two surviving wax cylinders that were produced make von Moltke, who was born in 1800, the earliest-living human whose voice was recorded, and the only human born in the 18th century whose voice can be heard in the present day.
Sir Henry Parkes, Premier of New South Wales, delivers the Tenterfield Oration, calling for the Federation of Australia.
The British South Africa Company receives a Royal Charter.
The first free elections are held in Costa Rica.
North Dakota and South Dakota are admitted as the 39th and 40th U.S. states, respectively.
English Association football team Wimbledon F.C. plays their first match.
Montana is admitted as the 41st U.S. state.
Washington is admitted as the 42nd U.S. state.

Inspired by Jules Verne, pioneer American woman journalist Nellie Bly (Elizabeth Cochrane) begins an attempt to beat travel around the world in less than 80 days (Bly finishes the journey in 72 days, 6 hours and 11 minutes).

Field Marshal Deodoro da Fonseca organizes a military coup, which deposes Emperor Pedro II of Brazil and abolishes the Brazilian monarchy. Deodoro da Fonseca proclaims Brazil a republic, and forms a provisional government.
The Brazilian Imperial Family is forced into exile in France.
The modern-day flag of Brazil is adopted by the Provisional Government of the Republic.
Argentina is the first country to recognize the abolition of the monarchy in Brazil.
Gustav Mahler premieres his Symphony No. 1, in Budapest.
The first jukebox goes into operation, at the Palais Royale Saloon in San Francisco.
Clemson University is founded in Clemson, South Carolina.
Wofford and Furman play the first intercollegiate football game, in the state of South Carolina.
The Spanish football team Recreativo de Huelva is formed (the oldest club in Spain by the 21st century).
The first interurban tram-train to emerge in the United States is the Newark and Granville Street Railway in Ohio.

The Wisden Cricketers' Almanack publishes its first Wisden Cricketers of the Year (actually titled Six Great Bowlers of the Year). The cricketers chosen are George Lohmann, Bobby Peel, Johnny Briggs, Charles Turner, John Ferris and Sammy Woods.

An early method of high-voltage direct current (HVDC) transmission, as developed by the Swiss engineer René Thury, is implemented commercially in Italy by the Acquedotto de Ferrari-Galliera Company. This system transmits 630 kW at 14 kV DC over a distance of 120 km (75 mi).
Frederick Abel invents cordite.
The Capilano Suspension Bridge (the longest suspension foot-bridge in the world) is opened in British Columbia.
Yellow fever interrupts the building of the Panama Canal.
A huge locust swarm crosses the Red Sea and destroys crops in the Nile Valley.
Abdul Hamid II introduce the anti-slave trade law of Kanunname of 1889.
The Kingdom of Italy establishes Eritrea as its colony in the Horn of Africa.
Alice Sanger becomes the first female staffer in the White House.
1890 British Ultimatum: The United Kingdom demands Portugal withdraw its forces from the land between the Portuguese colonies of Mozambique and Angola (most of present-day Zimbabwe and Zambia).
Ballet The Sleeping Beauty, with music by Tchaikovsky, is premiered at the Imperial Mariinsky Theatre in St. Petersburg, Russia.
American journalist Nellie Bly completes her round-the-world journey in 72 days.
The United Mine Workers of America is founded.
The worldwide insurance and financial service brand Allianz is founded in Berlin, Germany.
The National American Woman Suffrage Association (NAWSA) is founded by Elizabeth Cady Stanton and Susan B. Anthony.
Chicago is selected to host the Columbian Exposition.
The first American football game in Ohio State University history is played in Delaware, Ohio, against Ohio Wesleyan
The Forth Bridge, the longest bridge in Great Britain, on the Firth of Forth in Scotland, is opened to rail traffic.
North Dakota State University is founded in Fargo.
The first railway in Transvaal, the Randtram, opens between Boksburg and Braamfontein in Johannesburg.
middle Mississippi Valley tornado outbreak: 24 significant tornadoes are spawned by one system, including one that kills 76 people in Louisville, Kentucky.
Kaiser Wilhelm II forces Otto von Bismarck to resign as Chancellor of Germany.
Preston North End retain the English Football League Championship, winning their final game at Notts County
Washington State University is founded in Pullman.
Kashihara Shrine, a landmark spot in Nara Prefecture, Japan, is officially built by Emperor Mutsuhito (Emperor of Meiji).
At the First International Conference of American States, in Washington D.C., The Commercial Bureau of the American Republics is founded.
A coordinated series of mass rallies and one-day strikes is held throughout many cities and mining towns in Europe and North America, to demand an eight-hour workday.
President Benjamin Harrison signs the Oklahoma Organic Act, under which Oklahoma Territory is organized, a prerequisite for later statehood.
The first ever official English County Championship cricket match begins in Bristol; Yorkshire beats Gloucestershire, by eight wickets.
Dutch artist Vincent van Gogh moves to Auvers-sur-Oise on the edge of Paris, in the care of Paul Gachet, where he will produce around seventy paintings in as many days.
The five-story skylight Arcade opens in Cleveland, Ohio.
The Ulm Minister opens in Ulm, Germany as the world's tallest cathedral.

The United States Census Bureau begins using Herman Hollerith 's tabulating machine to tabulate census returns using punched card input, a landmark in the history of computing hardware. Hollerith's company eventually becomes IBM. The 1890 United States census determines the US population to be 62,979,766, an increase of 25.5 percent relative to the 1880 census.

Royal Dutch Petroleum, predecessor of Royal Dutch Shell, the major worldwide energy production and sales company, is founded in the Netherlands to develop an oilfield in Pangkalan Brandan, North Sumatra.
The Picture of Dorian Gray (by Oscar Wilde) is published by Philadelphia-based Lippincott's Monthly Magazine (dated July).
Canadian-born boxer George Dixon defeats the British bantamweight champion in London, giving him claim to be the first black world champion in any sport.

Heligoland–Zanzibar Treaty: Britain cedes the Heligoland islands (in the German Bight) to Germany, in return for protectorates over Wituland and the Sultanate of Zanzibar (the islands of Pemba and Unguja) in east Africa.

1890 Japanese general election: In the first general election for the House of Representatives of Japan, about 5% of the adult male population elect a lower house of the Diet of Japan, in accordance with the new Meiji Constitution of 1889.
The Ouija board is first released by Elijah Bond.
The Sherman Antitrust Act and Sherman Silver Purchase Act become United States law.
Idaho is admitted as the 43rd U.S. state.
Wyoming is admitted as the 44th U.S. state.
In Minnesota, storms result in the Sea Wing disaster on Lake Pepin, killing 98.
In Buenos Aires, the Revolution of the Park takes place, forcing President Juárez Celman 's resignation.
Death of Vincent van Gogh: van Gogh shoots himself, dying two days later.
At Auburn Prison in New York, William Kemmler becomes the first person to be executed in the electric chair.
Treaty of London: Portugal and the United Kingdom define the borders of the Portuguese colonies of Mozambique and Angola.
The BOVESPA stock exchange is founded in São Paulo, Brazil.
Kaiser Wilhelm II and Tsar Alexander III meet at Narva.
Dublin association football club Bohemian F.C. is founded in the Gate Lodge, Phoenix Park.
Salisbury, Rhodesia, is founded.
The University of North Texas is founded, as the Texas Normal College and Teacher Training Institute.
— President Wilford Woodruff of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints issues the 1890 Manifesto ending the official practice of polygamy.
The Yosemite National Park is established in California.

The first brief flight of Clément Ader 's steam-powered fixed-wing aircraft Ader Éole takes place in Satory, France. It flies uncontrolled approximately 50 m (160 ft) at a height of 20 cm (7.9 in), the first take-off of a powered airplane solely under its own power.
In Washington, D.C., the Daughters of the American Revolution is founded.
The Uddevalla Suffrage Association is founded in Sweden, with a formal founding event on November 2 a month later.
The Delta Chi fraternity is founded by 11 law students at Cornell University in Ithaca, New York.
The first deep level London Underground (Tube) Railway, the City and South London Railway, opens officially.
Edward King, Anglican bishop of Lincoln, is convicted of using ritualistic practices.

King William III of the Netherlands dies without a male heir, and his daughter Princess Wilhelmina becomes Queen, causing the end of the personal union of thrones with Luxembourg (which requires a male heir) so that Adolphe, Duke of Nassau becomes Grand Duke of Luxembourg.
At West Point, New York, the United States Navy defeats the United States Army 24–0 in the first Army–Navy Game of college football.
Scotland Yard, headquarters of the Metropolitan Police Service, moves to a building on London's Victoria Embankment, as New Scotland Yard.
The Meiji Constitution goes into effect in Japan, and its first Diet convenes.
The New York World Building is completed in New York City, the tallest building in the United States for 10 years at a height of 110 meters.
Hunkpapa Lakota leader Sitting Bull is killed by police on Standing Rock Indian Reservation.
The Oklahoma territorial legislature establishes three institutions of higher learning University of Oklahoma, Oklahoma State University, and University of Central Oklahoma.
High School Cadets is written by John Philip Sousa.
Blackwall Buildings, Whitechapel, noted philanthropic housing, is built in the East End of London.

Wounded Knee Massacre: At Wounded Knee, South Dakota, a Lakota camp, the U.S. 7th Cavalry Regiment tries to disperse the non-violent "Ghost-Dance" which was promised to usher in a new era of power and freedom to Native Americans but is feared as a potential rallying tool for violent rebellion by some in the U.S. government. Shooting begins, and 153 Lakota Sioux and 25 troops are killed; about 150 flee the scene. This is the last tribe to be defeated and confined to a reservation as well as the beginning of the decline of both the American Indian Wars and the American frontier.
The folding carton box is invented by Robert Gair, a Brooklyn printer who developed production of paper-board boxes in 1879.
Brown trout are introduced into the upper Firehole River, in Yellowstone National Park.
The United States city of Boise, Idaho, drills the first geothermal well.

English archaeologist Flinders Petrie excavates at Tell el-Hesi, Palestine (mistakenly identified as Tel Lachish), the first scientific excavation of an archaeological site in the Holy Land, during which he discovers how tells are formed.
William II of Prussia opposes Bismarck's attempt to renew the law outlawing the Social Democratic Party.
Emerson Electric, an American electronics industry giant, is founded in Missouri.
American geostrategist Alfred Thayer Mahan publishes his influential book The Influence of Sea Power upon History, 1660–1783.
Francis Galton announces a statistical demonstration of the uniqueness and classifiability of individual human fingerprints.
Japanese tractor and iron pipe brand, Kubota founded in Osaka, Japan.
A strike of 500 Hungarian steel workers occurs; 3,000 men are out of work as a consequence.
Germany takes formal possession of its new African territories.
The Earl of Zetland issues a declaration regarding the famine in the western counties of Ireland.
A fight between railway strikers and police breaks out at Motherwell, Scotland.
A fight between the United States and Lakotas breaks out near Pine Ridge agency.
The Australian shearers' strike, that leads indirectly to the foundation of the Australian Labor Party, begins.
General Miles' forces surround the Lakota in the Pine Ridge Reservation.
The great shoe strike in Rochester, New York is called off.
in France, the Irish Nationalist leaders hold a conference at Boulogne. The French government promptly takes loan.
3,000 Lakotas approach Pine Ridge with a view to surrender.
Mahoning Valley, Ohio, sixteen blast furnaces shut down, putting 10,000 men out of work.
Canada brings suit before the United States Supreme Court in re-seizures of vessels in the Bering Sea.
St. Mary's Cathedral dedicated in San Francisco.
Conference of Lakota chiefs with General Miles at Pine Ridge Reservation, the Lakota agree to surrender.
Scottish railway strikers attempt to wreck a train near Greenock, Scotland.
The Chilean Civil War of 1891 breaks out.
A British squadron ordered to Chile.
General Miles officially announces the end of the native outbreak and congratulates his troops.
Jim Hogg becomes the first native Texan to be governor of that state.
May 2 – The Jamaica International Exhibition is held.
Liliuokalani is proclaimed Queen of Hawaii.
The Portuguese republican revolution breaks out, in the northern city of Porto.
The Tobacco Protest begins in Iran.

In the FA Cup quarter final in English Association football, a goal is deliberately stopped by handball on the goal line. An indirect free kick is awarded, since the penalty kick, proposed the previous year by William McCrum, has not yet been implemented. This event probably changes public opinion on the penalty kick, seen previously as an Irishman's motion.
Allmänna Idrottsklubben (AIK) sports club is founded in Stockholm, Sweden.
Springhill, Nova Scotia suffers a serious mining disaster.
The International Copyright Act of 1891 is passed, by the 51st United States Congress.
1st Prime Minister of Canada Sir John A. Macdonald wins a 4th consecutive parliamentary victory over the Liberal Party.

12 – The Great Blizzard of 1891 in the south and west of England leads to extensive snow drifts and powerful storms off the south coast, with 14 ships sunk, and approximately 220 deaths attributed to the weather conditions.
Djurgårdens IF (DIF) sports club is founded in Stockholm.
In New Orleans, a lynch mob storms the Old Parish Prison, and lynches 11 Italians arrested but found innocent of the murder of Police Chief David Hennessy.
The British steamship SS Utopia, carrying Italian migrants to New York, sinks in the inner harbor of Gibraltar after collision with the battleship HMS Anson, killing 564.
The London–Paris telephone system officially opens.
The Wrigley Company is founded in Chicago.
The London–Paris telephone system is opened to the general public.
Census in the United Kingdom: 15.6 million people live in cities of 20,000 or more in England and Wales, and cities of 20,000 or more account for 54% of the total English population.
The first official game in the Association football league of Argentina (1891 Argentine Primera División) is held in Caballito, Buenos Aires.
Chilean Civil War of 1891: Chilean ironclad Blanco Encalada is sunk at the Battle of Caldera Bay by torpedo boats. This is the first ironclad warship lost to a self-propelled torpedo.
Mirza Ghulam Ahmad claims to be the Promised Messiah (the second coming of Jesus) and the Mahdi awaited in Islam.
The first Fascio dei lavoratori (Workers League) is founded by Giuseppe De Felice Giuffrida in Catania, Sicily.
Troops fire on a workers' May Day demonstration in support of the 8-hour workday in Fourmies, France, killing 9 and wounding 30.
The Music Hall in New York (later known as Carnegie Hall) has its grand opening and first public performance, with Peter Tchaikovsky as guest conductor.
Ōtsu incident: Tsesarevich Nikolay Alexandrovich (the future Czar Nicholas II) of Russia survives an assassination attempt while visiting Japan.
Pope Leo XIII issues the encyclical Rerum novarum, on the rights and duties of capital and labor, resulting in the creation of many Christian Democrat parties throughout Europe.
Thomas Edison 's prototype kinetoscope is first displayed at Edison's Laboratory, for a convention of the National Federation of Women's Clubs.

In the Kuperovskaya district of Vladivostok, a grand ceremonial inauguration of construction work on the Trans-Siberian Railway is carried out by the Tsesarevich Nikolay Alexandrovich, and a religious service held.
The clipper ship Cromdale is completed. She is the last fully rigged ship built for the Australian wool trade.
The Johnstown Inclined Plane opens in Johnstown, Pennsylvania.
Minas Gerais was granted in 1891.
The first long-distance transmission of alternating current is made, from the Ames power plant near Telluride, Colorado, by Lucien and Paul Nunn.
Arthur Conan Doyle 's detective Sherlock Holmes appears in The Strand Magazine (London) for the first time, in the issue dated July.
The Springboks rugby union team of South Africa play their first international test match against the Lions team of the British Isles, and lose by 4–0.
The first American Express traveler's cheque is cashed.
France and Russia conclude a defensive alliance.
The first penalty kick is awarded in an Association football match: John Heath scores it for Wolverhampton Wanderers in England.
The Chilean Civil War of 1891 ends with the suicide of deposed President José Manuel Balmaceda and victory for the Congressional party, beginning the country's Parliamentary Era.
The first hydropower plant of Finland is commissioned along the Tammerkoski rapids in Tampere, Pirkanmaa.
Club Atlético Peñarol is founded in Montevideo, under the name of the CURCC (Central Uruguay Railway Cricket Club).
Thyssen, predecessor of the Thyssen Krupp worldwide conglomerate, is founded in Duisburg, Germany.
Eugène Dubois finds the first fragmentary bones of Pithecanthropus erectus (later redesignated Homo erectus), or " Java Man ", at Trinil on the Solo River.
Stanford University in California opens its doors. October 1 Stanford University opens its doors.
Skansen is established as the world's first open-air museum by Artur Hazelius, on the island of Djurgården in Stockholm, Sweden.
The 8.0 M s Mino–Owari earthquake strikes the Gifu region of Japan. This oblique-slip event kills over 7,200, injures more than 17,000, and creates fault scarps that still remain visible.
A personal care brand in Japan and Asia, Lion Corporation was founded, as predecessor name was Kobayashi Tomijirō Shōten (小林富次郎商店). [ citation needed ]
Jindandao Incident: The Chinese Juu Uda League in Inner Mongolia massacres tens of thousands of Mongols, before being suppressed by government troops in late December.
The constitution of the First Brazilian Republic is promulgated.
The International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers is organized in St. Louis, Missouri.
Drexel University is inaugurated as the Drexel Institute of Art, Science and Industry in Philadelphia.
James Naismith invents basketball in the United States.
Nikola Tesla invents the Tesla coil.
Production of the Swiss Army Knife by Victorinox begins.
Brahmin teacher and nationalist Bal Gangadhar Tilak begins agitation for Indian Home Rule.
New Mexico Military Institute is founded (as Goss Military Institute) in Roswell, New Mexico Territory.
Seattle University is established as the Immaculate Conception school.
Asteroid 323 Brucia becomes the first asteroid discovered using photography.
Michelin patents the removable pneumatic bicycle tire.
Philips founded in Eindhoven, Netherlands, for the production of carbon-filament lamps and other electro-technical products.
Ellis Island begins processing immigrants to the United States.
Rudolf Diesel applies for a patent, on his compression ignition engine (the Diesel engine).
St. Petersburg, Florida is incorporated as a town.
Theodoros Deligiannis ends his term as Prime Minister of Greece and Konstantinos Konstantopoulos takes office.
8 – "Exclusive Agreement": Rulers of the Trucial States (Abu Dhabi, Dubai, Sharjah, Ajman, Ras al-Khaimah and Umm al-Quwain) sign an agreement, by which they become de facto British protectorates.

The first basketball game is played in public, between students and faculty at the Springfield YMCA before 200 spectators. The final score is 5–1 in favor of the students, with the only goal for the faculty being scored by Amos Alonzo Stagg.
Ernest Louis, a grandson of Queen Victoria, becomes Grand Duke of Hesse and the Rhine on the death of his father, Grand Duke Louis IV.
Jesse W. Reno patents the first escalator, installed at Coney Island.
The Liverpool Football Club is founded in England by John Houlding, the owner of Anfield; Houlding decides to form his own team after Everton leaves Anfield, in an argument over rent.
The St. Patrick's Day Snowstorm besieges Tennessee with upwards of 26 inches of snow, establishing accumulation records that still stand.
Sir Frederick Stanley, Governor General of Canada, announces his intention to donate the Stanley Cup for ice hockey.
The first ever French rugby championship final takes place in Paris. Pierre de Coubertin referees the match, which Racing Club de France wins 4–3 over Stade Français.
The world's first fingerprinting bureau is formally opened by the Buenos Aires Chief of Police; it has been operating unofficially since the previous year.
The Johnson County War breaks out between small farmers and large ranchers in Wyoming.
The General Electric Company is established through the merger of the Thomson-Houston Electric Company and the Edison General Electric Company.
Battle of Yemoja River: British troops defeat Ijebu infantry in modern-day Nigeria, using a maxim gun.
The last broad gauge train runs from Paddington on the Great Western Railway of England.
The British conquest of Ijebu Ode marks a major extension of colonial power into the Nigerian interior.
Prince George (later George V of the United Kingdom) becomes Duke of York.
An oil fire in Oil City, Pennsylvania, United States, kills 130 people.
The Chicago "L" begins operation for the first time with the opening of the Chicago and South Side Rapid Transit Railroad.

Homer Plessy, a mixed-race man, is arrested for deliberately sitting in a whites-only railroad car in Louisiana, leading to the landmark United States Supreme Court decision Plessy v. Ferguson, which legitimized " separate but equal " racial segregation in the United States.
The Limelight Department, later one of the world's first film studios, is officially established in Melbourne, Australia.
The Homestead Strike begins in Homestead, Pennsylvania, culminating in a battle between striking workers and private security agents on July 6.

18 – British general election: The Conservative and Liberal Unionist coalition government loses its majority in the House of Commons, eventually leading to Prime Minister Lord Salisbury 's resignation on August 12.
Samoa changes its time zone from 4 hours ahead of Japan to being 3 hours behind California, such that it crosses the International Date Line, and Monday, July 4 occurs twice.
Dr. José Rizal, Filipino writer, philosopher and political activist, is arrested by Spanish authorities in connection with La Liga Filipina.
Homestead Strike: The arrival of a force of 300 Pinkerton detectives from New York and Chicago results in a fight in which about 10 men are killed.
The Great Fire of 1892 devastates the city of St. John's, Newfoundland.
A hidden lake bursts out of a glacier on the side of Mont Blanc, flooding the valley below and killing around 200 villagers and holidaymakers in Saint-Gervais-les-Bains.
The United International Bureau for the Protection of Intellectual Property (UIBPIP or BIRPI) is established in Bern, Switzerland.
Queen Victoria meets with Martha Ann Ricks.
The Community of the Resurrection, an Anglican religious community for men, is founded by Charles Gore and Walter Frere, initially in Oxford.
The father and stepmother of Lizzie Borden are found murdered in their Fall River, Massachusetts home; she will be acquitted of their murder.
Thomas Edison receives a patent for a two-way telegraph.
Valparaíso, Chile founds its first football team, Santiago Wanderers.
William Ewart Gladstone assumes the U.K. premiership, as head of the Liberal government, with Irish Nationalist Party support.
The Pledge of Allegiance is first recited in the United States.
Amalthea, the fifth moon of Jupiter, is discovered by Edward Emerson Barnard.
Sergei Witte replaces Ivan Vyshnegradsky, as Russian finance minister.
Women are first admitted to Yale University's graduate school.
The University of Chicago holds its first classes.
Master criminal Adam Worth is captured in Liège, Belgium, during an attempted robbery of a money delivery cart.
The Dalton Gang, attempting to rob two banks in Coffeyville, Kansas, is shot by the townspeople; only Emmett Dalton, with 23 wounds, survives, to spend 14 years in prison.
To mark the 400th anniversary Columbus Day holiday, the " Pledge of Allegiance " is first recited in unison by students in U.S. public schools.
The Historical American Exposition opens in Madrid.
The first collection of Arthur Conan Doyle 's Sherlock Holmes stories from The Strand Magazine, The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes, is published in London.
The first football club in Bohemia, Slavia Praha is established, originally under name of Akademický cyklistický odbor Slavia (A.C.O.S.), focusing on cycling.
1892 United States presidential election: Grover Cleveland is elected over Benjamin Harrison and James B. Weaver, to win the second of his non-consecutive terms.
An anarchist bomb kills six in a police station in Avenue de l'Opéra, Paris.
The four-day New Orleans General Strike begins.
French troops occupy Abomey, capital of the kingdom of Dahomey.
The Hotel Zinzendorf catches fire in the city of Winston-Salem, North Carolina; 45 people die.
John Thompson becomes Canada's fourth prime minister.
First issue of Vogue is published in the United States.
The Nutcracker ballet, with music by Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky, is premiered at the Imperial Mariinsky Theatre in Saint Petersburg, Russia.
Viruses are first described by Russian biologist Dmitri Ivanovsky.

The Newcastle East End F.C. is renamed Newcastle United F.C., following the demise of the Newcastle West End F.C. and East End's move to St James' Park, formerly West End's home, in the north east of England.
A cholera outbreak occurs in Hamburg, Germany.
Diplomat Henry Galway secures a treaty by which Ovonramwen, Oba of Benin, ostensibly accepts British protection for his kingdom.
A 50-year-old tortoise called Timothy, previously serving as a naval mascot, is brought to the estate of Powderham Castle in England, where she lives until her death in 2004.
Webb C. Ball introduces railroad chronometers, which become the general railroad timepiece standards in North America.
The Washington National Cathedral is chartered by Congress; the charter is signed by President Benjamin Harrison.
The Independent Labour Party of the United Kingdom has its first meeting.
U.S. Marines from the USS Boston land in Honolulu, Hawaii, to prevent the queen from abrogating the Bayonet Constitution.
The Telefon Hírmondó service starts with around 60 subscribers, in Budapest.

Overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii: Lorrin A. Thurston and the Citizen's Committee of Public Safety in Hawaii, with the intervention of the United States Marine Corps, overthrow the government of Queen Liliuokalani.
The Tati Concessions Land, formerly part of Matabeleland, is formally annexed to the Bechuanaland Protectorate (modern-day Botswana).
Thomas Edison finishes construction of the first motion picture studio in West Orange, New Jersey.
19 – White Star Line cargo liner SS Naronic sinks without a trace in heavy seas on the Liverpool–New York transatlantic passage.
Rudolf Diesel receives a patent for the diesel engine.
The American University is established by an Act of Congress, in Washington, D.C.
USS Indiana, the first battleship in the United States Navy comparable to other nation's battleships of the time, is launched.
The Liverpool Overhead Railway opens with 2-car electric multiple units, the first to operate in the world.
Ivory Coast becomes a French colony.
In Belgium, Adam Worth is sentenced to 7 years for robbery (he is released in 1897).
The rank of Chief Petty Officer is established in the United States Navy.
The iconic Salt Lake Temple of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints is dedicated, after 40 years of construction.
The first recorded college basketball game occurs in Beaver Falls, Pennsylvania, between the Geneva College Covenanters and the New Brighton YMCA.
The Alpha Xi Delta Sorority is founded at Lombard College in Galesburg, Illinois.
The Free Presbyterian Church of Scotland is formed.
Belgian general strike of 1893: Riots erupt in Mons; the day after, the Belgian Parliament approves universal male suffrage.
The 1893 World's Fair, also known as the World's Columbian Exposition, opens to the public in Chicago, Illinois. The first United States commemorative postage stamps are issued for the event.
Panic of 1893: A crash on the New York Stock Exchange starts a depression.
Edison's 1½ inch system of Kinetoscope is first demonstrated in public, at the Brooklyn Institute.

Gandhi arrives in South Africa, where he will live until 1914, lead non-violent protests on behalf of Indian immigrants in the South African Republic (Transvaal), and develop a deeper experience of such activities.

The Anti-Saloon League is incorporated, originally as a state organization, in Oberlin, Ohio. On December 18, 1895, it becomes a nationwide organization. The same year, the American Council on Alcohol Problems is established, along with the Committee of Fifty for the Study of the Liquor Problem.
Wedding of Prince George, Duke of York, and Princess Mary of Teck: the future King George V of the United Kingdom marries at St James's Palace in London.
1893 German federal election: Small anti-Semitic parties secure 2.9% of the vote.
Gold is found in Kalgoorlie, Western Australia.
Lizzie Borden is acquitted of the axe murder of her parents in Fall River, Massachusetts in 1892.
The Wengernalpbahn railway in Wengen, Switzerland (Canton of Bern) is opened.
The flagship HMS Victoria (1887) of the British Mediterranean Fleet collides with HMS Camperdown (1885) and sinks in 10 minutes; Vice-admiral Sir George Tryon goes down with his ship.
Unveiling of the Shaftesbury Memorial Fountain at Piccadilly Circus in London with its statue of Anteros.
U.S. President Grover Cleveland is operated on in secret.
The small town of Pomeroy, Iowa, is nearly destroyed by a tornado; 71 people are killed and 200 injured.
Liberal general and politician José Santos Zelaya leads a successful revolt in Nicaragua.
Kōkichi Mikimoto, in Japan, develops the method to seed and grow cultured pearls.

Paknam Incident: Two French Navy ships are fired upon by Siamese cannons stationed at the Paknam Fort, that guards the Chao Phraya River. Three months later, Siam is forced to cede modern-day Laos to France.
Frederick Jackson Turner gives a lecture titled " The Significance of the Frontier in American History " before the American Historical Association in Chicago.
Scottish Association football club Dundee F.C. is formed.
The Corinth Canal is completed in Greece.
The world's first driving licenses are introduced in France under the Paris Police Ordinance.
The Ibadan area becomes a British protectorate, after a treaty signed by Fijabi, the Baale of Ibadan, with the British acting Governor of Lagos, George C. Denton.
The Sea Islands hurricane hits Savannah, Georgia, Charleston, South Carolina, and the Sea Islands, killing 1,000–2,000.
William Ewart Gladstone 's Government of Ireland Bill 1893, intended to give Ireland self-government, is rejected by the U.K. Parliament.
Under pressure of a general strike, the Belgian Federal Parliament enacts general multiple suffrage.
Russian monitor Rusalka sinks in a storm in the Gulf of Finland, with the loss of all 177 crew; her hulk is eventually discovered in 2003 off Helsinki.
Genoa Cricket & Athletic Club, the oldest Italian Association football club, is formed.

The World Parliament of Religions opens as an adjunct to the World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago; Bengali Hindu monk Swami Vivekananda receives a standing ovation for his address in response to his welcoming.
American Temperance University begins classes in Harriman, Tennessee (it closes after 15 years, in May 1908).
Settlers make a land run for prime land in the Cherokee Strip in Oklahoma.
Swami Vivekananda delivers an inspiring paper at the World Parliament of Religions in Chicago.
New Zealand becomes the first country in the world to grant women's suffrage.
Brothers Charles and Frank Duryea drive the first gasoline-powered motorcar in America, on public roads in Springfield, Massachusetts.
The Baháʼí Faith is first publicly mentioned in the United States, at the World Parliament of Religions in Chicago.
The World Parliament of Religions holds its closing meeting in Chicago.
The Portuguese sports club Futebol Clube do Porto is founded.
The first car number plates appear in Paris, France.
The Franco-Siamese Treaty of 1893 is signed, as the Kingdom of Siam cedes all of its territories east of the Mekong River to France, creating the territory of Laos.
The first students enter St Hilda's College, Oxford, England, founded for women by Dorothea Beale.

A devastating levee collapse, flash flood and landslide hit and damage around Kyushu Island, Shikoku Island and western Honshū in Japan, due to a strong typhoon wind; an official document reports that 2,044 people perish.

American sisters Patty Hill and Mildred J. Hill copyright their book Song Stories for the Kindergarten including "Good Morning to All". The melody, by Mildred Hill, is later adapted, without authorization, by Robert H. Coleman as "Good Morning to You!", with the second stanza containing the words to " Happy Birthday to You ", leading to a successful copyright lawsuit by the Hill sisters in 1934.
The Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization (IMRO) is founded in the town of Thessaloniki. Its aim is to liberate the region of Macedonia from the Ottoman Turks.
In Saint Petersburg (Russia), Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky conducts the first performance of his Symphony No. 6 in B minor, Pathétique, nine days before his death.
The 1893 World's Fair, also known as the World's Columbian Exposition, closes.
First Matabele War: Battle of Bembezi, British South Africa Company defeats an assault by the Matabele.
Colorado women are granted the right to vote.

The Durand Line is established as the boundary between British India and Afghanistan, by a memorandum of understanding signed by Sir Mortimer Durand, Foreign Secretary of British India, and Abdur Rahman Khan, Amir of Afghanistan.
FC Basel Association football club is founded in Switzerland.
Athletic club Královské Vinohrady, later Sparta Prague, is founded.

Arthur Conan Doyle 's story " The Adventure of the Final Problem ", published in the December dated issue of The Strand Magazine and serialized in Sunday newspapers worldwide, surprises the reading public by revealing that his popular character Sherlock Holmes had apparently died at the Reichenbach Falls on May 4, 1891.
First Matabele War: The Shangani Patrol of British South Africa Company soldiers is ambushed and annihilated, by more than 3,000 Matabele warriors.
Plural voting is abolished in New South Wales.
Antonín Dvořák 's Symphony No. 9 (From the New World) receives its premiere at Carnegie Hall, New York City, conducted by the composer, to immediate acclaim.
Booker T. Washington High School (Houston) is founded as "Colored High", the first African-American high school in Houston, Texas.
American pharmacist Caleb Bradham invents the recipe for what later becomes Pepsi. He originally sells it as 'Brad's Drink' at his pharmacy in New Bern, North Carolina.
8,000 Chinese have arrived in Cuba.
A 16th century Ardabil Carpet from Persia enters the collection of the South Kensington Museum in London.
The Girls' Brigade is founded in Dublin, Ireland, origin of the international Christian youth organisation.
TMI Episcopal is founded in San Antonio as "The West Texas School for Boys", quickly changed to "West Texas Military Academy", by Bishop James S. Johnston.
German physicist Wilhelm Wien formulates Wien's displacement law.
Sudbury, Ontario, Canada, is incorporated as a town.
The first recumbent bicycle, the Fautenil Vélociped, is made in France.
Evergreen Park, Illinois, is incorporated.
A military alliance is established between the French Third Republic and the Russian Empire.
William Kennedy Dickson receives a patent for motion picture film in the United States.
New England Telephone and Telegraph installs the first battery -operated telephone switchboard, in Lexington, Massachusetts.
French anarchist Émile Henry sets off a bomb in a Paris café, killing one person and wounding twenty.
French anarchist Martial Bourdin dies of an accidental detonation of his own bomb, next to the Royal Observatory, Greenwich, in London, England.

In Korea, peasant unrest erupts in the Donghak Peasant Revolution, a massive revolt of followers of the Donghak movement. Both China and Japan send military forces, claiming to come to the ruling Joseon dynasty government's aid.

The Local Government Act (coming into effect December 1894–January 1895) reforms local government in Britain, creating a system of urban and rural districts with elected councils, with elected civil parish councils in rural areas, and gives women, irrespective of marital status, the right to vote and stand in local (but not national) elections.
William Gladstone resigns as British Prime Minister.
Coca-Cola is sold in bottles for the first time.
A syzygy of planets occurs, as Mercury transits the Sun as seen from Venus, and Mercury and Venus both transit the Sun as seen from Saturn, but no two of the transits are simultaneous.
Coxey's Army (of the unemployed), the first significant protest march in the United States, departs from Massillon, Ohio, for Washington, D.C.
Britain establishes a protectorate over Uganda.
Manchester City Football Club is formed in north-west England under this name.
A bituminous coal miners' strike closes mines across the central United States.

Canada 's largest known landslide occurs in Saint-Alban, Quebec, displacing 185 million cubic metres (6.5 × 10 ^ 9 cu ft) of rock and dirt, and leaving a 40-metre (130 ft) scar that covers 4.6 million square metres (50 × 10 ^ 6 sq ft).
Third plague pandemic: Bubonic plague breaks out in the Tai Ping Shan area of Hong Kong (by the end of the year, the death toll is 2,552 people); it also breaks out this year in Canton.
Coxey's Army arrives in Washington; Coxey is arrested on the Capitol grounds.
The May Day Riots (against unemployment) break out in Cleveland, Ohio.
Pullman Strike: Three thousand Pullman Palace Car Company factory workers go on a "wildcat" (without union approval) strike in Illinois.
Blackpool Tower is opened in Blackpool, in north-west England, as a visitor attraction.
The Manchester Ship Canal and Docks are officially opened by Queen Victoria, linking the previously landlocked industrial city of Manchester, in north-west England, to the Irish Sea.
Dahomey becomes a French colony.
The International Olympic Committee is founded at the Sorbonne, Paris, at the initiative of Baron Pierre de Coubertin.
Sadi Carnot, president of France, is assassinated in Lyon.
Tower Bridge in London opens for traffic.
The football club FC La Chaux-de-Fonds is founded in Switzerland.
The short-lived Republic of Hawaii is proclaimed by Sanford B. Dole.
A fire at the site of the 1893 World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago destroys most of the remaining buildings.
The United Kingdom and Japan sign the Anglo-Japanese Treaty of Commerce and Navigation, as the U.K. becomes the first of the Western nations to agree to give up its extraterritorial rights in Japan.
The Paris–Rouen Competition for Horseless Carriages, the first automobile competition, is held.

War is declared between the Qing Empire of China and the Empire of Japan over their rival claims of influence on their common ally, the Joseon dynasty of Korea. The event marks the start of the First Sino-Japanese War.
Italian anarchist Sante Geronimo Caserio is executed by guillotine for the assassination of French President Carnot in Lyon.
New Zealand enacts the world's first minimum wage law, to take effect on January 1, in the passage of the Industrial Conciliation and Arbitration Act of 1894.
Great Hinckley Fire: A forest fire in Hinckley, Minnesota, kills more than 450 people.
In New York City, 12,000 tailors strike against sweatshop working conditions.
Richard Strauss marries Pauline De Ahna.
The SS Ohio (1875) and the schooner barge Ironton collide and sink in Lake Huron. While the crew of the Ohio is rescued, five of the other craft's seven-member crew, including the captain, are lost.
Petrópolis becomes the capital of the Brazilian state of Rio de Janeiro, until 1902.
Dreyfus affair: French Army officer Alfred Dreyfus is arrested for spying.
Domenico Menegatti obtains a patent for a procedure to be applied in producing pandoro industrially.
Republicans win by a landslide in the United States House of Representatives elections, which sets the stage for the decisive presidential election of 1896.
The Masonic Grande Loge de France is founded, splitting from the larger and older Grand Orient de France.

First Sino-Japanese War: Battle of Lushunkou – Japanese troops secure a decisive victory over the Chinese, capture the port city of Lüshunkou, and begin the Port Arthur massacre, in which more than 1,000 Chinese servicemen and civilians die.
Wedding of Nicholas II of Russia and Alix of Hesse in the Grand Church of the Winter Palace at Saint Petersburg.
Kate Chopin 's feminist short story " The Story of an Hour " is first published, in the American magazine Vogue.

Women in South Australia become the first in Australia to gain the right to vote and the first in the world with the right to be elected to Parliament, taking effect from 1895, after decades of activism.
Mackenzie Bowell becomes Canada's fifth prime minister.
The Liga Femeilor Române, the first women's organisation in Romania, is founded.
The Society of Beaux-Arts Architects is founded in the United States.

Edward B. Marks and Joe Stern publish the waltz The Little Lost Child in the United States, promoting the playing of the waltz with slides projected by a magic lantern, the earliest version of music video known as the illustrated song.
Oil is discovered on the Osage Indian reservation, making the Osage the "richest group of people in the world".
Spillers Records is founded in Cardiff (Wales), the world's oldest record shop still in operation.
Dreyfus affair: French Army officer Alfred Dreyfus is convicted of treason.

Dreyfus affair: French officer Alfred Dreyfus is stripped of his army rank and sentenced to life imprisonment on Devil's Island (off French Guiana) on what is much later admitted to be a false charge of treason.

The Wilcox rebellion, an attempt led by Robert Wilcox to overthrow the Republic of Hawaii and restore the Kingdom of Hawaii, begins with royalist troops landing at Waikiki Beach in Oahuand clashing with republican defenders. The rebellion ends after three days and the remaining 190 royalists are taken prisoners of war.
Britain's National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty is founded by Octavia Hill, Robert Hunter and Canon Hardwicke Rawnsley.
First Italo-Ethiopian War: Battle of Coatit – Italian forces defeat the Ethiopians.
A warehouse fire and dynamite explosion kills 57 people, including 13 firefighters in Butte, Montana in the U.S.
A 6.8 magnitude earthquake strikes northeastern Iran near the town of Quchan and causes at least 1,000 deaths.

The U.S. Supreme Court rules in United States v. E. C. Knight Co. that Congress and the U.S. federal government cannot regulate manufacturing, and dismisses an antitrust lawsuit against American Sugar Refining Company, which controls 98 percent of sugar refining in the United States.
The American steamer S.S. Chicora sinks in a storm on Lake Michigan, along with all 21 of its crew and a lone passenger.
An effort to restore the Hawaiian monarchy ends as the former Queen Liliʻuokalani abdicates and pledges allegiance to the Republic of Hawaii.

The sinking of the German ocean liner SS Elbe kills 334 people on board, 20 minutes after the ship had collided with the British steamer SS Crathie. Only two lifeboats are able to evacuate before the Elbe goes down, and the first lifeboat capsizes when too many passengers attempt to get onboard. A second lifeboat, with 15 members of the crew, four men and woman, carries the only survivors.

The gold reserve of the U.S. Treasury is saved when J. P. Morgan and the Rothschilds loan $65 million worth of gold to the United States government. The offering of syndicate bonds sells out only 22 minutes after the New York market opens, and just two hours after going on sale in London.

Venezuelan crisis of 1895: U.S. President Grover Cleveland signs into law a bill resulting from the proposition of House Resolution 252, by William Lindsay Scruggs and Congressman Leonidas Livingston, to the third session of the 53rd Congress of the United States of America. The bill recommends that Venezuela and Great Britain settle their dispute by arbitration.
The first rebellions of the Cuban War of Independence break out.
In Munich, Germany, bicyclists have to pass a test and display license plates.
Japanese troops capture Liaoyang and land in Taiwan.
Heian Shrine is completed in Kyoto, Japan.

Bridget Cleary is killed and her body burned in County Tipperary, Ireland, by her husband, Michael; he is subsequently convicted and imprisoned for manslaughter, his defence being a belief that he had killed a changeling left in his wife's place after she had been abducted by fairies.
The world's first gasoline bus route is started in Germany, between Siegen and Netphen.

Brothers Auguste and Louis Lumière make what is probably the first presentation of a projected celluloid film moving picture, the 46-second Workers Leaving the Lumière Factory, to members of the Société d'encouragement pour l'industrie nationale in Paris.
Rudolf Diesel patents the Diesel engine in Germany.
Oscar Wilde is arrested in London for "gross indecency", after losing a criminal libel case against the Marquess of Queensberry.
Nansen's Fram expedition to the Arctic reaches 86°13.6'N, almost 3° beyond the previous Farthest North attained.
A major earthquake severely damages Ljubljana, the capital of Carniola.

The Treaty of Shimonoseki is signed between China and Japan. This marks the end of the First Sino-Japanese War, and the defeated Qing Empire is forced to renounce its claims on Korea, and to concede the southern portion of Fengtian province, Taiwan and the Penghu to Japan. The huge indemnity exacted from China is used to establish the Yawata Iron and Steel Works in Japan.
Gongche Shangshu movement: 603 candidates sign a 10,000-word petition against the Treaty of Shimonoseki.
The unique, historic and picturesque Spiral Bridge is constructed to carry U.S. 61 over the Mississippi River at Hastings, Minnesota. It is demolished in 1951.
Gongche Shangshu movement: Thousands of Beijing scholars and citizens protest against the Treaty of Shimonoseki.
Thirteen workers are killed by soldiers of the Russian Empire during the Yaroslavl Great Manufacture strike.

The first motor race in Italy is held, on a course from Turin to Asti and back, a total of 93 km (58 mi). Five entrants start the event; only three complete it. It is won by Simone Federman in a four-seat Daimler Omnibus, at an average speed of 15.5 km/h (9.6 mph).
Anti-Japanese officials, led by Tang Jingsong in Taiwan, declare independence from the Qing dynasty, forming the short-lived Republic of Formosa.

R. v. Wilde: Oscar Wilde is convicted in London of "unlawfully committing acts of gross indecency with certain male persons" (under the Labouchere Amendment) and given a two years' sentence of hard labour, during which he will write De Profundis.
In re Debs: The Supreme Court of the United States decides that the federal government has the right to regulate interstate commerce, legalizing the military suppression of the Pullman Strike.
The Liberal Revolution begins in Ecuador, making the civil war more intense in the country.
Britain annexes Tongaland, between Zululand and Mozambique.
The Paris–Bordeaux–Paris automobile trial is held.
The Kiel Canal, connecting the North Sea to the Baltic across the base of the Jutland peninsula in Germany, is officially opened.
The Treaty of Amapala establishes the union of Nicaragua, Honduras and El Salvador (which ends in 1898).
The United States Court of Private Land Claims rules that James Reavis 's claim to the Barony of Arizona is "wholly fictitious and fraudulent".
11 – The Doukhobors ' pacifist protests culminate in the "burning of the arms" in the South Caucasus.
Archie MacLaren scores an English County Championship cricket record innings of 424 for Lancashire, against Somerset, at Taunton. This record lasts until 1994.
Oldham Athletic A.F.C. is founded in England.
The Basque Nationalist Party (Euzko Alderdi Jeltzalea-Partido Nacionalista Vasco) is founded by Sabino Arana.
The Aljaž Tower, a symbol of the Slovenes, is erected on Mount Triglav.
The first ever indoor promenade concert, origin of The Proms, is held at the Queen's Hall in London, opening a series conducted by Henry Wood.
American frontier murderer and outlaw John Wesley Hardin is killed by an off-duty policeman in a saloon in El Paso, Texas.

The Northern Rugby Football Union (the modern-day Rugby Football League) is formed at a meeting of 21 rugby clubs at the George Hotel, Huddersfield, in the north of England, leading to the creation of the professional sport of rugby league football.
The Mat Salleh Rebellion in North Borneo is incited.
Shelbourne F.C. is founded in Dublin, Ireland.
The first professional American football game is played, in Latrobe, Pennsylvania, between the Latrobe YMCA and the Jeannette Athletic Club (Latrobe wins 12–0).
The first game of what will become known as rugby league football is played in England, starting the 1895–96 Northern Rugby Football Union season.
Daniel David Palmer performs the first chiropractic spinal adjustment, on Harvey Lillard, whose complaint was partial deafness after an injury.

October 3 – the Automobile Club de France sponsors the longest race to date, a 1,710 km (1,060 mi) event, from Bordeaux to Agen and back. Because it is held in ten stages, it can be considered the first rally. The first three places are taken by two Panhards and a three-wheeler De Dion-Bouton.
French troops capture Antananarivo, Madagascar.
Peiyang University, predecessor of Tianjin University, is founded as an institution of higher education in Qing dynasty China.
Queen Min, queen consort of Joseon (Korea), is assassinated at her private residence within Gyeongbokgung Palace by Japanese agents.
The city of Tainan, last stronghold of the Republic of Formosa, capitulates to the forces of the Empire of Japan, ending the short-lived republic, and beginning the era of Taiwan under Japanese rule.

1895 Charleston earthquake: A major earthquake occurs near Charleston, Missouri, in the New Madrid Seismic Zone of the midwestern United States. As of 2014, the earthquake risk for the region will be closely monitored.
Max Skladanowsky and his brother Emil present a short film at the Berlin Wintergarten theatre in Germany using the movie projector they have developed.
George B. Selden is granted the first U.S. patent for an automobile.
Wilhelm Röntgen discovers the type of electromagnetic radiation later known as X-rays.
Flamengo, a well known professional football club in Brazil, is officially founded.
Oscar Hammerstein opens the Olympia Theatre, the first theatre to be built in New York City's Times Square district.
At the Swedish-Norwegian Club in Paris, Alfred Nobel signs his last will and testament, setting aside his estate to establish the Nobel Prize after his death.
Chicago Times-Herald race: The first American automobile race in history is sponsored by the Chicago Times-Herald. Press coverage first arouses significant American interest in the automobile.
A corps of 2,350 Italian troops, mostly Askari, are crushed by 30,000 Abyssinian troops at Amba Alagi.

Svante Arrhenius becomes the first scientist to deliver quantified data about the sensitivity of global climate to atmospheric carbon dioxide (the " Greenhouse effect "), as he presents his paper "On the Influence of Carbonic Acid in the Air Upon The Temperature of the Ground" to the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences.
The railways of the Cape of Good Hope, Colony of Natal, the Orange Free State, the South African Republic and southern Mozambique are all linked at Union Junction near Alberton.
The Laurin & Klement automobile brand, predecessor of Škoda Auto, is founded as a bicycle manufacturer in central Bohemia (modern-day Czech Republic).
George Washington Vanderbilt II officially opens his Biltmore Estate, inviting his family and guests to celebrate his new home in Asheville, North Carolina.
Kingstown lifeboat disaster: 15 crew are lost when their life-boat capsizes while trying to rescue the crew of the Palme off Kingstown (modern-day Dún Laoghaire), near Dublin, Ireland.
The Duck Reach Power Station opens in Tasmania (the first publicly owned hydroelectric plant in the Southern Hemisphere).
Auguste and Louis Lumière make what is probably the first commercial public screening of projected moving picture films to a paying audience, at the Salon Indien du Grand Café in Paris.
The world's first portable handheld electric drill is developed, by brothers Wilhelm and Carl Fein in Germany.
Konstantin Tsiolkovsky proposes a space elevator.
The first sample fair (Mustermesse) is held at Leipzig, Germany.
The first Boxer dog club is established in Germany.
The Raiffeisen model of Cooperative Credit and Saving Bank, predecessor of Rabo Bank, a worldwide multiple financial service provider, is founded in the Netherlands.
The name ' HP Sauce ' is first registered in the United Kingdom for a brown sauce.
The Swarovski Company is founded by Armand Kosman, Franz Weis and Daniel Swarovski in the Austrian Tyrol, for the production of crystal glass.
The Jameson Raid comes to an end as Jameson surrenders to the Boers.
Utah is admitted as the 45th U.S. state.
An Austrian newspaper reports Wilhelm Röntgen 's discovery, last November, of a type of electromagnetic radiation, later known as X-rays.
Cecil Rhodes is forced to resign as Prime Minister of the Cape of Good Hope for his involvement in the Jameson Raid.
American culinary expert Fannie Farmer publishes her first cookbook.
H. L. Smith takes the first X-ray photograph.
Devonport High School for Boys is founded in Plymouth (England).
Fourth Anglo-Ashanti War: British redcoats enter the Ashanti capital, Kumasi, and Asantehene Agyeman Prempeh I is deposed.
Walter Arnold, of East Peckham, Kent, England, is fined 1 shilling for speeding at 8 mph (13 km/h), exceeding the contemporary urban speed limit of 2 mph (3.2 km/h), the first speeding fine.
Puccini 's opera La bohème premieres in Turin, Italy.
Oscar Wilde 's play Salomé (1891) has its stage premiere (while Wilde is in prison) in its original French in Paris.
Braamfontein Explosion: A train carrying 56 tons of dynamite explodes at Braamfontein, Johannesburg, killing more than 78 people.
Battle of Adwa: Ethiopia defends its independence from Italy, ending the First Italo-Ethiopian War.
Publication begins for Der Eigene, the world's first magazine with an orientation to male homosexuality, by Adolf Brand in Berlin.
Responding to national outrage at the defeat at Adwa, Italian Prime Minister Francesco Crispi resigns.
The Royal College of St Patrick, Maynooth in Ireland is granted the status of pontifical university by charter of the Holy See.

Svante Arrhenius first publishes the "greenhouse law", becoming the first person to predict that emissions of carbon dioxide from the burning of fossil fuels and other combustion processes are large enough to cause global warming through the greenhouse effect.
The first known women's basketball game between two colleges is played between Stanford and California.
The opening ceremonies of the 1896 Summer Olympics, the first modern Olympic Games, are held in Athens, Greece.
The National Farm School (later Delaware Valley College) is chartered in Doylestown, Pennsylvania.
Blackpool Pleasure Beach, a popular English theme park ("Britain's Biggest Tourist Attraction"), is founded by Alderman William George Bean.
Cricket: Against Warwickshire, Yorkshire sets a still-standing County Championship record in England, when they accumulate an innings total of 887.
The Franchise Bill is passed by the Colony of Natal 's Legislative Assembly, disfranchising natives of other countries.
Plessy v. Ferguson: The U.S. Supreme Court introduces the separate but equal doctrine, and upholds racial segregation.

Coronation of Nicholas II and Alexandra Feodorovna in the Dormition Cathedral, Moscow; this will be the last coronation of the Russian monarch. The Qing dynasty is represented at the coronation by Chinese official Li Hongzhang who through September goes on to visit Germany, Britain, Canada and the United States.
Eleven years after its foundation, a group of 12 purely industrial stocks are chosen to form the Dow Jones Industrial Average. The index is composed entirely of industrial shares for the first time.

St. Louis–East St. Louis tornado: The costliest and third deadliest tornado in U.S. history levels a mile wide swath of downtown St. Louis, Missouri, incurring US$2.9 billion (1997 USD) in normalized damages, killing more than 255 and injuring over 1,000 people.
The Ford Quadricycle, the first vehicle developed by Henry Ford, is completed, eventually leading Ford to build the empire that "put America on wheels".
Mahdist War: Battle of Ferkeh – British and Egyptian troops are victorious.
J. T. Hearne sets a record for the earliest date of taking 100 wickets in cricket, in England (it is equalled by Charlie Parker in 1931).
The 8.5 M w Sanriku earthquake and tsunami kills 22,000 in northeastern Japan.
The New York Telephone Company is formed, succeeding the Metropolitan Telephone and Telegraph Company, to control telephone service within New York City.
Liberal leader Wilfrid Laurier defeats Charles Tupper during Canadian federal elections for the 8th Canadian Parliament, to become the first Francophone Prime Minister of Canada.
Twin Shaft disaster: An explosion in the Newton Coal Company's Twin Shaft Mine in Pittston, Pennsylvania results in a massive cave-in that kills 58 miners.
William Jennings Bryan delivers his Cross of Gold speech at the Democratic National Convention, which nominates him for president of the United States.
Wilfrid Laurier becomes Canada's seventh prime minister, and the first French-speaker to hold that office.
In Washington, D.C., in response to a "call to confer" issued by Josephine St. Pierre Ruffin to all women of color, the National Association of Colored Women's Clubs is organized.
The International Socialist Workers and Trade Union Congress opens in London.
A causeway is opened between the islands of Saaremaa and Muhu in Estonia.
The 1896 Eastern North America heat wave kills 1,500 people from Chicago, Illinois to Boston, Massachusetts.

Atlantic City rail crash: Shortly after 6:30 pm, at a crossing just west of Atlantic City, New Jersey, two trains collide, crushing five loaded passenger coaches, killing 50 and seriously injuring approximately sixty.
The Park Seung-jik shop, predecessor of South Korean conglomerate Doosan Group, is founded in Joseon (the kingdom of Korea).
The Uganda Railway Act, 1896, is approved in the United Kingdom, for construction of a railway in Africa from Mombasa to Lake Victoria.
Skookum Jim Mason, George Carmack and Dawson Charlie discover gold in the Klondike, Yukon.
Bridget Driscoll is run over by a Benz car on the grounds of The Crystal Palace, London, the world's first motoring fatality.
The Cry of Pugad Lawin initiates the Philippine Revolution.
Britain establishes a Protectorate over the Ashanti people concluding the Fourth Anglo-Ashanti War.
The shortest war in recorded history, the Anglo-Zanzibar War, starts at 9:00 in the morning, and lasts for 45 minutes of shelling.
Clarkson University holds its first classes, with 17 students attending in Potsdam, New York.
The Crash at Crush train wreck stunt is held in Texas.
Queen Victoria surpasses her grandfather King George III as the longest-reigning monarch in British history up to this time.
Pathé Frères, a French film company and one of the oldest film companies, is founded by the brothers Charles Pathé, Théophile Pathé, Émile Pathé and Jacques Pathé.
Khodynka Tragedy: a crowd crush at Khodynka Field in Moscow kills at least 1,200 of those marking the coronation year of Emperor Nicholas II of Russia.
Italy and France sign a treaty whereby Italy virtually recognizes Tunisia as a French dependency.
Gottlieb Daimler builds the first gasoline truck.
The Victorian Football League is established as Australian rules football in Australia (a predecessor of the Australian Football League).
The Augusta High School cornerstone is laid in Augusta, Kentucky, marking the end of the Augusta Methodist College.
1896 United States presidential election: Republican William McKinley defeats William Jennings Bryan. The event is viewed by some as a political realignment for the United States Republican Party.
Richard Strauss 's orchestral tone poem Also sprach Zarathustra is first performed, in Frankfurt, conducted by the composer.
Udinese Calcio Association football club is founded in Udine, Italy.
" St. Augustine Monster ": A large carcass, later postulated to be the remains of a gigantic octopus, is found washed ashore near St. Augustine, Florida.

Archaeologist Alois Anton Führer, Nepalese General Khadga Samsher Rana and an expedition rediscover the great stone pillar of Ashoka at Lumbini, traditionally the spot of the birthplace of Gautama Buddha, after using Faxian 's records.
New York Aquarium opens.
The premiere of Alfred Jarry 's absurdist play Ubu Roi in Paris causes a near-riot.
The Glasgow Subway, the third-oldest underground metro system in the world, opens.
John Philip Sousa composes The Stars and Stripes Forever which will become the national march of the United States.
Racing Club de Lyon, a football club in France, is officially founded and becomes a predecessor of Olympique Lyonnais. [ citation needed ]
Pope Leo XIII is filmed, making him the first ever Pope to be filmed and the earliest-born person to be captured on film.
The pharmaceutical and healthcare company Hoffmann-La Roche in Switzerland comes wholly under the control of Fritz Hoffmann-La Roche.
France establishes an administrative post in Abengourou, Ivory Coast.
José Rizal, Filipino scholar and poet, is executed by Spanish authorities in the Philippines.
A school of mines opens in Kimberley and will form the core of the University of the Witwatersrand.
The International Alpha Omicron Pi sorority is founded, in New York City.
A British force is ambushed by Chief Ologbosere, son-in-law of the ruler. This leads to a punitive expedition against Benin.
A cyclone destroys Darwin, Australia.
Lady Flora Shaw, future wife of Governor General Lord Lugard, officially proposes the name "Nigeria" in a newspaper contest, to be given to the British Niger Coast Protectorate.
In this date's issue of the journal Engineering, the word computer is first used to refer to a mechanical calculation device.
The Czechoslovak Trade Union Association is founded in Prague.
Freedom of religion is proclaimed in Madagascar.
The French conquer the island of Raiatea and capture the rebel chief Teraupo'o, ending the Leeward Islands War and bringing all of the Society Islands under their control.
Benin is put to the torch by the British Army's Benin Expedition. Ovonramwen, Oba of Benin, is exiled from his kingdom and the Benin Bronzes are carried off to London.
The Sigma Pi fraternity is founded in Vincennes, Indiana.
The French military governor of Madagascar, Joseph Gallieni, exiles Queen Ranavalona III to Réunion, abolishing the monarchy the next day.
San Diego State University is founded.
Emilio Aguinaldo unseats Andrés Bonifacio at the Tejeros Convention, becoming the new head of the Filipino revolutionary group Katipunan.
Yamaichi Securities founded in Japan; it will cease trading a hundred years later.

Drillers near Bartlesville, Oklahoma strike oil for the first time, in the designated "Indian Territory", on land leased from the Osage Indians. The gusher, at the Nellie Johnstone Number One well, leads to rapid population growth.
the Greco-Turkish War of 1897 Breaks out.
The first Boston Marathon is held in the United States, with fifteen men competing, and won by John McDermott.
Representatives of the Chickasaw Nation, Choctaw Nation and U.S. Dawes Commission sign the Atoka Agreement, which becomes an important precursor for creating the State of Oklahoma.
6 May – Greco-Turkish War of 1897: Battle of Velestino.

J. J. Thomson of the Cavendish Laboratory announces his discovery of the electron as a subatomic particle, over 1,800 times smaller than a proton (in the atomic nucleus), at a lecture at the Royal Institution in London.
John Jacob Abel announces the successful isolation of epinephrine (adrenaline), in a paper read before the Association of American Physicians.
19 zinc miners die of carbon monoxide poisoning at Snaefell Mine on the Isle of Man.

A patent is awarded for the invention of the first automotive muffler, with the granting by the U.S. Patent Office of application number 582,485 to Milton Reeves and his brother Marshall T. Reeves, of the Reeves Pulley Company of Columbus, Indiana.
The Stars and Stripes Forever, an American patriotic march by John Philip Sousa, is performed for the first time.
The Scientific-Humanitarian Committee (Wissenschaftlich-humanitäres Komitee, WhK) is founded in Berlin as an LGBT campaigning organization, the first such in history.
Oscar Wilde is released from prison in England, and goes into voluntary exile on the continent.
The Blackwall Tunnel, at this time the longest underwater road tunnel in the world, is opened for traffic beneath the River Thames in the East End of London by the Prince of Wales.
Irish-born theatrical manager Bram Stoker 's contemporary Gothic horror novel Dracula is first published (in London); it will influence the direction of vampire literature for the following century.

On Decoration Day (later Memorial Day) the Robert Gould Shaw Memorial is dedicated in Boston. The bronze bas relief by Augustus St. Gaudens depicts the 54th Massachusetts Infantry Regiment of black Civil War soldiers.
1897 Assam earthquake: An earthquake of magnitude of 8.0 rocks Assam, India, killing over 1,500 people.
Kyoto University is officially established in Japan.
The Diamond Jubilee of Queen Victoria is celebrated in the United Kingdom. No other British monarch will celebrate such a jubilee until Elizabeth II in 2012.
S. A. Andrée's Arctic Balloon Expedition of 1897 begins. The ill-fated expedition to fly over the Arctic results in the death of the entire team within months.
The Klondike Gold Rush begins when the first successful prospectors arrive in Seattle
Writer Jack London sails to join the Klondike Gold Rush, where he will write his first successful stories.
August 2 – Siege of Malakand: British troops are besieged by Pashtun tribesmen in Malakand, on the Northwest frontier of British India (modern-day Khyber Pakhtunkhwa in Pakistan).
Mount Saint Elias, the second highest peak in the United States and Canada, is first ascended.

At the Bayer pharmaceutical company, pharmacist Felix Hoffmann successfully synthesizes acetylsalicylic acid, after isolating a compound from a plant of the Spiraea family; the company markets it under the brand name " Aspirin ".
The Olds Motor Vehicle Co. is founded in Lansing, Michigan, by Ransom E. Olds.
The First Zionist Congress convenes in Basel, Switzerland.
Thomas Edison is granted a patent for the Kinetoscope, a precursor of the movie projector.
The Tremont Street subway is opened in Boston, Massachusetts.
Lattimer massacre: A sheriff's posse kills 19 unarmed immigrant miners in Pennsylvania.
After months of searching, generals of Menelik II of Ethiopia capture Gaki Sherocho, the last king of Kaffa, bringing an end to that ancient kingdom.

Battle of Saragarhi: Twenty-one Sikhs of the 36th Sikhs regiment of the British Indian Army defend an army post to the death, against 10,000 Afghan and Orakzai tribesmen, in the Tirah Campaign on the Northwest frontier of the British Raj (modern-day Khyber Pakhtunkhwa in Pakistan).
Greece and Turkey sign a peace treaty to end the Greco-Turkish War.
Francis P. Church responds (anonymously) to a letter to the editor of The Sun (New York City) that is known as the famous " Yes, Virginia, there is a Santa Claus " letter.
After a long siege, Brazilian government troops take Canudos in north Brazil, crushing Antônio Conselheiro and his followers.
Ethiopia adopts the tricolor flag: green is for the land, yellow for gold, and red is symbolic of strength and the blood shed.
USS Baltimore (Cruiser # 3, later CM-1) is recommissioned, since 1890, for several months of duty in the Hawaiian Islands.
The Korean Empire is proclaimed, marking the end of the Joseon dynasty after just over 500 years.
The city of Belo Horizonte, Brazil is created. The construction of the second Brazilian planned city is completed successfully; an immigration of 1,000,000 people is estimated.
HMS Canopus, a pre-dreadnought battleship of the Royal Navy, is launched at Portsmouth, England; she will be deployed widely in World War I.
The Kappa Delta sorority is founded in Farmville, Virginia.
Juventus FC is founded as an association football club in Turin.
Spain grants Puerto Rico autonomy.
The first issue of the feminist newspaper La Fronde is published by Marguerite Durand in Paris.
The comic strip The Katzenjammer Kids debuts in the New York Journal.
Belo Horizonte, the first planned city in Brazil, is incorporated.
Pact of Biak-na-Bato: The Philippine Revolution is settled, with Spanish promises to reform.
The play Cyrano de Bergerac, by Edmond Rostand, premieres in Paris.
Natal annexes Zululand.
The first electric bicycle is invented.
Karl Lueger becomes mayor of Vienna.
Zhejiang University is founded in China.
Émile Durkheim publishes his classic study Suicide.
The pan-African anthem " Nkosi Sikelel' iAfrika " ("God Bless Africa") is composed as a Xhosa hymn by South African teacher Enoch Sontonga.
Dos Equis beer is first brewed in Mexico, in anticipation of the new century. "Dos equis" is Spanish for "two x", a reference to the 20th Century (XX in Roman numerals)
Alexander Scriabin publishes his Piano Sonata no. 2 "Sonata-Fantasia" in G sharp minor

New York City annexes land from surrounding counties, creating the City of Greater New York as the world's second largest. The city is geographically divided into five boroughs: Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, The Bronx and Staten Island.

Novelist Émile Zola 's open letter to the President of the French Republic on the Dreyfus affair, J'Accuse…!, is published on the front page of the Paris daily newspaper L'Aurore, accusing the government of wrongfully imprisoning Alfred Dreyfus and of antisemitism.

The automobile belonging to Henry Lindfield of Brighton rolls out of control down a hill in Purley, London, England, and hits a tree; thus he becomes the world's first fatality from an automobile accident on a public highway.

Spanish–American War: The USS Maine explodes and sinks in Havana Harbor, Cuba, for reasons never fully established, killing 266 men. The event precipitates the United States' declaration of war on Spain, two months later. February 15: USS Maine is sunk.
Émile Zola is imprisoned in France, after writing J'Accuse…!.
Vladimir Lenin creates the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party in Minsk
Association football and sports club BSC Young Boys is established in Bern, Switzerland, as the Fussballclub Young Boys.
In Melbourne the representatives of five colonies adopt a constitution, which will become the basis of the Commonwealth of Australia.
Robert Allison of Port Carbon, Pennsylvania, becomes the first person to buy an American-built automobile, when he buys a Winton automobile that has been advertised in Scientific American.
The Sabie Game Reserve in South Africa is created, as the first officially designated game reserve.

Annie Oakley promotes the service of women in combat situations, with the United States military. On this day, she writes a letter to President McKinley "offering the government the services of a company of 50 'lady sharpshooters' who would provide their own arms and ammunition should war break out with Spain."
Spanish–American War: The United States Navy begins a blockade of Cuban ports and the USS Nashville captures a Spanish merchant ship.
Spanish–American War: A conference of senior Spanish Navy officers led by naval minister Segismundo Bermejo decide to send Admiral Pascual Cervera 's squadron to Cuba and Puerto Rico.
Spanish–American War: The United States declares war on Spain; the U.S. Congress announces that a state of war has existed since April 21 (later backdating this one more day to April 20).
In Essen, German company Rheinisch-Westfälisches Elektrizitätswerk RWE is founded.
An explosion in Santa Cruz, California, kills 13 workers, at the California Powder Works.
The Paris Auto Show, the first large-scale commercial vehicle exhibition show, is held in Tuileries Garden.
Spanish–American War – Battle of Manila Bay: Commodore Dewey destroys the Spanish squadron, in the first battle of the war, as well as the first battle in the Philippines Campaign.
Thousands of Chinese scholars and Beijing citizens seeking reforms protest in front of the capital control yuan.
9 – Bava Beccaris massacre: Hundreds of demonstrators are killed, when General Fiorenzo Bava Beccaris orders troops to fire on a rally in Milan, Italy.
The first games of the Italian Football Federation are played, in which Genoa played against Torino.
Spanish–American War: The Puerto Rican Campaign begins, with the Bombardment of San Juan.
The German Federation football club SV Darmstadt 98 is formed.
The territory of Kwang-Chou-Wan is leased by China to France, according to the Treaty of 12 April 1892, as the Territoire de Kouang-Tchéou-Wan, forming part of French Indochina.

Secondo Pia takes the first photographs of the Shroud of Turin and discovers that the image on the Shroud itself appears to be a photographic negative. The original flag of the Philippines as conceived by General Emilio Aguinaldo. The blue is of a lighter shade than the currently mandated royal blue, the sun has eight points as currently but many more rays and it has a mythical face.
The Trans-Mississippi Exposition World's Fair opens, in Omaha, Nebraska.
William Ramsay and Morris Travers discover neon at their laboratory at University College London, after extracting it from liquid nitrogen.
The British government arranges a 99-year rent of Hong Kong from China.
Tuone Udaina, the last known speaker of the Dalmatian language, is killed in an explosion.
The Guangxu Emperor announces the creation of what would later become Peking University.
Philippine Declaration of Independence: After 333 years of Spanish dominance, General Emilio Aguinaldo declares the Philippines ' independence from Spain.
Yukon Territory is formed in Canada, with Dawson chosen as its capital.
Food processing giant Nabisco is founded in New Jersey. [ page needed ]
Spanish–American War: The United States captures Guam, making it the first U.S. overseas territory.
Effective date of the Curtis Act of 1898 which will lead to the dissolution of tribal and communal lands in Indian Territory and ultimately the creation of the State of Oklahoma in 1907.

Spanish–American War: Battle of San Juan Hill – United States troops (including Buffalo Soldiers and Theodore Roosevelt 's Rough Riders) take a strategic position close to Santiago de Cuba from the Spanish.
American adventurer Joshua Slocum completes a 3-year solo circumnavigation of the world.
The United States Navy destroys the Spanish Navy 's Caribbean Squadron.
